CHIEF
  JUSTICE TOAL:Â Â Â Â  In this product liability case, we granted a petition for
  a writ of certiorari in our original jurisdiction to review the trial courtâ€™s
  discovery order compelling Petitioner Bridgestone Corporation (Bridgestone) to
  turn over its steel belt skim stock formula, classified as a trade secret, to
  Respondent Russell Laffitte.Â  For the reasons detailed below, we find that
  Respondent has not shown that knowledge of Bridgestoneâ€™s trade secret is
  necessary in order for Respondent to litigate this product liability action.Â 
  Consequently, the trial courtâ€™s order compelling disclosure by Bridgestone of
  the skim stock formula is reversed.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On July 16, 2005, Angela Plyler was driving her 1999 Ford Explorer
  along Interstate 95 in Hampton County with her three children as passengers.Â 
  The tread from the left rear tire of the Explorer separated from the tire,
  allegedly causing the vehicle to overturn and collide with a tree.Â  The single‑car
  accident killed Angela and her teenage son Justin, and seriously injured her
  daughters Alania and Hannah.
Respondent, acting as personal representative for the decedents
  and as conservator for the minor daughters, filed four separate lawsuits
  against several defendants, including Bridgestone, the manufacturer of the
  vehicleâ€™s left rear tire.Â  The complaints allege negligence, warranty, and
  strict liability claims against Bridgestone.Â  As to the negligence allegations,
  Respondent maintains Bridgestone used an inadequate tire design and failed to
  use proper manufacturing techniques resulting in a defective tire.Â  In
  addition, Respondent specifically alleges Bridgestone failed to use sufficient
  antidegradants to protect the integrity of the tire.Â Â Â  
The four
  cases were consolidated for discovery purposes.Â  Respondent sought to obtain
  information on the design and manufacturing processes for the subject tire,
  which had been manufactured in 1996 at Bridgestoneâ€™s Hofu Plant in Japan.[1]Â  Bridgestone objected to Respondentâ€™s
  requests for its steel belt skim stock formula[2] and other related information on the basis that the skim stock formula was a
  trade secret of Bridgestone.[3]Â 
  According to Bridgestone, Respondent can prove his claims without discovery of
  the skim stock formula because he has access to the actual failed tire and can therefore
  conduct appropriate testing on the tire itself.Â  Respondent counters that
  without the information related to the skim stock ingredients and manufacturing
  processes, including any plant-specific deviations from the manufacturing
  formula, the defect claims cannot be proven.
The
  trial court held a hearing in January 2007 on Respondentâ€™s motion to compel and
  Bridgestoneâ€™s cross-motion for a protective order.Â  The trial court informed
  counsel in February 2007 that it would be granting the motion to compel.Â  Prior
  to entry of the final order, however, the trial court granted Bridgestoneâ€™s
  request that it be allowed to depose Respondentâ€™s experts solely on the issue
  of Respondentâ€™s need for the skim stock formula.Â  Four experts provided
  affidavit or deposition testimony on the issue of Respondentâ€™s need for the
  skim stock formula.Â  
Bridgestoneâ€™s expert, Brian Queiser, described the various factors
  beyond the tireâ€™s chemical composition which could affect the tireâ€™s
  durability.[4]Â 
  According to Queiserâ€™s affidavit:

  A tire is a highly engineered, complex product, which is the
    result of a blend of chemistry and engineering.Â  A steel belted radial
    passenger tire typically contains twenty or more components and more than a
    dozen different rubber compounds. . . . 
  . . . Furthermore, the individual components of a steel belted
    radial tire are designed to work in conjunction with the other components of
    that tire.Â  As a result, the forces exerted on the tire during its operation
    are subject to the combined effects of many parameters, including tire size;
    inflation pressure; component materials, dimensions, and gauge; as well as
    vehicle characteristics.Â  Therefore, it is not accurate to gauge the
    performance of any particular tire by focusing on one isolated component or
    compound.
  . . . . 
  . . . Given the inherent design of any steel belted radial tire, .
    . . the areas of the steel belt edges are generally the areas of highest
    stress/strain. Â As a result, any steel belted radial tire can sustain a
    tread/belt separation due to numerous service conditions such as overloading,
    underinflation, punctures, road hazards, impact damage and so forth.

Queiser
  further explained that rubber compound formulas cannot be reverse engineered
  from the finished product because once a tire is cured, the chemical
  composition changes. Queiser asserted that because the physical properties of
  the subject tire itself could be inspected and tested, â€œ[a]ccess to the formulas
  is unnecessary to determine whether the tire was properly designed and
  manufactured.â€Â  As to the trade secret nature of the skim stock formula,
  Queiser described the formula as â€œone of Bridgestone/Firestoneâ€™s most valuable
  assets and most closely guarded secrets.â€Â  
At his
  deposition, when asked why the skim stock formula was unnecessary in the
  instant litigation, Queiser responded as follows:

  Well, I guess in this case, as I understand it, all that you would
    need is what you essentially have.Â  You have the tire, you have the ability to
    test the tire, test its physical properties.Â  It has been my experience that
    that is all you need to evaluate the condition of the tire as it relates to its
    performance.Â  It is my experience that the ability to have the chemical
    information, the recipe, really doesnâ€™t answer those questions for you.Â  The
    formula or recipe doesnâ€™t give you the performance, frankly, which is the most
    important element.

Queiser
  elaborated that when the federal government investigated certain tires
  manufactured by Bridgestone/Firestone, Inc., which were similar to tires
  recalled by Firestone in August 2000, â€œ[f]ormula was not part of the report . .
  . , it was all about the performance, the design of the tire from a mechanical
  and structural perspective and the performance of that tire.Â  It was not about
  the chemical constituents or the recipe.â€ When pressed by Respondentâ€™s
  counsel as to whether the skim compound or manufacturing process was ever
  considered as part of the federal investigation, Queiser answered as follows:

  No, I would not say â€œnever
    considered.â€Â  But certainly it was something that was clearly early set aside
    as a probable cause.Â  We had so many tires produced from so many different
    plants with that same formula, hundreds of which . . . had absolutely no claim
    or lawsuit associated with them on that same compound.Â  That formula or
    compound, per se, no, it wasnâ€™t a factor early on.

Queiser also described how rubber changes over time from
  exposure to oxygen and ozone, noting that â€œ[t]he environment, the use of the
  tire or the rubber, how the rubber is used, [and] other external influences
  naturally are a part of its properties over time.â€Â  Queiser acknowledged that
  oxidation in general would cause changes in the makeup of a rubber compound,
  but qualified his statement saying that chemical changes in rubber compounds,
  in his opinion, were still not fully understood by modern science.Â  Queiser also acknowledged that antidegradants are
  added to the skim stock compound to combat the effects of oxygen on a tire and
  that there were â€œother inherent qualitiesâ€ of other ingredients in the tire
  which â€œmay also lend themselves to some resistance to change.â€Â  Queiser
  nonetheless adhered to his view that by physically testing the subject tire -
  perhaps by viewing it at a microscopic level - would be the appropriate way to
  assess whether there is a design defect.Â  
Finally, Queiser testified that the skim
  stock compound chemically interfaces with the brass which covers the steel
  belts, and that this â€œis one of the essences of the trade secret nature of the
  chemical composition and the production of that compound.â€Â  If a competitor were
  to have knowledge on this aspect of tire design, Queiser stated that the
  competitor would essentially acquire â€œa companyâ€™s decadesâ€™ worth of experienceâ€
  which would give it â€œa huge competitive advantage.â€Â  
Respondent presented three experts to opine on the need
  for the skim stock formula in support of the motion to compel.Â  Robert C. Ochs
  stated in an affidavit that he had evaluated the subject tire to determine why
  the tire failed.[5]Â 
  Ochs averred as follows:

  My initial evaluation of the tire reveals that the tire failed
    prematurely as a result of a defect in the tire.Â  At this time I cannot state
    whether the defect is in the manufacture or design of the tire.Â  
  [Respondent has] requested that I work together with James E.
    Duddey, Ph.D. and Richard J. Smythe, Ph.D. to determine if the failure was the
    result of a manufacturing defect or a design defect.Â  In order to perform the
    specific work requested by [Respondent] it will be necessary to compare the
    failed tire with its initial physical properties as designed by Bridgestone.Â  
  Because this failure involves a separation of the tread belt, it
    will be necessary to examine the skim compound formula to aid in determining
    the true nature of the defect.Â  Once the skim compound used to manufacture the
    subject tire is analyzed, both for its intended physical properties and as
    compared to the central compound formula, I will then be able to render
    opinions on the true nature of the defect.

Respondentâ€™s second expert, Dr. James Duddey inspected the failed
  tire and made the following observations in his affidavit:[6]

  Examination of the tire demonstrates a premature failure caused by
    the separation of the steel belts.Â  The tire shows evidence of surface cracking
    that could be caused by fatigue or premature rubber aging.Â  The tire tread
    piece examined demonstrates a degree of hardness in the skim stock that may be
    related to either the initial physical properties of the rubber compound or
    premature aging.

Additionally,
  because Respondentâ€™s counsel specifically requested that Duddey review the skim
  stock formula to determine whether a design defect existed in the subject tire,
  and whether changes made to the antidegradant package used in the skim stock
  formula affected the aging mechanical properties of the tire, Duddey stated that
  he needed â€œaccess to documents showing the initial physical properties of the
  rubber compound to determine whether there exists a plant specific
  manufacturing issue or an overall design issue.â€Â  
At his deposition,
  Duddey acknowledged that a number of factors, such as overload and
  underinflation, could cause belt separation in tires that were properly
  designed.Â  Duddey also explained that there were multiple possible causes for
  the increased hardness found in the subject tire, including oxidative aging and
  heat exposure.Â  
As to needing the skim stock formula in order to determine why the
  subject tire exhibited hardness, Duddey testified that â€œas a starter you need
  to know what the properties were as the tire was designed and manufactured and
  then you need to try to make some judgment as to if itâ€™s significantly
  different than when it was manufactured, how it got to that point.â€Â  Duddey
  admitted, however, that both the hardness and the cracking found in the subject
  tire did not necessarily relate back to the formulation of the compound, but
  could also have been associated with how the tire had been used.Â  Duddey explained
  that if Bridgestone provided the skim stock formula for the subject tire,
  ultimately all he could do was make a comparison as to â€œwhat is the general
  practice that is out there in the supplier literature and the technical
  literature.â€Â  
Respondentâ€™s
  third expert, Dr. Richard Smythe, was hired to analyze certain materials within
  the tire deemed important by experts Ochs or Duddey.[7]Â  Smythe indicated that he would
  design an analytical protocol in order to evaluate certain aspects of the skim
  stock formula and that if Ochs and Duddey determined that the subject tire did
  not exhibit the physical properties intended by its design, he would be able to
  assist in a root-cause analysis of why that tire failed.Â  Smythe asserted that
  it was â€œabsolutely necessaryâ€ that he know all of the ingredients in the rubber
  compound in order to render his expert opinion in the matter.Â Â Â Â  
After considering the expertsâ€™ depositions and the partiesâ€™
  supplemental briefs, the trial court issued an order compelling discovery and issued
  a restrictive protective order.[8]Â 
  Specifically, the trial court found that Respondent had met the prerequisites
  for discovery of trade secret information under either Rule 26(c), SCRCP, or
  the South Carolina Trade Secrets Act, S .C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 39-8-10 et seq. (Supp. 2007) (hereinafter â€œTrade Secrets
  Actâ€).Â  The trial court
  concluded that Respondentâ€™s experts had established the need for the skim stock
  formula, stating as follows:

  [Respondentâ€™s] claim [is] that the failed tire experienced a steel
    belt separation.Â  It further appears it is the skim stock compound that is
    designed to provide adhesion between the steel belts and between surrounding
    components.Â  As such, the composition of the ingredients, both actual and
    intended, and the method by which the rubber compound was made is relevant to
    the inquiry into why the subject tire failed.Â  While it may be possible, it
    appears unlikely that [Respondent] could seriously pursue a design defect
    theory without access to the materials and methods used to manufacture the
    portion of the tire claimed to be responsible for the failure.

Bridgestone
  thereafter petitioned for certiorari review of the trial courtâ€™s order in this
  Courtâ€™s original jurisdiction.Â  The Court granted the petition and Bridgestone
  raises the following issues for review:

  
    I. 
    
    What is the
  appropriate standard for the discovery of trade secret information in a product
  liability action?
  
  
  
    II.    
    Did the trial court
  err in finding that Respondent established the requisite need for Bridgestone’s
  trade secret skim stock formula?
  

STANDARD OF REVIEW
Ordinarily,
  an order compelling discovery is not directly appealable.Â  Lowndes Products,
    Inc. v. Brower, 262 S.C. 431, 205 S.E.2d 184 (1974).Â  Nevertheless, a
  writ of certiorari may be issued when exceptional circumstances exist.Â  See
    In re Breast Implant Product Liability Litigation, 331 S.C. 540, 503 S.E.2d
  445 (1998).Â  The instant case presents such exceptional circumstances as it
  involves a novel question of law in a matter that has been the subject of
  numerous claims in state and federal courts.Â  A decision by this Court at this
  time best serves the interests of judicial economy by eliminating the numerous
  inevitable appeals raising this novel issue of significant public interest.Â  Id. n.2. Â 
On
  certiorari, review by the Court is confined to the correction of errors of
  law.Â  Berry v. Spigner, 226 S.C. 183, 84 S.E.2d 381 (1954).
LAW/ANALYSIS
We
  begin our analysis by putting the legal nature of a trade secret into context.Â 
  As aptly described in a recent opinion by the Indiana Supreme Court:

  Trade
    secrets are unique creatures of the law, not property in the ordinary sense,
    but historically receiving protection as such. Â Unlike other assets, the value of a trade secret
    hinges on its secrecy. Â As more people or organizations learn the secret, the
    value quickly diminishes. Â For this reason, owners or inventors go to great
    lengths to protect their trade secrets from dissemination.
  The value of trade secret
    protection to a healthy economy has been widely accepted for some time. Â Over
    the last two hundred years, the law has developed mechanisms for accomplishing
    this end.

Bridgestone Am. Holding, Inc. v. Mayberry, 878 N.E.2d 189, 192 (Ind. 2007) (footnote omitted).
However, it is also
  true that â€œtrade secrets may be valuable during the
  course of litigation not involving misappropriation claims, and there are
  moments when justice requires disclosure.â€Â  Id. at 193.Â  In spite of
  this acknowledgement of the potential value of trade secrets in litigation, the Mayberry court also cautioned that â€œcourts must proceed with care when
  supervising the discovery of trade secrets, lest the judiciary be used to
  achieve misappropriation or mere leverage.â€Â  Id.

I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Standard for Discovery of Trade Secrets
The
  question of what standard governs the discovery of trade secret information is
  a novel issue in South Carolina.Â  Under the Trade Secrets Act, a person â€œaggrieved
  by a misappropriation, wrongful disclosure, or wrongful use of his trade
  secrets may bring a civil action to recover damages incurred as a result of the
  wrongful acts.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 39-8-30(C).Â  The Trade Secrets Act addresses
  discovery matters and provides in pertinent part as follows: 

  (A) In an action under this
    chapter, a court shall preserve the secrecy of an alleged trade secret by
    reasonable means, which may include granting protective orders in connection
    with discovery proceedings, holding hearings in-camera, sealing the records of
    the action, and ordering any person involved in the litigation not to disclose
    an alleged trade secret without prior court approval.
  (B) In any civil action where discovery is sought of
    information designated by its holder as a trade secret, before ordering
    discovery a court shall first determine whether there is a substantial need by
    the party seeking discovery for the information.
  â€œSubstantial needâ€ as used in
    this section means:
  
    (1) the allegations in the initial pleading setting
      forth the factual predicate for or against liability have been plead with particularity;
    (2) the information sought is directly relevant to the
      allegations plead with particularity in the initial pleading;
    (3) the information is such that the proponent of the
      discovery will be substantially prejudiced if not permitted access to the
      information; and
    (4) a good faith basis exists for the belief that
      testimony based on or evidence deriving from the trade secret information will
      be admissible at trial.
  

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 39-8-60.Â 
  Although Respondent suggests that the Trade Secrets Act only applies to those
  actions alleging trade secret misappropriation,[9] we find that the plain language of Â§ 39-8-60(B) clearly indicates that trade
  secrets may be protected during discovery not only in misappropriation cases,
  but in â€œany civil actionâ€ where trade secrets are sought during discovery.Â  See
    Key Corp. Capital, Inc. v. County of Beaufort, 373 S.C. 55, 59, 644 S.E.2d
  675, 677 (2007) (noting that where a statuteâ€™s language is plain,
  unambiguous, and conveys a clear meaning, the court has no right to impose
  another meaning).Â  
This
  is not to say, however, that the â€œsubstantial needâ€ language of the Trade
  Secrets Act is the sole relevant inquiry in determining the standard governing
  trade secret information.Â  As Respondent points out, the South Carolina Rules
  of Civil Procedure also provide for the protection of trade secret information
  when such information is sought during discovery.Â  Specifically, Rule 26(c),
  SCRCP, allows for protective orders under certain circumstances as follows:

  Upon motion by a party or by
    the person from whom discovery is sought, and for good cause shown, the
    court in which the action is pending . . . may make any order which justice
    requires to protect a party or person from annoyance, embarrassment,
    oppression, or undue burden by expense, including one or more of the following:
    . . . (7) that a trade secret or other confidential research, development, or
    commercial information not be disclosed or be disclosed only in a designated
    way.

In
  determining whether trade secret information is subject to a protective order
  under Rule 26(c)(7), federal and state courts typically apply a balancing test that
  incorporates a â€œrelevant and necessaryâ€ standard for the party seeking to
  discover the trade secret information.[10]Â 
    See generally 8 Charles Alan Wright, Arthur R. Miller & Richard L.
  Marcus, Federal Practice and Procedure Â§ 2043 (2d ed. 1994) (hereinafter
  â€œWright & Millerâ€); James J. Watson, Annotation, Discovery of Trade
    Secret in State Court Action, 75 A.L.R.4th 1009, 1028-30 (1990).Â  The test
  is a three-part inquiry:

  
    1.    
    The party opposing discovery must
  show that the information sought is a trade secret and that disclosure would be
  harmful.
    
    
  
  
    2.
    If trade secret status is
  established, the burden shifts to the party seeking discovery to show that the
  information is relevant and necessary to bring the matter to trial. 
    
    
  
  
    3. 
    If both parties satisfy their
  burden, the court must weigh the potential harm of disclosure against the need
  for the information in reaching a decision. 
  

See
  also Mayberry, 878 N.E.2d at 193; Coca-Cola
    Bottling Co. of Shreveport, Inc. v. Coca-Cola Co., 107 F.R.D. 288, 292-93
(D. Del. 1985).[11]Â  
We disagree
  with Respondentâ€™s argument that our determination that the Trade Secrets Act applies
  to any civil action impermissibly supplants a rule of civil procedure.Â  See
    Baggerly v. CSX Transp., Inc., 370 S.C. 362, 635 S.E.2d
  97 (2006) (rejecting an interpretation of a statute which would have
  contravened a rule of evidence).Â  Unlike the statute at issue in Baggerly,
  Â§ 39-8-60 does not improperly limit the operation of Rule 26, but rather is
  consistent with Rule 26 in that both provide for reasonable restrictions on the
  discovery of trade secrets.Â  The Trade Secrets Act therefore does not supplant,
  but rather complements, Rule 26(c), SCRCP.Â  Cf. Mayberry, 878
  N.E.2d at 194 (finding that the application of Rule 26 to trade secrets â€œshould
  be informed by Indianaâ€™s enactment of the Uniform Trade Secrets Actâ€). 
To
  this end, we hold that the balancing test associated with the discovery of
  trade secret information under Rule 26(c), SCRCP, governs the discovery of
  trade secret information in this matter.Â  Regarding the requirement that the
  trade secret information must be â€œrelevant,â€ we hold that the information must
  be relevant not only to the general subject matter of the litigation, but also relevant
  specifically to the issues involved in the litigation.Â  See Duplan Corp. v.
    Deering Milliken, Inc., 397 F.Supp. 1146, 1185 (D.S.C. 1974).Â  For the
  trade secret information to be deemed â€œnecessary,â€ we hold that the party
  seeking the information â€œcannot merely assert unfairness but must demonstrate
  with specificity exactly how the lack of the information will impair the
  presentation of the case on the merits to the point that an unjust result is a
  real, rather than a merely possible, threat.â€Â  In re Bridgestone/Firestone,
    Inc., 106 S.W.3d 730, 733 (Tex. 2003); accord
      Bridgestone/Firestone, Inc. v. Superior Court, 9 Cal.Rptr.2d 709,
  713 (Cal. Ct. App. 1992) (holding that a party seeking discovery must make
  a â€œparticularized showingâ€ that â€œthe information sought is essential to a fair
  resolution of the lawsuitâ€).Â  â€œImplicit in this is the notion that suitable
  substitutes must be completely lacking.â€ Â Mayberry, 878 N.E.2d at
  196.Â  In other words, the trial court must evaluate whether there are
  reasonable alternatives available to the party seeking the discovery of the
  information, and ultimately, the trial court must require the discovery of a
  trade secret only when â€œthe issues cannot be fairly adjudicated unless the
  information is available.â€Â  Wright & Miller, Â§ 2043. 
From
  here, we turn to an analysis of the second issue on appeal in order to
  determine whether Respondent meets the â€œrelevant and necessaryâ€ standard of
  proof for discovery of a trade secret.
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Application of the standard to Respondentâ€™s request
for Bridgestoneâ€™s skim stock formula
Bridgestone argues
  that the trial court erred in finding that discovery of the skim stock formula
  was necessary to Respondentâ€™s case.Â  Specifically, Bridgestone contends that:Â 
  (1) the expert testimony does not establish that if the experts were provided
  the skim stock formula and related manufacturing information, they would
  necessarily be able to opine on a defect; and (2) other methods, such as testing
  the tire itself, are available to Respondent.Â  We agree.Â  
In our view, Respondentâ€™s expertsâ€™ reasons for opining that the
  formula was necessary for their analyses do not rise to the level of
  specificity required for discovery of trade secrets.Â  For example, expert
  Smythe did not elaborate on why it was â€œabsolutely necessaryâ€ that he know the
  skim stock formula in order to render his expert opinion in the matter.Â 
  Furthermore, although expert Ochs concluded in his affidavit that it was necessary
  to compare the failed tire with its initial physical properties because the
  tireâ€™s failure involved a separation of the tread belt, Ochs never explained
  how the occurrence of a tread belt separation should result in the automatic
  conclusion that the belt separation was related to the initial physical
  properties of the tire requiring disclosure of the skim stock formula.Â  Given
  Queiserâ€™s and Duddeyâ€™s testimony on the many potential causes of tread belt
  separation related to the usage of the tire rather than its initial physical
  properties, we find that Ochsâ€™s testimony lacks the precision required for
  Respondent to show that disclosure of Bridgestoneâ€™s skim stock formula is
  necessary to this case.Â  See also
    Bridgestone/Firestone, Inc. v. Superior Court, 9 Cal.Rptr.2d at 716 (finding that the tire expert did not â€œdescribe
  with any precision how or why the formulas were a predicate to his ability to
  reach conclusions in the caseâ€).Â  
Expert Duddeyâ€™s reasoning for acquiring the formula
  was similarly vague.Â  In his affidavit, Duddey initially attributed the
  apparent surface cracking on the subject tire to either
  â€œfatigue or premature rubber aging,â€ and the degree of hardness in the skim
  stock to â€œeither the initial physical properties of the rubber compound or
  premature aging.â€ When later asked at
  deposition to elaborate on the need for the skim stock formula, Duddey
  responded that â€œas a starter you need to know what the properties were as the
  tire was designed and manufactured and then you need to try to make some judgment
  as to if itâ€™s significantly different than when it was manufactured, how it got
  to that point.â€Â  Duddey provided no indication in his response at deposition
  that he had examined and subsequently discarded the alternative theories
  propounded in his affidavit for the tireâ€™s failure.Â  For this reason, we find
  that this testimony fails to adequately articulate how disclosure of the skim
  stock formula is critical to the analysis in this case.Â  
We find also find no evidence that the skim stock
  formula is essential to a defect inquiry.Â  Bridgestoneâ€™s expert Queiser clearly
  indicated that because a tire is a complex object made up of many compounds, it
  would be inaccurate to gauge the performance of a
  particular tire by focusing on one isolated component or compound.Â  Queiser also
  noted how properties of the skim rubber compounds change as the tire
  ages.Â Â  Respondentâ€™s experts, however, focused solely
  on the tireâ€™s initial properties without addressing Queiserâ€™s assertions
  regarding the interaction of compounds in the tire during the curing process
  and throughout the tireâ€™s lifetime.Â  In this way, we find Respondentâ€™s experts
  failed to provide a sufficiently complete argument as to why the skim stock
  formula was necessary to their analyses of this case. 
Furthermore, the expertsâ€™ testimony provides no
  detailed indication as to how the case is incapable of being fairly adjudicated
  without the trade secret information.Â  See In re Bridgestone/Firestone, Inc.,
  106 S.W.3d at 733 (holding that the party seeking trade secret information
  cannot simply claim unfairness but must show â€œwith specificity how the lack of
  the information will impair the presentation of the case on the merits to the
  point that an unjust result is a real, rather than a merely possible,
  threatâ€).Â  While we recognize the logic in Respondentâ€™s
  theory that in order to prove a tire design or manufacturing defect, it would
  be useful to have knowledge of the original recipe and whatever manufacturing
  deviations were made from that recipe, we reiterate that the standard for
  discovery of trade secret information is â€œnecessary,â€ not â€œuseful.â€Â  See Bridgestone/Firestone,
    Inc. v. Superior Court, 9 Cal.Rptr.2d at 715 (finding that â€œit is not
  enough that a trade secret might be usefulâ€ to the party seeking discovery).Â  
Additionally,
  we find that the trial court failed to analyze the availability of reasonable
  alternatives to the discovery of the trade secret. Â Specifically, a chemical
  analysis necessitating the discovery of Bridgestoneâ€™s skim stock formula is not
  the sole, or even the best, way to test for defects.Â  We
  find an October 2001 report issued by the National Highway Traffic
  Safety Administration (NHTSA) particularly
  instructive to the Court in this regard.[12]Â  The stated purpose of the federal investigation documented in this
  report was to determine whether Firestoneâ€™s August 2000 recall of Wilderness AT
  tires was adequate in scope.Â Â  The report focused on non-recalled tires that
  were manufactured primarily as original equipment for Ford Explorers, yet were
  similar to the tires recalled by Firestone in 2000.Â  The study used peer tires,
  mostly Goodyear Wrangler tires, in order to compare performance results to the
  Wilderness AT tires being evaluated.
The methods of the federal
  recall investigation, employed on both Firestone tires and the peer tires,
  included â€œthorough analyses of available data regarding the performance of
  tires in the field; shearography analysis to evaluate crack initiation and
  growth patterns and their severity in tires obtained from areas of the country
  where most of the failures have occurred; and observations, physical
  measurements, and chemical analyses.â€Â  NHTSA Report at iii.Â  Additionally, the
  NHTSA conducted belt peel adhesion testing, a physical test on one-inch wide
  samples of tire tread which are essentially pulled by a tensile test machine
  â€œto measure the force required to â€˜peelâ€™ the two belts apart.â€Â  Id.Â  The report explained the purpose of this test as follows:

  [T]he properties of the belt wedge
    and skim rubber compounds change as the tire ages.Â  These changes reduce the
    compoundsâ€™ resistance to fatigue crack growth and catastrophic failure.Â  One
    measure of the degradation of the belt rubber is the peel adhesion test.Â  This
    test is most directly related to the belt rubberâ€™s resistance to a final,
    catastrophic belt-leaving-belt failure.

Id.Â  The report specifically noted there was
  â€œno evidence of a belt wire-to-rubber adhesion issue.â€Â  Id. at 23 n.38.
The NHTSA
  concluded that a safety-related defect existed in Firestone Wilderness AT
  P235/75R15 and P255/75R16 tires manufactured prior to May 1998 at specified
  manufacturing facilities.Â  One of the primary findings was that the design of
  the shoulder pocket of the tires could â€œcause high stresses at the belt edge
  and lead to a narrowing of the wedge gauge at the pocket,â€ indicated by â€œa
  series of weak spots around the tireâ€™s circumference, leading to the initiation
  and growth of cracksâ€ in the tires. Â Id. at 30.Â  
We find it significant that the NHTSA, without focusing on the skim stock
  formula, conducted physical testing of the tires and ultimately arrived at a
  scientifically-supported conclusion that there was a design defect which caused
  belt separation.Â  This reliance on a structural analysis to determine
  defect, rather than a chemical analysis, provides tangible proof that other adequate means of testing for defects are available
  to Respondent and that therefore, Respondentâ€™s case will not be substantially
  impaired if he is denied access to the trade secret information.Â  We note that
  other jurisdictions have similarly recognized that physically
  testing the tire itself for defects, including testing at a molecular level if
  necessary, may be a suitable substitute for testing based on the skim
  stock formula.Â  See Mayberry, 878 N.E.2d at 196 (noting that
  testimony revealed that an inspection of the failed tire appears to be â€œmore
  than an adequate substitute for examining the skim stock formulaâ€); In re
    Bridgestone/Firestone, Inc., 106 S.W.3d at 733 (finding that because a tireâ€™s physical properties can be tested
  without knowing the recipe for the skim stock compound, tests on a finished
  tire are â€œmore probative of defect than its skim stock formula would beâ€).Â  
Further,
  the discovery already available to Respondent for analysis of the alleged
  defect includes information about development, design review, and testing of
  tires manufactured with the same specifications as the tire in this case.Â  Bridgestone
  has also produced or agreed to produce analysis reports of inner liner problems
  with similar tires, reports from cut tire analysis done at the Hofu plant, and
  records and depositions from similar cases involving Bridgestone tires.Â  The
  variety of information these documents encompass provides Respondent with
  â€œsuitable substitutesâ€ for analysis of the skim stock formula itself.Â  Mayberry,
  878 N.E.2d at 196.Â  Thus, particularly in light of the discovery obtainable in
  this case, Respondent has not shown that the case is incapable of being fairly
  adjudicated without the trade secret information.Â  
For
  these reasons, we hold that under the proper standard governing the discovery
  of trade secrets, knowledge of Bridgestoneâ€™s skim
  stock formula is not â€œnecessaryâ€ in order for
  Respondent to litigate the instant product liability action.[13]Â  Accordingly, we hold that
  the trial court erred in finding that Respondent was entitled to discovery of
  Bridgestoneâ€™s trade secret information.
We
  note that Bridgestone should not use our holding in this matter at trial to
  suggest weaknesses in Respondentâ€™s case due to his expertsâ€™ ignorance about the
  formula.Â  See In re Bridgestone/Firestone, Inc., 106 S.W.3d at 734
  (recognizing that it would be unfair for the manufacturer to argue the
  plaintiffâ€™s case was impaired due to lack of evidence that the manufacturer
  withheld); Bridgestone/Firestone, Inc. v. Superior Court, 9 Cal.Rptr.2d
  at 716 n.8 (noting that it would be unfair for the manufacturer to challenge an
  expert at trial about his knowledge of the skim stock formula).Â  Indeed, if at
  any time during the litigation, Respondent can satisfy his burden of showing
  necessity, this matter could be revisited.Â  See In re Bridgestone/Firestone,
    Inc., 106 S.W.3d at 734 (finding that while the mere possibility of
  unfairness is not enough to warrant disclosure of the information, this issue
  can be addressed should it materialize).Â  
CONCLUSION
For
  the foregoing reasons, we hold that Respondent failed
  meet the standard for the discovery of Bridgestoneâ€™s trade secret information,
  and therefore, we reverse the decision of the trial court compelling the
  disclosure of Bridgestoneâ€™s trade secret.
BEATTY,
  KITTREDGE, JJ., and Acting Justice James E. Moore, concur.Â  PLEICONES, J.,
dissenting in a separate opinion.

JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  I respectfully dissent, and would affirm the
  circuit courtâ€™s order compelling petitioner to disclose the skim stock
  formula.Â  Since this order is before us on a common law writ of certiorari, we
  may reverse the trial courtâ€™s decision only if it is affected by an error of
  law.Â  Berry v. Spigner, 226 S.C. 183, 84 S.E.2d 381 (1954).Â  We cannot
  consider the facts, â€œexcept to ascertain whether the order is wholly
  unsupported by the evidence.â€Â  Id.Â  Since I find evidence in the record,
  particularly the affidavit of Dr. Duddey, which supports the circuit courtâ€™s
order, I would affirm.
In my opinion, the
  majority reverses not because there is no evidence, nor because the circuit
  court committed an error of law, but because, in the majorityâ€™s view, the
  petitionersâ€™ experts were more persuasive than those of respondent.Â  For
  example, the majority states respondentâ€™s experts did not address Queiserâ€™s
  assertion that a tireâ€™s performance is not dependent on its initial
  composition. Dr. Duddey, however, acknowledged that post-manufacturing factors
  could explain the tireâ€™s failure, but also maintained that he needed the
  formula in order to determine whether a design defect, perhaps in the
  antidegradant package component of the formula, contributed to its failure.Â  In
  my view, whether this was sufficiently specific is a judgment call for the
  trial judge.
Moreover, the
  majority opines that â€œa chemical analysis necessitating the discovery of
  Bridgestoneâ€™s skim stock formula is not the sole, or even the best, means to
  test for defectâ€ and holds there is â€œno evidence that the skim stock formula is
  essential to a defect inquiry.â€Â  It is not respondentâ€™s burden under either the
  Trade Secrets Act or Rule 26 (c) (7), SCRCP to demonstrate that knowledge of
  the trade secret is the â€œbestâ€ or â€œsoleâ€ way for it to proceed, nor that it is
  â€œessential,â€ but rather that it has a â€œsubstantial needâ€[14] for this â€œrelevant and necessaryâ€[15] information.Â  Applying our limited scope of review on certiorari[16] to the order before us, I would hold there is evidence to support the trial
  judgeâ€™s findings that respondent has met his burden.
I would affirm.


[1] The subject tire is a P235/75R15 Radial ATX steel
  belted radial passenger tire and was designed for use as a replacement tire.Â 
  At the time of the accident, the subject tire was being used as a spare and was
  the only Bridgestone tire on the Explorer; Michelen manufactured the other
  three tires.
[2] According to Bridgestoneâ€™s expert witness, steel belt skim stock is â€œa
  specifically formulated rubber compound calendered onto the steel cord to form
  the steel belts in a steel belted radial passenger or light truck tire,â€ which
  is â€œformulated to provide, among other things, adhesion between the rubber and
  steel cord, and between the belts and surrounding components.â€Â  The formula of
  a rubber compound such as the steel belt skim stock â€œtypically contains the
  chemicals or ingredients used in the compound; the quantities or relative
  percentages of those ingredients; and the manner in which those ingredients are
  processed to form the compound and give it the desired physical properties
  after it is vulcanized, or cured.â€ 
[3] Respondent has not disputed
  that the skim stock formula is a trade secret.Â  Under South Carolina law, a trade secret is defined as
  information, including a formula or process, that:

  (i) derives independent economic value, actual or
    potential, from not being generally known to, and not being readily
    ascertainable by proper means by the public or any other person who can obtain
    economic value from its disclosure or use, and
  (ii) is the subject of efforts that are reasonable under the
    circumstances to maintain its secrecy.

  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 39-8-20(5)(a) (Supp. 2007).
[4] Queiser, an employee of Bridgestone/Firestone, Inc.
  since 1994, holds a bachelorâ€™s degree in aeronautical and astronautical
  engineering as well as a masterâ€™s degree in engineering mechanics.Â  He stated
  that he has â€œpersonally developed steel belted radial tires from concept
  through . . . productionâ€ and that his experience included analysis of tire
  failure.Â  
[5] Ochs holds a bachelorâ€™s degree and a masterâ€™s degree in mechanical
  engineering.Â  Michelin employed Ochs from 1969-1994, during which time his work
  included analysis of failed passenger and light truck tires.
[6] Duddey holds a Ph.D. in physical organic chemistry and
  worked for Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company for thirty-two years.Â  
[7]Â 
  Smythe, an analytical chemist, has been exposed to at least one proprietary
  skim stock formula and has performed work on rubber compounds to determine why
  they failed.Â  Smythe is not a tire engineer and does not claim to have
  expertise in tire design or manufacturing.Â  
[8] The trial court found that a protective order could be fashioned to protect the
  trade secret status of the information, but â€œ[b]ecause the parties are in a
  better position to narrow the issues on the terms of a protective order,â€ the
  trial court instructed the parties to collaborate on the specific terms of the
  protective order.Â  There is no protective order in the record presumably
  because Bridgestone filed its petition for a writ of certiorari less than a
  month after the trial courtâ€™s order.
[9] In support of his position, Respondent asserts Griego
  v. Ford Motor Co., 19 F.Supp.2d 531, 533 (D.S.C. 1998), in which the
  federal district court held that the Trade Secrets Act
  does not apply to a product liability action because it â€œis not based on
  misappropriation of a trade secret or protection against such a
  misappropriation.â€Â  We decline to adopt the reasoning set forth in Griego and note that a federal court decision interpreting state law is not
  binding on this Court.Â  Blyth v. Marcus, 335 S.C. 363, 517 S.E.2d
  433 (1999).
[10] The language of Rule 26(c), SCRCP, mirrors that of
  federal Rule 26(c).Â  Because there is no South Carolina precedent construing
  this rule, federal interpretation
  of Rule 26(c) is persuasive authority.Â  See State v. Colf, 332 S.C. 313, 317, 504 S.E.2d 360, 361 (Ct. App. 1998). 
[11] Likewise, in jurisdictions where trade secrets are
  protected by a codified evidentiary privilege, the courts apply a similar
  balancing test.Â  See, e.g., In re Contâ€™l Gen. Tire, Inc.,
  979 S.W.2d 609 (Tex. 1998); Bridgestone/Firestone, Inc. v. Superior Court,
  9 Cal.Rptr.2d 709 (Cal. Ct. App. 1992).
[12] See U.S. Depâ€™t of Trans., NHTSA, Office of Defects Investigation, Engineering
  Analysis Report and Initial Decision Regarding EA00-023 Firestone Wilderness AT
  Tires (October 2001) (hereinafter â€œNHTSA Reportâ€).Â  
[13] Contrary to the dissentâ€™s assertion, we do not reverse the trial courtâ€™s order
  compelling discovery based on our view of the expertsâ€™ testimonies.Â  Rather, we
  reverse because Respondent failed as a matter of law to meet the applicable
  standard governing the discovery of trade secrets.Â  
[14] S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 39-8-60 (B).
[15] Rule 26 (c)(7), SCRCP.
[16] Compare Bridgestone Americas Holding, Inc. v. Mayberry, 878
  N.E.2d 189 (Ind. 2007); In re Bridgestone/Firestone, Inc., 106 S.W.3d
  730 (Tex. 2003) citing In re Continental Tire, Inc., 979 S.W. 2d
  609, (Tex. 1998), relied upon by the majority, both of which came before the
  reviewing courts under the more liberal â€œabuse of discretionâ€ standard of
  review.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Jim Aaron, Appellant,
        v.
        Susan J. Mahl,
          a/k/a Susan J. Scott and Elizabeth M. Smith, Clerk of Court for Beaufort County, South Carolina, Defendants,
        Of Whom Susan
          J. Mahl, a/k/a Susan J. Scott is theRespondent,
        and
        Susan J. Scott, Respondent,
        v.
        Rehon &
          Roberts, a Professional Corporation, Peter M. Rehon and Ronald D. Foster, Additional
          Plaintiffs on the Counterclaim.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
  Â Curtis L. Coltrane, Special Circuit Court
Judge

Opinion No. 26607
  Heard December 4, 2008 - Filed March 2,
2009Â Â  

REVERSED AND REMANDED 


  
    
      
        Brian
          C. Pitts, of Smoot, Pitts, Elliott & Biel, of Hilton Head Island, for
          Appellant
        Robert
          V. Mathison, Jr., of Mathison & Mathison, of Hilton Head Island, for
          Respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE
  WALLER:Â  This is a direct
  appeal from the trial courtâ€™s dismissal of appellant Jim Aaronâ€™s action to
  enforce California and Indiana judgments against respondent Susan Mahl (a/k/a
  Susan Scott).Â  We certified the appeal pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR, and now reverse.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
Respondent was a California attorney.[1]Â  Between 1996 and 1999, respondent
  was a civil litigator and managing partner with the law firm now known as Rehon & Roberts (â€œR&Râ€).[2]Â 
  Respondent left the firm in November 1999 to start her own firm.Â  In January
  2000, R&R brought a California lawsuit against respondent for fraud and deceit, breach of fiduciary duty,
  conversion, and other causes of action.
In
  February 2001, she closed her practice, moved out of California, and then
  traveled with appellant, who was her boyfriend at the time.Â  Eventually, she
  moved to Bluffton, South Carolina.Â  In July 2001, respondent bought a house in
  Bluffton for $234,918 in cash, although the Bluffton house originally was
  titled in appellantâ€™s name.Â  According to appellant, respondent titled the
  house in his name in order to secure it from judgment.[3]Â 
  Moreover, in August 2001, respondent petitioned the South Carolina family court
  to legally change her name from Susan J. Mahl to Susan J. Scott.[4]Â  
R&Râ€™s case against
  respondent went to trial on September 17, 2001.Â  By this time, the California trial court had struck respondentâ€™s answer and cross complaint due to discovery
  abuse.Â  Respondent did not appear at trial, and judgment was entered in
  R&Râ€™s favor.Â  The California court granted general damages in the amount of
  $749,572.37, plus $150,000 in punitive damages (â€œthe California judgmentâ€).Â  
After
  trial, respondent moved to have both the California judgment, and the sanction
  order which had struck her answer, set aside. Respondent represented that after
  she moved out of California, she received her mail through a mailing service
  located in South Dakota.Â  Respondent claimed that although she had been aware
  her trial originally had been set for September 10, 2001, she never received
  notice that the case was scheduled for September 17, 2001, and did not know her
  attorney had withdrawn on September 7, 2001.Â  She also alleged that her mental
  condition - major depression - impaired her ability to participate in the
  litigation.Â 

The California trial court denied her motion to set aside the judgment.[5] Respondent appealed, but the California Court of Appeal affirmed.Â  Rehon
  & Roberts v. Mahl, 2003 WL 22810438, 1 (Cal. Ct. App. Nov. 25, 2003).Â 
  The California Supreme Court denied review on February 18, 2004. Â 
In November or
  December of 2001, R&R assigned the California judgment for
    collection to appellant (â€œthe Assignmentâ€).[6]Â 
  There was also a collection agreement between R&R and appellant.Â 
  This document stated, inter alia, that R&R retained appellant as a
  collector, and thereby assigned the California judgment to him.[7]Â 
  Appellant was to receive 50% of the proceeds he collected.Â  
In
  December 2001, appellant filed suit against respondent in both Indiana and  South Carolina to enforce the California judgment.Â  The lawsuit filed in South Carolina is the subject of the instant appeal.
On October 24,
  2002, the Indiana circuit court granted appellant summary judgment in favor of
  appellant (â€œthe Indiana judgmentâ€).Â  The Indiana court specifically rejected
  respondentâ€™s argument that R&Râ€™s assignment to appellant was an invalid
  partial assignment.Â  Respondent did not appeal the Indiana judgment.Â  In
  January 2003, the Indiana court barred respondent from
  disposing, transferring or removing any of her assets, and specifically ordered
  respondent not to transfer any interest in her Bluffton house.Â  
Various pretrial
  orders were also issued by the South Carolina court in the instant case.Â  For
  example, on October 8, 2003, Judge Kemmerlin (the first Master in Equity
  assigned to this case) entered an order which directed the Beaufort Clerk of
  Court to enroll and index the California judgment, but delayed execution until
  the California appellate process had finalized.
Appellant moved for
  summary judgment in the instant action after the California judgment became
  final.Â  The trial court, however, denied the motion and ordered appellant to
  produce the collection agreement.Â  In July 2004, respondent amended her
  complaint to assert various counterclaims and defenses, including fraud on the
  court and the affirmative defense of unclean hands.Â  
On March 20, 2006,
  the case went to trial before Master-in-Equity Coltrane acting as a special
  circuit court judge.Â  Ultimately, the trial court issued a written order of
  judgment which found that appellant could not enforce the California judgment.Â 
  The trial court found various aspects of the collection agreement â€œtroubling,â€
  and specifically found that the Assignment from R&R to appellant was
  invalid.Â  Additionally, the trial court decided that appellantâ€™s hands were
  unclean because his actions were â€œrendered possible only through his personal
  relationship withâ€ respondent. Â Accordingly, the trial court dismissed
  appellantâ€™s complaint.[8]
Both parties moved
  to alter or amend the judgment order.Â  In its amended order, the trial court
  ruled on the issue of whether R&R should have been joined as a plaintiff at
  trial.Â  The trial court found that because appellant had previously objected to
  respondentâ€™s pretrial attempts to join R&R, he was estopped from seeking to
  join the firm as a party.Â  Moreover, the trial court found joinder of R&R
  would not be just under Rule 21, SCRCP.Â  
ISSUES

  
    1.   
    Did the trial court err in failing
  to find that respondent could not collaterally attack the California and Indiana judgments and by not giving full, faith and credit to both the California and Indiana judgments? 
  
  
  
    2. 
     Did the trial court err in ruling
  that appellant had unclean hands?  
  

STANDARD OF REVIEW
An
  action to enforce a judgment is an action at law. Â Minorplanet Sys. USA Ltd.
    v. American Aire, Inc., 368 S.C. 146, 149, 628 S.E.2d 43, 45 (2006).Â 
  In an action at law, tried by a judge without a jury, the findings of the trial
  court must be affirmed if there is any evidence to support them. Â Townes
    Assocs., Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 221 S.E.2d 773 (1976). 
DISCUSSION
1.Â  Full Faith and Credit / Collateral Estoppel
Appellant
  argues the trial court erred by not granting full faith and credit to the California judgment and the Indiana judgment, both of which are final judgments.Â  In
  addition, appellant contends the trial court should not have allowed respondent
  to collaterally attack those judgments at the South Carolina trial.Â  We agree.
The Full Faith and Credit Clause of the United States Constitution
  provides that â€œFull Faith and Credit
  shall be given in each state to the ... judicial proceedings of every other
  state.â€ U.S. Const. art. IV, Â§ 1.Â  Generally, full faith and credit â€œâ€˜requires every
  State to give to a judgment at least the res judicata effect which the
  judgment would be accorded in the
    State which rendered it.â€™â€Â  Hospitality Mgmt. Assocs. v.
      Shell Oil Co., 356 S.C. 644, 653, 591 S.E.2d 611, 616 (2004) (quoting Durfee v. Duke, 375 U.S. 106, 109 (1963)).Â  Therefore, â€œa foreign
  judgment which is regular on its face generally may not be collaterally
  attacked.â€Â  Bankers Trust Co. v. Braten, 317 S.C. 547, 550, 455 S.E.2d
  199, 200 (Ct. App. 1995).
In
  other words, â€œthe judgment of a state court should
  have the same credit, validity and effect, in every other court of the United States, which it had in the state where it was pronounced.â€Â  Id.; see also Hamilton v. Patterson, 115 S.E.2d 68, 70 (1960) (a
  defendant may not a second time challenge the validity of a plaintiffâ€™s right
  which has ripened into a judgment) (citation omitted).
We
  find the trial court erred by not enforcing the California judgment in South Carolina.Â  This judgment resulted from a trial at which respondent did not appear.Â 
  She subsequently attempted to set aside the judgment, but all her attempts at
  appeal were denied by the California courts.Â  Thus, the trial court should have
  followed the general principles of Full Faith and Credit in the instant case
  and given effect to R&Râ€™s valid foreign judgment.
Moreover,
  the basic principles of res judicata and collateral estoppel also apply. Â Res judicata bars subsequent actions by the same parties when the
  claims arise out of the same occurrence that was the subject of a prior action
  between those parties.Â  E.g., Riedman Corp. v. Greenville Steel
    Structures, Inc., 308 S.C. 467, 469, 419 S.E.2d 217, 218 (1992).Â  Collateral
  estoppel prevents a party from re-litigating an issue in a subsequent suit which
  was actually and necessarily litigated and determined in a prior action.Â  E.g., Jinks v. Richland County, 355 S.C. 341, 349, 585 S.E.2d 281, 285 (2003).
Here,
  respondent expressly raised the issue about the validity of the Assignment to
  the circuit court in Indiana.[9]Â 
  The circuit court in Indiana granted appellant summary judgment and specifically rejected respondentâ€™s attack on the Assignment.Â  Respondent did not appeal from
  that order.Â  Thus, the Indiana judgment, like the California judgment before
  it, became final and is entitled to Full Faith and Credit.Â  Clearly, respondent
  should have been collaterally estopped from making the same argument about the
  Assignment to the South Carolina courts.Â  Id.
Nevertheless,
  respondent maintains that because the collection agreement was not disclosed in
  either the California or the Indiana litigation, she is permitted not only to
  raise and litigate the issue again, but to have the entire lawsuit dismissed
  because of the existence of the collection agreement (which she alleges
  invalidates the Assignment).Â  Respondent, however, has already had her bites at
  the apple.Â  In both the California and Indiana actions, respondent
  unsuccessfully challenged the validity of the assignment; ultimately, she prevailed
  here in South Carolina on the very same issue.Â  This was error.Â  We find res
    judicata and collateral estoppel apply to preclude her from re-litigating
  issues which have already been actually litigated in a prior action.Â  
Respondent
  further contends that the failure to produce the collection agreement amounts
  to extrinsic fraud, and therefore, an exception should be made to the general
  rules governing Full, Faith, and Credit and collateral estoppel.Â  
It
  is true that these general rules may not apply â€œwhere extrinsic fraud has been
  practiced to procure the judgment.â€Â  Bankers Trust Co. v. Braten, 317
  S.C. at 550, 455 S.E.2d at 200.Â  However, allegations that a party failed to
  disclose documents generally amount to intrinsic, rather than extrinsic, fraud.
  Â Chewning v. Ford Motor Co., 354 S.C. 72, 579 S.E.2d 605 (2003).Â  Moreover,
  relief from a judgment is generally denied in a case of intrinsic fraud because
  when an issue has been litigated and determined in a former action, it â€œshould
  not be retried, â€¦ otherwise litigation would be interminable.â€Â  Id. at 82, 579 S.E.2d at 610 (citation omitted).
Respondent
  maintains that a fraud on the court was perpetrated in Indiana when appellant
  and his attorneys attached the Assignment to the complaint seeking to enforce
  the California judgment.Â  In respondentâ€™s view, this amounted to a fabrication
  because the collection agreement is the â€œtrueâ€ assignment document.Â  She
  therefore argues the Indiana attorneys engaged in a scheme to defraud, and
  appellant committed perjury in his affidavits which stated that the Assignment
  was â€œa true and correct copy of the assignment.â€Â  
Appellant, on the
  other hand, argues that the collection agreement does not negate the Assignment,
  and thus, there was nothing false about presenting the Assignment as evidence
  that R&R had assigned the California judgment to him for collection.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
We
  find the facts of the instant case do not establish an extrinsic fraud on the
  court.Â  See id. at 82, 579 S.E.2d at 610 (â€œThe subornation of perjury
  by an attorney and/or the intentional concealment of documents by an attorney
  are actions which constitute extrinsic fraud.â€).[10]Â  
2.Â  Unclean Hands
Appellant argues that the equitable defense of unclean hands should not have
  been allowed because he was not seeking equity, but instead was pursuing an
  action at law - the domestication and enforcement of a foreign judgment.Â  We
  agree.
The doctrine
  of unclean hands â€œprecludes a plaintiff from recovering in equity if he
  acted unfairly in a matter that is the subject of the litigation to the
  prejudice of the defendant.â€Â  Ingram v. Kaseyâ€™s Assocs., 340 S.C. 98,
  107 n.2, 531 S.E.2d 287, 292 n.2, (2000) (emphasis added).Â  The equitable
  doctrine of unclean hands, however, has no application
  to an action at law.Â  E.g., Holmes v. Henderson, 549 S.E.2d 81 (Ga. 2001); Ellwood v. Mid
    States Commodities, Inc., 404 N.W.2d 174, 184 (Iowa 1987).Â  Thus,
  the trial court erred in applying this particular equitable defense to the
  instant case because appellant was not seeking to recover in equity.

CONCLUSION
For the reasons outlined above, we reverse the trial
  courtâ€™s dismissal and remand for enforcement of the California judgment.[11]
REVERSED AND
  REMANDED.
PLEICONES, BEATTY
  and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur. TOAL, C.J., dissenting in a separate opinion.

CHIEF
  JUSTICE TOAL:Â  I respectfully
  dissent.Â  In my view, Appellantâ€™s repeated failure to present the Collection
  Agreement amounted to extrinsic fraud, and I would therefore hold that the
  trial court properly dismissed Appellantâ€™s action to enforce the California judgment.
Extrinsic
  fraud is fraud that induces a person not to present a case or deprives a person
  of the opportunity to be heard. Â Relief is granted for extrinsic fraud on the
  theory that because the fraud prevented a party from fully exhibiting and
  trying his case, there has never been a real contest before the court on the
  subject matter of the action.Â  Chewning
    v. Ford Motor Co., 354
  S.C. 72, 80, 579 S.E.2d 605, 610 (2003)
  (quoting Hilton Head Ctr. of
    South Carolina v. Public Serv. Commâ€™n,
  294 S.C. 9, 11, 362 S.E.2d 176, 177 (1987)). On the other hand, intrinsic fraud
  is fraud which was presented and considered in the trial.Â  Chewning, 354
  S.C. at 81, 579 S.E.2d at 610.Â  It is fraud which misleads a court in
  determining issues and induces the court to find for the party perpetrating the
  fraud.Â  Id.
In
  the instant case, Appellant retained Attorney Thomas Botkin to negotiate an
  assignment agreement between him and Rehon & Roberts for collection of the California judgment.[12]Â 
  Subsequently, Botkin filed suit in Indiana on behalf of Appellant to enforce
  the California judgment.Â  In the complaint, Botkin alleged that the California judgment had been assigned to Appellant, and he attached Appellantâ€™s supporting
  affidavit and a copy of the Assignment as proof of his right to enforce the
  judgment.Â  The Collection Agreement was never referenced in the complaint or at
  any time during the Indiana litigation.Â  Likewise, in the South Carolina
  complaint, Botkin[13] attached a copy of the Assignment in support of his motion to enforce the
  judgment and never disclosed the existence of the Collection Agreement.Â  It was
  not until 2004 following the Masterâ€™s order to compel that the Collection
  Agreement was disclosed.

In
  my view, the evidence shows that Appellantâ€™s attorney intentionally concealed
  the Collection Agreement.Â  As a result of these actions, Respondent was
  prevented from fully litigating her claim that the assignment was invalid[14] during the Indiana litigation.Â  See Chewing, 354 S.C. at 84, 579 S.E.2d
  at 611 (recognizing that where an
  attorney embarks on a scheme to intentionally conceal documents, extrinsic
  fraud constituting a fraud upon the court occurs).Â  For these reasons, I would hold that repeatedly
  failing to disclose the Collection Agreement constituted extrinsic fraud, and
  therefore, the trial court did not err in failing to give full faith and credit
  to the Indiana judgment.Â Â Â 


[1] Respondent was admitted to the California Bar in
  1980.Â  Effective February 1, 2001, her status changed to inactive.Â  On July 29,
  2005, respondent had disciplinary charges pending, and she tendered her
  resignation.Â  Respondentâ€™s resignation became effective as of September 14,
  2005. Â See http://members.calbar.ca.gov/search/member_detail.aspx?x=95447.
[2] The firm was previously named Mahl Rehon Walworth
  & Roberts.Â  
[3] Appellant subsequently deeded the house back to her
  on October 5, 2001. Nonetheless, respondent filed suit against appellant in Indiana on October 11, 2001.Â  According to respondent, appellant â€œhad
  misappropriated funds entrusted to him.â€Â  As of the time of trial in South Carolina, the Indiana litigation between respondent (as plaintiff) and appellant (as
  defendant) was still pending.Â  Moreover, in the instant case, respondent
  admitted that she encumbered the Bluffton house by mortgages despite the fact
  that the Indiana court had ordered against such encumbrances. 
[4] Respondent declared on the name change petition that
  she had â€œno intention to defraud anyone or to avoid creditors by virtue of the
  name change.â€Â  The family court granted her the name change on September 24,
  2001.Â  In the instant case, appellant testified that respondent told him she
  was going to change her name in order to â€œdisappearâ€ and avoid her creditors.Â  
[5] The California judge specifically found that
  respondent â€œdeliberately refrained from obtaining information about the status
  of her case.â€Â  The judge also rejected respondentâ€™s allegations that her mental
  condition impaired her functioning, and noted respondent had been â€œactive in
  litigation in other states, including a change of her surname, buying and
  selling real estate in two different states, and significant travel.â€Â  The
  judge also specifically noted that respondent had â€œthe wherewithal to transfer
  the title to her late model Jaguar automobile within a few days after she
  purportedly learned of the judgment against her.â€Â  
[6] The assignment itself is undated, but testimony from
  appellantâ€™s attorney at the South Carolina trial establishes the approximate
  date of the assignment.Â  
[7] The collection agreement was not disclosed in either
  the California litigation or the Indiana litigation. Â In May 2004, its
  production was ordered by the South Carolina court.Â  This will be further
  discussed infra.
[8] Respondentâ€™s counterclaims were also dismissed
  because she did not oppose appellantâ€™s directed verdict motion.Â  
[9] Furthermore, in the California post-judgment
  litigation, respondent also claimed the Assignment was invalid.Â  
[10] At most, respondentâ€™s allegations amount to
  nondisclosure of a documentÂ  which generally is considered intrinsic fraud;
  thus, the issue should not have been re-litigated.Â  
[11] We decline to address appellantâ€™s remaining issues.Â  See Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518
  S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (an appellate court need not address additional issues if the resolution of another issue is dispositive).
[12] Botkinâ€™s signature appears on the Collection Agreement.Â  
[13] Botkin was admitted pro hac vice to represent Appellant in the South Carolina litigation.Â  
[14] The Collection Agreement purports to disclaim any fiduciary duty between the
  parties and appears to be a partial assignment, both of which are prohibited
  under California law.Â  Thus, the alleged assignment upon which Appellant relied
  for his authority to enforce the judgment was invalid.
