THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Jeffrey Eugene
      Davie, Petitioner,
				v.
				State of South Carolina, Respondent.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal From York County
Â John C. Hayes, III, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26608
Submitted November 19, 2008 - Filed March
  9, 2009Â Â  
REVERSED AND REMANDED


	
		
			
				Deputy
  Chief Appellate Defender Wanda H. Carter, of South Carolina Commission on
  Indigent Defense, Division of Appellate Defense, ofÂ  Columbia, for Petitioner.
				Attorney
  General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
  Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General Julie M.
  Thames, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE
  BEATTY:Â  In this post-conviction
  relief (PCR) case, the Court granted a writ of certiorari to review the PCR
  judgeâ€™s denial of relief to Jeffrey Eugene Davie (Petitioner) for his plea of
  guilty which resulted in a sentence of twenty-seven years in prison. Â Petitioner
  primarily contends the PCR judge erred in ruling that plea counsel was not ineffective
  for failing to communicate a fifteen-year plea offer made by the State.Â  We
  reverse the PCR judgeâ€™s order, vacate Petitionerâ€™s sentence, and remand for re-sentencing.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
Pursuant
  to a plea agreement, Petitioner pled guilty in November 2000 to trafficking
  crack cocaine, third offense; distribution of crack cocaine, third offense;
  distribution of crack cocaine within proximity of a public park; conspiracy to
  violate the South Carolina drug laws; unlawful conduct toward a child; failure
  to stop for a blue light; driving under suspension, third offense; and child
  endangerment.Â  In exchange for Petitionerâ€™s â€œstraight upâ€ plea, the State
  agreed to dismiss additional charges.Â  At the plea hearing, the State
  stipulated that the dismissal of the other charges would preclude the State
  from seeking a sentence of life without the possibility of parole for
  Petitioner.[1] Â The judge sentenced Petitioner to an aggregate of twenty-seven yearsâ€™
  imprisonment.Â  Petitioner did not directly appeal his plea or sentence.Â  
On April 12, 2001,
  Petitioner filed a PCR application.Â  In his application, Petitioner moved for
  the PCR court to vacate his guilty plea and sentence on the ground the State
  reneged on a twenty-five-year sentencing cap. Â In an amended application,
  Petitioner raised several subject matter jurisdiction challenges to the charges
  for which he pled guilty.Â  Additionally, Petitioner alleged he was denied
  effective assistance of counsel on the ground his plea counsel failed to
  properly advise him of the sentencing enhancements for his prior drug
  offenses.Â  In an amended application dated July 31, 2002, Petitionerâ€™s PCR
  counsel reiterated Petitionerâ€™s prior claims but also alleged that plea counsel
  had failed to inform Petitioner of a written plea agreement in which the State
  offered a fifteen-year sentence in exchange for Petitionerâ€™s plea to all of the
  pending charges. 
At the PCR hearing,
  Petitioner testified that two years after he pled guilty he discovered the
  State initially extended a plea offer of fifteen years.Â  Because plea counsel
  never communicated this offer to him, Petitioner claimed ineffective assistance
  of counsel.Â  Petitioner stated he would have accepted the fifteen-year deal had
  he been aware of it prior to the plea proceeding.Â  
Plea counsel
  testified he was not aware of the Stateâ€™s offered plea agreement for a
  fifteen-year sentence until after the offer had expired.  Counsel explained
  he was in the process of relocating his office at the time the State mailed its
  written plea offer.Â  As part of the office relocation, counsel stated he
  acquired a new post office box.Â  Had he been aware of the offer, counsel
  claimed he would have communicated it to Petitioner.Â  Counsel believed
  Petitioner would have accepted the plea offer had it been communicated to him. Counsel
  further testified that the only subsequent offer was the one Petitioner
  accepted at his plea hearing, wherein Petitioner pled â€œstraight upâ€ to the
  eight charges in return for the State dropping the remaining three charges and
  seeking a sentence of life without parole. 
At the conclusion
  of the PCR hearing, Petitionerâ€™s counsel argued that plea counselâ€™s failure to
  communicate the plea offer to Petitioner constituted ineffective assistance of
  counsel.Â  In terms of relief, counsel requested the PCR court remand the case
  for a re-sentencing hearing with the directive that the new sentence could not
  exceed the twenty-seven-year sentence that was previously imposed.Â  
The judge denied
  Petitionerâ€™s request for relief, finding â€œno proof of ineffective assistance of
  counsel regarding the unfortunate circumstances, which caused a plea offer to
  lapse prior to [Petitionerâ€™s] consideration of the same.â€ Â The judge stated it
  was â€œunfortunateâ€ that Petitioner did not have the opportunity to consider the
  fifteen-year plea offer.Â  However, the judge noted the offer was not available
  to Petitioner at the time of his guilty plea.Â  Additionally, the judge found
  Petitioner knowingly and voluntarily pled guilty given he was fully advised of
  the rights he was waiving by pleading guilty and he understood the underlying
  charges of his guilty plea.Â  The judge also concluded Petitioner ultimately
  benefited from the Stateâ€™s agreement by avoiding a sentence of life without
  parole.[2]Â  
The Court granted
  the Petitionerâ€™s request for a writ of certiorari to review the PCR judgeâ€™s
  decision.
DISCUSSION
Petitioner
  contends his plea counsel was ineffective in failing to communicate the Stateâ€™s
  initial fifteen-year plea offer to him.Â  Because he would have accepted the
  offer, Petitioner asserts he was prejudiced by counselâ€™s deficient performance.Â 
  We agree.
Standard of Review
A
  defendant has the right to the effective assistance of counsel under the Sixth
  Amendment to the United States Constitution.Â  Strickland v. Washington, 466 U.S. 668 (1984).Â  This Court has held that a defendant has the right to
  effective assistance of counsel during the plea bargaining process.Â  Judge
    v. State, 321 S.C. 554, 471 S.E.2d 146 (1996), overruled on other
      grounds by Jackson v. State, 342 S.C. 95, 535 S.E.2d 926
  (2000).Â  â€œThere is a strong presumption that counsel rendered adequate
  assistance and exercised reasonable professional judgment in making all
  significant decisions in the case.â€Â  Ard v. Catoe, 372 S.C. 318, 331,
  642 S.E.2d 590, 596, cert. denied, 128 S. Ct. 370 (2007).Â Â  
In a
  PCR proceeding, the applicant bears the burden of establishing that he or she is
  entitled to relief.Â  Caprood v. State, 338 S.C. 103, 109, 525 S.E.2d
  514, 517 (2000).Â  â€œIn the context of a guilty plea, the court must determine
  whether 1) counselâ€™s advice was within the range of competence demanded of
  attorneys in criminal cases- i.e. was counselâ€™s performance deficient, and 2)
  if there is a reasonable probability that, but for counselâ€™s errors, the
  defendant would not have pled guilty.â€ Smith v. State, 369 S.C. 135,
  138, 631 S.E.2d 260, 261 (2006) (citing Hill v. Lockhart, 474 U.S. 52, 56-58 (1985)). Â â€œThe
  defendantâ€™s undisputed testimony that he would not have pled guilty to the
  charges but for trial counselâ€™s advice is sufficient to prove that defendant
  would not have pled guilty.â€Â  Id. at 138, 631 S.E.2d at 261.Â  â€œIn
  determining guilty plea issues, it is proper to consider
  the guilty plea transcript as well as evidence at the PCR
  hearing.â€ Suber v. State, 371 S.C. 554, 558, 640 S.E.2d 884, 886 (2007).
â€œThis
  Court gives great deference to the post-conviction relief (PCR) courtâ€™s findings
  of fact and conclusions of law.â€Â  Dempsey v. State, 363 S.C. 365, 368,
  610 S.E.2d 812, 814 (2005).Â  In
  reviewing the PCR courtâ€™s decision, an appellate court is concerned only with
  whether any evidence of probative value exists to support that decision.  Smith,
  369 S.C. at 138, 631 S.E.2d at 261.Â  This Court will uphold the findings of the
  PCR court when there is any evidence of probative value to support them, and
  will reverse the decision of the PCR court when it is controlled by an
  error of law.  Suber, 371 S.C. at 558-59, 640 S.E.2d at 886.
To
  prevail on his claim of ineffective assistance of counsel, Petitioner was
  required to prove that 1) plea counselâ€™s failure to communicate the Stateâ€™s
  initial, fifteen-year plea offer constituted deficient performance, and 2) he
  was prejudiced by this deficient performance, i.e., there is a
  reasonable probability that but for counselâ€™s deficient performance, he would
  have accepted the original plea offer. 
Deficient Performance
Although
  our appellate courts have not directly addressed the question of whether
  counselâ€™s failure to communicate a plea offer to his or her client constitutes
  deficient performance, other cases of deficient performance in the context of
  plea bargaining would appear to support Petitionerâ€™s position.Â  See, e.g., Sprouse v. State, 355 S.C. 335, 340, 585 S.E.2d 278, 281 (2003) (finding
  defendant was entitled to post-conviction relief where the State failed to
  honor the plea agreement it made with defendant and trial counsel failed
  to ensure that the State adhered to the original plea agreement); Thompson
    v. State, 340 S.C. 112, 116-17, 531 S.E.2d 294, 296-97 (2000) (concluding
  defendant established a claim for ineffective assistance of counsel where trial
  counsel failed to object when the solicitor recommended the maximum sentence in
  violation of the plea agreement); Jordan v. State, 297 S.C. 52, 53-54,
  374 S.E.2d 683, 684-85 (1988) (holding trial counsel rendered ineffective
  assistance of counsel in failing to withdraw guilty plea after State reneged on
  plea, and reasoning that counselâ€™s conduct in not protecting defendantâ€™s right
  to enforce the plea agreement with the solicitorâ€™s office fell below â€œprevailing
  professional normsâ€).
Because
  our appellate courts have not specifically ruled on this issue, we are guided
  by the decisions of other state and federal jurisdictions.Â  As we view these
  cases, we believe an adoption of a rule that counselâ€™s failure to convey a plea
  offer constitutes deficient performance would be consistent with the majority of
  other state and federal jurisdictions.Â  The theory underlying these decisions
  is that such conduct constitutes unreasonable performance under the prevailing
  professional standards established by the American Bar Association or
  state-specific ethical rules of conduct.Â  Pursuant to these professional
  standards, counsel is required to fully communicate with the client so that the
  client can make an informed decision regarding any proposals by the State.Â  See United States v. Rodriguez, 929 F.2d 747, 752-53 (1st Cir.
  1991); Pham v. United States, 317 F.3d 178, 182 (2d Cir. 2003); United States ex rel. Caruso v. Zelinsky, 689 F.2d 435, 438 (3d Cir. 1982); Barentine
    v. United States, 728 F.Supp. 1241, 1251 (W.D.N.C.), affâ€™d, 908 F.2d
  968 (4th Cir. 1990); Griffin v. United States, 330 F.3d 733, 737 (6th
  Cir. 2003); Johnson v. Duckworth, 793 F.2d 898, 902 (7th Cir. 1986); United
    States v. Blaylock, 20 F.3d 1458, 1465 (9th Cir. 1994); Diaz v. United
      States, 930 F.2d 832, 834 (11th Cir. 1991); see also Rasmussen v.
        State, 658 S.W.2d 867, 867-68 (Ark. 1983); Cottle v. State, 733 So.
  2d 963, 964-65 (Fla. 1999); Lloyd v. State, 373 S.E.2d 1, 3 (Ga. 1988); People
    v. Whitfield, 239 N.E.2d 850, 852 (Ill. 1968); Lyles v. State, 382
  N.E.2d 991, 993-94 (Ind. Ct. App. 1978); Williams v. State, 605 A.2d
  103, 108 (Md. 1992); People v. Alexander, 518 N.Y.S.2d 872, 879 (N.Y. App.
  Div. 1987); State v. Simmons, 309 S.E.2d 493, 497 (N.C. Ct. App. 1983); Jiminez
    v. State, 144 P.3d 903, 906 (Okla. Crim. App. 2006); Commonwealth v.
      Copeland, 554 A.2d 54, 60-61 (Pa. Super. Ct. 1988); Harris v. State,
  875 S.W.2d 662, 665 (Tenn. 1994); Hanzelka v. State, 682 S.W.2d 385, 387
  (Tex. Ct. App. 1984); State v. James, 739 P.2d 1161, 1166-67 (Wash. Ct.
  App. 1987); Becton v. Hun, 516 S.E.2d 762, 766-67 (W. Va. 1999); State
    v. Ludwig, 369 N.W.2d 722, 726-27 (Wis. 1985); see generally Gregory
  G. Sarno, Annotation, Adequacy of Defense Counselâ€™s Representation of
    Criminal Client Regarding Plea Bargaining, 8 A.L.R. 4th 660 (1981 &
  Supp. 2008) (discussing state and federal decisions determining the adequacy,
  competency, or effectiveness of defense counselâ€™s representation of a criminal
  accused in connection with plea bargaining and negotiating).
Turning
  to the facts of the instant case, we find that plea counselâ€™s failure to convey
  the Stateâ€™s initial plea offer to Petitioner constituted deficient
  performance.Â  Although counselâ€™s failure to do so could be construed as
  excusable neglect if one believes that the Stateâ€™s written offer was truly lost
  in the process of counselâ€™s office relocation, we do not believe that such
  neglect would negate the deficient performance.Â  Even if counsel is given the
  benefit of the doubt that he was not aware of the plea offer until after the
  expiration date, we find counsel was deficient in not objecting at the plea
  hearing.Â  During the plea hearing, the solicitor informed the circuit court
  judge that â€œ[t]he original plea offer in this matter has not been accepted by
  the due date of September 11th of this year, and so we told the defendant we
  were ready to go to trial.â€Â  In view of the solicitorâ€™s statement, it was
  incumbent upon plea counsel to object or in some way indicate to the court that
  he had no knowledge of the original plea offer.Â  Had counsel done so, he might
  have been able to convince the solicitor to reinstate this plea offer or
  persuade the circuit court judge to impose a fifteen-year sentence.Â  Because
  counsel failed to make any attempt to protect Petitionerâ€™s interests regarding
  this significantly lower sentence, we conclude counselâ€™s performance fell below
  the prevailing professional norms and, thus, constituted deficient performance.
Prejudice
Given
  our finding that plea counselâ€™s failure to communicate the Stateâ€™s initial plea
  offer constituted deficient performance, the question becomes whether
  Petitioner was prejudiced by this deficient performance.Â  We believe this is
  the most difficult question of the analysis because a definitive method of
  evaluating the prejudice prong does not appear to exist in our state or other
  jurisdictions.Â  Although most state courts follow the traditional, two-part Strickland test, differences appear to arise in what type of evidence must be presented to
  establish prejudice.
Some
  state courts have not required the defendant to present additional evidence.Â 
  Instead, the courts have essentially presumed prejudice merely based on the
  fact that plea counsel failed to communicate a plea offer.Â  These courts have
  reasoned that counselâ€™s failure to communicate a plea offer, whatever the
  terms, was inherently prejudicial because the deficient conduct prevented the
  defendant from making an informed decision. Â See, e.g.,Â  State v.
    Simmons, 309 S.E.2d 493, 498 (N.C. Ct. App. 1983) (concluding defendant was
  â€œclearly prejudiced by his attorneyâ€™s failure to inform him of the [plea
  bargain] offerâ€); Harris v. State, 875 S.W.2d 662, 665 (Tenn. 1994)
  (â€œThere is no doubt that the prejudice suffered by defendant was the direct
  result of failure on the part of defense counsel to discuss the plea bargain
  offer with his client and his failure to respond timely to the Stateâ€™s offer.â€); State v. James, 739 P.2d 1161, 1167 (Wash. Ct. App. 1987) (â€œIf we were
  presented with a finding, supported by substantial evidence, that in fact
  [counsel] failed to convey the plea negotiation to his clients, we would have
  no hesitation in concluding they were denied effective assistance of counsel on
  this error alone.â€).
Other
  state courts have found prejudice based on the defendantâ€™s self-serving
  statements that he would have accepted the plea offer had he been made aware of
  it.Â  See, e.g., People v. Culpepper, 567 N.Y.S.2d 327, 328 (N.Y. App.
  Div. 1990) (finding no prejudice where defendant did not say that â€œhe would
  have accepted the alleged plea offer if it had been transmittedâ€).
In
  contrast, other courts have utilized a burden of proof that is seemingly higher
  and requires objective evidence to show prejudice.Â  In these cases, the
  defendant must show not only that he would have accepted the offer, but also
  that he would have received a lesser sentence than that which he received or
  acted differently had he been aware of the plea offer. Â See, e.g., Cottle
    v. State, 733 So. 2d 963, 967 (Fla. 1999) (â€œ[C]ourts in this state have
  recognized claims arising out of counselâ€™s failure to inform a defendant of a
  plea offer, and have required a claimant to show that:Â  (1) counsel failed to
  communicate a plea offer . . ., (2) defendant would have accepted the plea
  offer but for the inadequate notice, and (3) acceptance of the Stateâ€™s plea
  offer would have resulted in a lesser sentence.â€); Williams v. State,
  605 A.2d 103, 110 (Md. 1992) (holding evidence of prejudice was â€œampleâ€ where
  the inference was supported by â€œobjective evidenceâ€ that the outcome would have
  been different had petitioner accepted the Stateâ€™s plea offer); Commonwealth
    v. Copeland, 554 A.2d 54, 61 (Pa. Super. Ct. 1988) (vacating defendantâ€™s
  sentence and remanding for an evidentiary hearing during which defendant would
  have the burden of proving that:Â  (1) an offer for a plea was made; (2) trial
  counsel failed to inform him of such offer; (3) trial counsel had no reasonable
  basis for failing to inform him of the plea offer; and (4) he was prejudiced
  thereby); cf. State v. Lopez, 743 N.W.2d 351, 358 (Neb. 2008)
  (defendant failed to establish that she was prejudiced by counselâ€™s failure to
  communicate offer of plea agreement where defendantâ€™s claims were contradicted
  by evidence introduced by the State and defense counsel). Â Â 
Finally,
  some jurisdictions have declined to adopt a definitive rule and, instead,
  advocated a case-by-case analysis looking strictly at the facts of each case. See,
    e.g., Lloyd v. State, 373 S.E.2d 1, 3 (Ga. 1988) (finding defendant
  was not prejudiced by counselâ€™s deficient performance, and stating â€œ[w]e prefer
  to examine the facts of each case and grant relief where there is at least an
  inference from the evidence that the defendant would have accepted the offer as
  made or something similarâ€); Hanzelka v. State, 682 S.W.2d 385, 387 (Tex. Ct. App. 1984) (â€œThis Court has concluded further that counselâ€™s deficient performance
  prejudiced Hanzelka in that under the terms of the plea bargain he would not
  have served any time in jail.â€). Â 
We
  find a case-by-case approach is most consistent with our prior decisions and
  effectively achieves the ultimate goal of assessing whether but for counselâ€™s
  deficient performance a defendant would have accepted the Stateâ€™s proposed plea
  bargain and that he would have benefited from the offer.Â  Because presumed
  prejudice is reserved to very limited situations, we hold that a defendant must
  show actual prejudice.Â  See Nance v. Ozmint, 367 S.C. 547, 552,
  626 S.E.2d 878, 880 (2006) (â€œAbsent [three narrow circumstances of presumed
  prejudice identified in United States v. Cronic, 466 U.S. 648 (1984)],
  defendants must show actual prejudice under Strickland.â€).Â Â  
However,
  it is not always necessary for a defendant to offer objective evidence to
  support a claim of actual prejudice.Â  Instead, depending on the facts of the
  case, a defendantâ€™s self-serving statement may be sufficient to establish
  actual prejudice.Â  See Jackson v. State, 342 S.C. 95, 97, 535
  S.E.2d 926, 927 (2000) (rejecting objective evidence requirement established in Judge and finding Petitioner proved he was prejudiced by counselâ€™s
  deficient performance in failing to properly advise the Petitioner that he was
  pleading to a felony rather than a misdemeanor where Petitionerâ€™s
  uncontradicted testimony established that he would not have pled had he known
  the charge was a felony), overruling Judge v. State, 321 S.C.
  554, 562, 471 S.E.2d 146, 150 (1996) (â€œThe second prong of the ineffective assistance inquiry--prejudice--is
  shown by demonstrating through objective evidence . . . [the existence
  of] a reasonable probability that, but for counselâ€™s advice, [the defendant]
  would have accepted the plea. Â Mere statements by the PCR petitioner that he
  would have accepted the plea agreement but for counselâ€™s incompetence are
  insufficient to show prejudice because they are self-serving and inherently
  unreliable.â€) (citation omitted); see also Smith v. State,
  369 S.C. 135, 138, 631 S.E.2d 260, 261 (2006) (â€œThe defendantâ€™s undisputed
  testimony that he would not have pled guilty to the charges but for trial
  counselâ€™s advice is sufficient to prove that defendant would not have pled
  guilty.â€). 
Applying these
  principles to the facts of the instant case, we conclude that Petitioner has
  proven he was prejudiced by plea counselâ€™s deficient performance.Â  Initially,
  we conclude that the difference in the sentence Petitioner received and the
  plea offer is proof of prejudice.Â  We reach this conclusion for several
  reasons.Â  First, the solicitor and plea counsel both acknowledged that the State
  originally offered a fifteen-year sentence in exchange for Petitionerâ€™s guilty
  plea.Â  Secondly, plea counsel admitted that he failed to communicate this offer
  to Petitioner.Â  Thirdly, both plea counsel and Petitioner testified that had
  this offer been communicated Petitioner would have accepted the plea
  agreement.Â  Finally, had Petitioner accepted the original offer, he would have
  received a significantly lower sentence than the twenty-seven-year sentence
  that was imposed.
Remedy
In
  light of our holding that Petitioner has established ineffective assistance of
  counsel, the final issue to be resolved is the relief to which Petitioner is
  entitled.Â  Notably, Petitioner has not set forth a specific request for relief
  in his brief.Â  However, a review of his PCR applications and the PCR hearing indicates
  that Petitioner appears to seek relief in the form of a new sentencing
  hearing.Â  As will be discussed, we agree that a re-sentencing hearing is the
  appropriate form of relief.
In
  formulating the appropriate relief, we are guided by general constitutional principles.
  Â Confronted with the issue presented in the instant case, the Kentucky Court of
  Appeals explained:

	Remedies for ineffective assistance of
  counsel â€œâ€˜should be tailored to the injury suffered from the constitutional
  violation and should not unnecessarily infringe on competing interests.â€™â€ Turner
    v. Tennessee, 858 F.2d 1201, 1207 (6th Cir. 1988), cert. denied, 502
  U.S. 1050, 112 S. Ct. 915, 116 L.Ed.2d 815 (1992) (quoting United States v.
    Morrison, 449 U.S. 361, 354, 101 S. Ct. 665, 66 L.Ed.2d 564 (1981)) . . . â€œIndeed,
  the only way to neutralize the constitutional deprivation suffered by [a
  defendant] would seem to be to provide [the defendant] with an opportunity to
  consider the [Commonwealthâ€™s initial] plea offer with the effective assistance
  of counsel.â€ Turner, 858 F.2d at 1208. 
	The United States
  Supreme Court has expressed that specific performance of a plea agreement is an
  allowable remedy where one has been denied constitutionally-guaranteed
  effective assistance of counsel. Id. (Citations
  omitted). On the other hand, specific performance is not warranted where it
  might unnecessarily infringe on the stateâ€™s competing interests. Id. at 1208-09. In some circumstances, the state may withdraw its original plea
  proposal, yet, in order to effectively do so the state must
  show the â€œwithdrawal is free of a reasonable apprehension of vindictiveness.â€ 
	Id. at 1208. (Citation omitted).
	It has been
  clearly established that when a criminal defendant successfully achieves
  relief, either through a direct or collateral attack to the conviction, he â€œmay
  not be subjected to greater punishment for exercising that right.â€ Id. at 1208 (Citing 
	Blackledge v. Perry, 417 U.S. 21, 94 S. Ct. 2098, 40
  L.Ed.2d 628 (1974)). The rebuttable presumption of vindictiveness is valid
  where there is a â€œrealistic likelihoodâ€ of prosecutorial retaliation. In
  ascertaining the existence of a realistic likelihood, the â€œcourts should focus
  on â€˜the nature of the right assertedâ€™ and â€˜the timing of the prosecutorâ€™s
  action.â€™â€ Turner, 858 F.2d at 1208 (quoting United States v. Goodwin,
  457 U.S. 368, 381-82, 102 S. Ct. 2485, 73 L.Ed.2d 74 (1982)).

Osborne v.
  Commonwealth, 992 S.W.2d
  860, 865 (Ky. Ct. App. 1998).
Because there is
  no evidence in the record that Petitioner expressed a desire to proceed to
  trial rather than plead guilty, we find a remand for a new trial is not the
  appropriate remedy.Â  See United States v. Blaylock, 20 F.3d 1458,
  1468 (9th Cir. 1994) (â€œSeveral
  courts have recognized that where the ineffective assistance occurred before trial, as in cases where the harm consisted in defense counselâ€™s failure to
  communicate a plea offer to defendant, . . . [granting a] subsequent fair trial
  does not remedy this deprivation.â€) (citation omitted).Â  
Furthermore, given
  Petitioner was never apprised of the plea offer, we do not believe that
  specific performance would be the appropriate remedy in that Petitioner did not
  detrimentally rely on the offer.Â Â  Cf. Custodio v. State, 373
  S.C. 4, 13, 644 S.E.2d 36, 40 (2007) (finding counsel rendered ineffective
  assistance in failing to have plea agreement enforced and concluding the
  appropriate remedy was specific performance of the plea agreement because
  defendant detrimentally relied on the promised plea agreement); Sprouse v.
    State, 355 S.C. 335, 340, 585 S.E.2d 278, 281 (2003) (holding counsel was
  ineffective in failing to ensure that the State adhered to the original plea
  agreement and remanding for specific performance of the plea agreement given it
  would grant â€œthe parties nothing more and nothing less than the benefit for
  which they originally bargainedâ€).Â  Accordingly, we hold that the appropriate
  remedy is a new sentencing hearing.
Given
  that we cannot compel the State to reinstate or the circuit court judge to
  accept the original, fifteen-year plea offer, we remand the case for a new
  sentencing hearing with the limitation that Petitionerâ€™s sentence should not
  exceed the original sentence of twenty-seven yearsâ€™ imprisonment.Â  See Commonwealth v. Copeland, 554 A.2d 54, 61 (Pa. Super. Ct. 1988) (â€œWe
  cannot compel the Commonwealth to reinstate its plea bargain offer; nor can we
  dictate what sentence may be imposed if appellant pleads guilty without so
  advantageous an offer as he had before, or if he goes to trial and is again
  convicted.â€).
The
  State and the circuit court judge should take into consideration the prior fifteen-year
  plea offer. Â See Harris v. State, 974 So. 2d 1149, 1151 (Fla.
  Dist. Ct. App. 2008) (concluding that, if on remand, counsel is found to have
  been ineffective in failing to properly advise defendant prior to revocation
  then there should be a â€œgood faith resumption of plea negotiationsâ€); Lyles
    v. State, 382 N.E.2d 991, 994 (Ind. Ct. App. 1978) (holding counsel was
  ineffective in failing to convey Stateâ€™s plea bargain offer and remanding â€œwith
  instructions to conduct a guilty plea hearing, assuming, as equity indicates
  under the limited facts of this case, the Stateâ€™s offer continuesâ€); Becton
    v. Hun, 516 S.E.2d 762, 768 (W.Va. 1999) (finding counsel was ineffective
  in failing to convey Stateâ€™s plea offer and remanding for a new sentencing
  hearing, but recognizing that the trial court would not be bound by the Stateâ€™s
  original sentencing recommendation).
CONCLUSION
Based
  on the foregoing, we find that counsel was deficient in failing to communicate
  the Stateâ€™s fifteen-year plea offer to Petitioner.Â  Given that both Petitioner
  and plea counsel testified Petitioner would have accepted the fifteen-year
  offer, an offer that was twelve years less than what Petitioner received, we
  conclude Petitioner has proven that he was prejudiced by counselâ€™s deficient
  performance.Â  Accordingly, we vacate Petitionerâ€™s sentence and remand for a
  re-sentencing hearing.Â  In re-sentencing Petitioner, the circuit court judge shall
  take into consideration the Stateâ€™s prior fifteen-year plea offer.Â  We further
  direct that any sentence Petitioner receives should not exceed the original
  twenty-seven-year sentence.
REVERSED AND
  REMANDED.
WALLER and
  KITTREDGE, JJ., concur. TOAL, C.J., concurring in result. PLEICONES, J. not
  participating.


[1]Â  The Solicitor made a brief reference to another plea
  offer, stating â€œthe original plea offer in this matter has not been accepted by
  the due date of September 11th of this year, and so we told the defendant we
  were ready to go to trial.â€ 
[2]Â Â  The PCR judge granted Petitioner relief with
  respect to his five-year sentence for child endangerment, finding it exceeded
  the one and one-half year statutorily mandated maximum.Â  Although Petitioner
  asserts in his brief that the PCR judge properly granted him relief on this
  issue, the State has not challenged the PCR judgeâ€™s finding.Â  Accordingly, we
  have confined our analysis to Petitionerâ€™s first issue.Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Joseph Holman, Petitioner,
				v.
				State of South Carolina, Respondent.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal From Bamberg County
Doyet A. Early, III, PCR Judge
Opinion No.Â  26609
Submitted January 22, 2009 - Filed March
  9, 2009Â  
REVERSED AND REMANDED


	
		
			
				Deputy
  Chief Appellate Defender Wanda H. Carter, of South Carolina Commission on
  Indigent Defense, Division of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
				Attorney
  General Henry Dargan McMaster; Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh; Assistant
  Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott; Assistant Attorney General Lance S.
  Boozer, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE
  KITTREDGE:Â Â Â Â Â  We granted Holmanâ€™s petition to review an order denying
  post-conviction relief (PCR) and now reverse, finding trial counsel deficient
  for failing to object to the introduction of wholly irrelevant and prejudicial
  evidence.Â  Accordingly, we grant PCR relief in the form of a new trial.
Petitioner
  was charged with multiple offenses arising from a shooting incident at Voorhees College in Bamberg County, South Carolina, on the evening of January 21, 2000, which
  spilled over into the early morning hours of the following day. Â Petitioner was
  alleged to be the shooter. Â Because Petitioner was seventeen at the time, he
  was further charged with possession of a pistol under the age of twenty-one.Â  A
  week following the January 21st shooting incident, a search of Petitionerâ€™s
  residence yielded a pistol.Â  The handgun seized from Petitionerâ€™s residence was
  in no manner connected to the shooting incident at Voorhees College.Â  Moreover, Petitioner was not charged with underage possession of the pistol seized
  from his residence.Â  We are troubled by the Stateâ€™s effort to admit the
  unrelated firearm in evidence.Â  More troubling is Petitionerâ€™s trial counselâ€™s
  failure to object to the admission of the unrelated pistol.
We
  hold that the failure to object to this clearly inadmissible evidence was
  ineffective assistance of counsel.Â  We reject the suggestion that the failure
  to object to the unrelated pistol can be justified as a valid trial strategy.Â  Whitehead
    v. State, 308 S.C. 119, 122, 417 S.E.2d 529, 531 (1992) (â€œCourts must be wary
  of second-guessing counselâ€™s trial tactics; and where counsel articulates a
  valid reason for employing certain strategy, such conduct will not be deemed
  ineffective assistance of counsel.â€).Â  Substantial, and easily avoidable,
  prejudice resulted from Petitionerâ€™s failure to challenge the admission of the
  firearm unconnected to the charged offenses.Â  State v. McConnell, 290
  S.C. 278, 280, 350 S.E.2d 179, 180 (1986) (holding the admission of bullets and
  a pistol unconnected to the crime was erroneous and prejudicial).
The
  admission of this irrelevant and prejudicial evidence undermines confidence in
  the outcome of the trial. Â Ard v. Catoe, 372 S.C. 318, 331, 642 S.E.2d
  590, 596 (2007) (â€œ[The prejudice prong is satisfied when] there is a reasonable
  probability that, but for counselâ€™s errors, the result of the trial would have
  been different.Â  A reasonable probability is a probability sufficient to
  undermine confidence in the outcome of the trial.â€) (internal citations
  omitted); Von Dohlen v. State, 360 S.C. 598, 603, 602 S.E.2d 738, 740-41
  (2004) (â€œIn order to prove counsel was ineffective, the applicant must show
  that counselâ€™s performance was deficient and that there is a reasonable
  probability that, but for counselâ€™s errors, the result of the trial would have
  been different.Â  A reasonable probability is a probability sufficient to undermine confidence in
  the outcome of the trial.â€).Â  As both the deficient performance and prejudice
  prongs are satisfied, we hold trial counsel was ineffective.Â  Strickland v. Washington, 466 U.S. 668, 687 (1984).Â  Therefore, we reverse the denial of PCR and
  grant the requested relief of a new trial.
REVERSED AND
  REMANDED.
TOAL, C.J.,
  WALLER, PLEICONES and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Richard Temple, Petitioner,
				v.
				Tec-Fab, Inc.,
      and Andrew Lytle, Respondents.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF
  APPEALS

Appeal From York County
S. Jackson Kimball, III, Circuit Court
  Judge
Opinion No.Â  26610
Heard January 21, 2009 - Filed March 9,
  2009Â  
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND
  REMANDED


	
		
			
				William
  Thomas Moody, of McKeown Law Firm, of York, for Petitioner.
				J.
  Cameron Halford, of Halford & Niemiec Law Firm, of Ft. Mill, for Respondent.
			
		
	


PER
  CURIAM:Â  We granted a writ of
  certiorari to review the Court of Appealsâ€™ opinion in Temple v. Tec-Fab, Inc,
  370 S.C. 383, 635 S.E.2d 541 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  The issue on certiorari is
  whether the Court of Appeals erred in reversing an award of treble damages for
  a violation of the Payment of Wages Act.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part,
  and remand to the trial court.Â  
FACTS
Temple was employed
  at Tec-Fab, Inc., a metal fabrication company in York County, for a salary of
  $5000 per month.Â  In December 2000, Temple purchased a 15% ownership interest
  in the company from Tec-Fabâ€™s president and sole shareholder, Richard Lytle.Â  Temple became corporate vice-president and ran the company on a daily basis; his salary
  was increased to $6000 per month.Â  Temple remained employed by Tec-Fab until
  February 2003, at which time he was fired by Lytle.Â  The letter of termination
  advised Temple he would receive back pay upon receipt of money from Accutron, a
  Tec-Fab customer, in one month.
Temple filed a
  complaint in April 2003, alleging Tec-Fab failed to pay his monthly wages for
  the months of September, October, November, and half of December 2002, as well
  as February 2003, thereby owing him back wages.Â  The complaint sought treble
  damages under the Payment of Wages Act.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 41-10-10 to -110
  (1986 & Supp. 2005). 
Tec-Fab and Lytle
  answered and counterclaimed, alleging Temple 1) had failed to remit to it
  $15,000 in payments he had received from Accutron, 2) had failed to return a
  truck owned by Tec-Fab, and 3) had kept $5114 in proceeds from the sale of
  scrap metal which was owed to Tec-Fab.Â  At trial, Temple admitted he had kept
  some of the proceeds from the sale of scrap metal, such that the master ruled
  Tec-Fab was entitled to a set-off of $5114 against the back-wages owed.Â  Based
  on Lytleâ€™s testimony that he told Temple subsequent to his firing that he could
  keep the Tec-Fab truck if he assumed the liability on it (which was
  $20,568.30), the circuit court found there was no conversion of the vehicle nor
  any set-off required.Â  
The trial court further
  ruled Temple was entitled to the gross amount of his back wages, totaling
  $27,500.00, which was then reduced by the $5114 scrap metal proceeds.[1]Â Â 
  The masterâ€™s order goes on to state that the gross sum of $22,385.75 â€œwill
    be trebled as required by statute, giving a total award of wages to
  Plaintiff of $67,157.25.â€Â  (emphasis supplied).Â  Temple was also awarded
  $7069.50 in costs and attorneys fees.Â  
The Court of
  Appeals reversed the award of treble damages, finding the circuit court
  committed an error of law in concluding the statute mandated trebling.Â  It
  further held, after a review of the record on appeal, that there was a bona
  fide dispute over the wages in question.Â  It therefore modified Templeâ€™s award to $22,385.75 (Templeâ€™s gross unpaid wages less the $5,114.25 withheld in
  company proceeds). 
ISSUE
The sole issue on
  certiorari is whether the Court of Appeals erred in reversing the award of
  treble damages to Temple?
DISCUSSION
In an action at law
  tried without a jury, an appellate courtâ€™s scope of review extends merely to
  the correction of errors of law.Â  The Court will not disturb the trial courtâ€™s
  findings unless they are found to be without evidence that reasonably supports
  those findings. Townes Assocs., Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81,
  86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976).Â Â  
The Court of
  Appeals held the circuit courtâ€™s ruling was controlled by an error of law,
  inasmuch as the trial court held the statute required the imposition of
  treble damages.Â  We agree. 
S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  41-10-80(c) states, â€œ[i]n case of any failure to pay wages due to an employee
  as required by Section 41-10-40 or 41-10-50 the employee may recover in a civil
  action an amount equal to three times the full amount of the unpaid wages, plus
  costs and reasonable attorneyâ€™s fees as the court may allow.â€Â  The language of
  Â§ 41-10-80(c) is discretionary and not mandatory.Â  In Rice v. Multimedia,
    Inc., 318 S.C. 95, 98, 456 S.E.2d 381, 383 (1995), we held that â€œ[t]he
  imposition of treble damages in those cases where there is a bona fide dispute
  would be unjust and harsh.â€Â  The Court went on to note:

	[T]here
  are some wage disputes when the issue may involve a valid close question of law
  or fact which should properly be decided by the courts. We do not believe the
  legislature intended to deter the litigation of reasonable good faith wage
  disputes; we do believe the legislature intended to punish the employer who
  forces the employee to resort to the court in an unreasonable or bad faith wage
  dispute.

Id. at 99, 456 S.E.2d at 384.Â  A finding that an employee
  is entitled to recover unpaid wages is not equivalent to a finding that there
  existed no bona fide dispute as to the employeeâ€™s entitlement to those wages.Â  Oâ€™Neal
    v. Intermedical Hosp. of South Carolina, 355 S.C. 499, 585 S.E.2d 526 (Ct.
  App. 2003).Â  Accord Futch v. McAlister, 335 S.C. 598, 518 S.E.2d
  591 (1999) (employee was not entitled to treble damages under Payment of Wages
  Act in light of bona fide dispute as to whether employer owed any wages based
  on employeeâ€™s alleged disloyalty).
Although we agree
  with the Court of Appealsâ€™ ruling that the trial judgeâ€™s award of treble
  damages was controlled by an error of law, we find it was for the trial court
  to determine, in the first instance, whether there existed a bona fide dispute
  such that treble damages were not warranted.Â  See Noisette v. Ismail, 304 S.C. 56, 58, 403 S.E.2d 122,
    124 (1991) (Court of Appeals should
  not address an issue which was not explicitly ruled on below).Â  Accordingly, to
  the extent the Court of Appeals ruled on this question, its opinion is reversed
  and the matter is remanded to the trial court for further consideration.Â  

AFFIRMED IN
  PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED.[2]Â  
TOAL, C.J.,
  WALLER, PLEICONES, BEATTY, JJ., and Acting Justice James E. Moore, concur.


[1]Â  The master ordered the record re-opened to
  ascertain the amount of scrap metal proceeds retained by Temple unless he
  consented to the amount of $5114, as stated by Tec-Fab; Temple consented.Â  This
  was an amended order; the original order indicated Temple was entitled to net,
  rather than gross wages.
[2] Â The parties assert that the Court of Appeals
  also reversed the award of attorneys fees and costs; we find no language to
  this effect in the Court of Appealsâ€™ opinion.Â Â  The trial court is directed to
  address this issue on remand and may award attorneys fees and costs in its
  discretion.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Thomas D.
      Jordan, Petitioner,
				v.
				Kelly Company,
      Inc., Employer, and Zenith Insurance Company, Carrier, Respondents.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF
  APPEALS

Appeal from Horry County
B. Hicks Harwell, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge
Opinion No.Â  26611
Heard January 6, 2009 - Filed March 9,
  2009Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				David
  James Canty, of Myrtle Beach, and James L. Hills, of Hills & Hills, of Myrtle
  Beach, for Petitioner.
				Christian
  Stegmaier and Peter H. Dworjanyn, both of Collins & Lacy, of Columbia, for Respondents.
			
		
	


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL: In
  this workersâ€™ compensation case, the
  single commissioner found Petitionerâ€™s injury compensable and awarded benefits,
  but the full commission reversed.Â  The circuit court reversed the full
  commission and reinstated the single commissionerâ€™s decision awarding
  benefits.Â  The court of appeals reversed the circuit court, finding that
  substantial evidence in the record supported the full commissionâ€™s decision.Â  Jordan v. Kelly Co. Inc., Op. No. 2007-UP-010 (S.C. Ct. App. filed January 11, 2007).Â 
  We granted a writ of certiorari to review the court of appealsâ€™ decision.Â  We
  affirm
Factual/Procedural
  Background

Petitioner
  Thomas Jordan was employed as a driver by Respondent Kelly Company, Inc., a
  hauling company specializing in transporting heavy equipment.Â  On January 11,
  2003, following the completion of a long haul route from Virginia to Texas, Petitioner suffered a heart attack.Â  Petitioner filed a claim for workersâ€™
  compensation benefits and alleged that the heart attack was proximately caused
  by unusual and extraordinary duties during this haul.
At
  the hearing, Petitioner testified that on Wednesday, January 8, 2003, Kelly
  Company sent him to pick up a large piece of equipment in Virginia and
  transport it to Texas by Friday, January 10, 2003.Â  Because the equipment had
  not been loaded, Petitioner departed seven hours past schedule, leaving him
  only two hours of travel time on Wednesday.[1]Â 
  Additionally, Petitioner testified that the required permits were not ready for
  him when he left Virginia and he therefore had to drive without the permits
  until he could pick up copies at a truck stop.Â  On Thursday, Petitioner drove
  from North Carolina to Alabama, and on Friday he drove from Alabama to Louisiana.Â  Petitioner informed a dispatcher that he would not be able to deliver the
  equipment to Texas by the Friday deadline, but the dispatcher informed
  Petitioner that the deadline was extended to 12:00 p.m. Saturday.Â  When
  Petitioner arrived in Texas on Saturday morning, he was unable to take the exit
  that his permit required him to take because the exit was under construction.Â 
  As a result, he had to deviate from his route through downtown Houston.Â  Petitioner made the delivery at 11:57.Â  
Petitioner
  testified that he began experiencing symptoms associated with a heart attack
  during the haul and on Saturday night.Â  He further testified that the haul was
  extremely stressful because he was forced to leave Virginia and travel without
  the required permits and to drive illegally through downtown Houston without a
  special permit or police escort.Â  
The
  single commissioner found that Petitionerâ€™s heart attack was precipitated by
  unusual and extraordinary conditions of his employment on the trip.Â  The full
  commission reversed and found that Petitioner was performing his job duties as
  a long haul driver in the ordinary and usual manner.Â  The circuit court
  reversed the full commissionâ€™s decision and reinstated the award of benefits.Â 
  The court of appeals reversed the circuit court and held that that substantial
  evidence in the record supported the full commissionâ€™s decision denying
  benefits.Â  
We
  granted Petitionerâ€™s request for a writ of certiorari to review the court of
  appealsâ€™ decision, and Petitioner presents the following issue for review:

	Did the
  court of appeals err in finding substantial evidence in the record exists to
  support the full commissionâ€™s findings?

Standard of Review
In workersâ€™ compensation cases, the full commission is the
  ultimate fact finder.Â Â  Shealy v. Aiken County, 341
  S.C. 448, 455, 535 S.E.2d 438, 442 (2000).Â  This Court must affirm the findings of
  fact made by the full commission if they are supported by substantial evidence.
  Â Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 136, 276 S.E.2d 304, 307 (1981). Â Substantial
  evidence is not a mere scintilla of evidence, but evidence which, considering
  the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion the
  agency reached. Tiller v. Natâ€™l Health Care Ctr., 334 S.C. 333, 338, 513 S.E.2d
  843, 845 (1999).
Law/Analysis
Petitioner argues
  that the court of appeals erred in holding that substantial evidence in the
  record exists to support the full commissionâ€™s findings.Â  We disagree.
A claimant may recover workersâ€™ compensation benefits if he sustains an â€œinjury by accident arising out of and in the
  course of the employment.â€  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-160 (2006).Â  The general rule is that a heart attack is
  compensable as a workerâ€™s compensation accident if it is induced by unexpected
  strain or overexertion in the performance of the duties of a claimantâ€™s
  employment or by unusual and extraordinary conditions of employment.Â  Hoxit
    v. Michelin Tire Corp., 304 S.C. 461, 464, 405 S.E.2d 407, 409 (1991).Â  
In
  our view, the court of appeals correctly held that substantial evidence in the
  record supported the full commissionâ€™s finding that Petitioner
  was not performing his job duties under unusual or extraordinary conditions of
  his employment.Â  Although Petitioner testified that the haul was extremely
  stressful, Petitionerâ€™s boss and co-worker testified that the Kelly Company
  did not impose deadlines and that it was not unusual for employees to deviate
  from their routes due to construction.Â  Petitioner admitted that he had left without permits on prior deliveries and that when this
  would happen, he would pick up a faxed copy of the permits at the nearest truck
  stop.Â  Furthermore, evidence in the record showed that Petitioner smoked
  cigarettes, had abused alcohol, suffered from high blood pressure, and had a
  family history of heart disease.Â  
Although the record contains conflicting evidence, this Court is
  not in a position to weigh the evidence presented in workersâ€™ compensation
  hearing.Â  See Shealy, 341 S.C. at 455, 535 S.E.2d at 442 (holding that the final determination of
  witness credibility and the weight to be accorded evidence is reserved to the
  full commission, and it is not the task of an appellate court to weigh the
  evidence as found by the full commission).Â  Accordingly, we hold that
  substantial evidence in the record supports the full commissionâ€™s finding that
  Petitionerâ€™s heart attack was not induced by unexpected strain or overexertion
  in the performance of the duties of his employment or by unusual and
  extraordinary conditions of employment.Â  
Conclusion
For the foregoing reasons, we affirm the court of appealsâ€™
  decision denying benefits.Â Â  
WALLER, PLEICONES, BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.


[1] Petitioner testified that drivers are only allowed to transport heavy equipment
  during daylight hours.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Deborah W.
      Spence, Individually, and on behalf of the Estate of Floyd W. Spence, Petitioner,
				v.
				Kenneth B.
      Wingate, Sweeny Wingate & Barrow, P.A., and Robert P. Wilkins, Jr., Defendants,
				of whom Kenneth
      B. Wingate and Sweeny Wingate & Barrow, P.A. are Respondents.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARIÂ TO THE COURT OF APPEALS

Appeal from Richland County
Â G. Thomas Cooper, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge
Opinion No. 26613
Submitted March 4, 2009 - Filed March 9,
  2009
REVERSED AND REMANDED


	
		
			
				A. Camden Lewis, and Brady R. Thomas, of Lewis & Babcock, LLP,
  of Columbia, for Petitioner.
				Pope D. Johnson, III, of Johnson & Barnette, LLP, of Columbia, for Respondents.
			
		
	


PER
  CURIAM:Â  Petitioner filed
  a legal malpractice action against respondents.Â  The trial judge granted respondentsâ€™ motion for summary judgment
  on the issue of whether respondents owed petitioner a fiduciary duty with
  respect to a congressional life insurance policy issued to petitionerâ€™s late
  husband.Â  The Court of Appeals affirmed, holding the issue was not preserved
  for review.Â  Spence v. Wingate, 378 S.C. 486, 663 S.E.2d 70 (Ct. App.
  2008).Â  We grant the petition for a writ of certiorari, dispense with further
  briefing, reverse the Court of Appealsâ€™ opinion, and remand the matter to the
  Court of Appeals for a ruling on the merits of petitionerâ€™s arguments.
At the
  hearing on respondentsâ€™ motion for summary judgment, respondents argued they
  were entitled to summary judgment because there existed no attorney-client
  relationship between respondents and petitioner; therefore, respondents owed no
  duty to petitioner.Â  Petitioner countered that she was a former client of
  respondents, and maintained respondents owed her a fiduciary duty based on the relationship.Â 
  The trial judge granted summary judgment, finding respondents â€œowed no duty or
  obligationâ€ to petitioner.Â  
The
  Court of Appeals held the issue was not preserved for review because petitioner
  failed to file a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion to alter or amend the judgment.Â  The
  Court of Appeals found the argument was not preserved because the trial judge
  did not mention petitionerâ€™s alternative theory of liability that, as a former
  client of respondents, she had a continuing fiduciary relationship with
  respondents.Â  
We hold
  the Court of Appeals erred in finding the issue was not preserved for appeal.Â  The
  trial judgeâ€™s order granted respondentsâ€™ motion for summary judgment on precisely the grounds argued by respondents at the summary judgment hearing.Â  While that
  order did not restate the ground on which petitioner opposed the motion - a
  duty based on the existence of a prior attorney-client relationship - the order
  explicitly addresses that argument by ruling respondents â€œowed no duty or
  obligationâ€ to petitioner.Â  This ruling is sufficient to preserve petitionerâ€™s
  argument that respondents owed a duty to petitioner, and petitioner was not
  required to file a Rule 59(e) motion to alter or amend in order to preserve the
  issue for appeal.Â  See Iâ€™On, L.L.C. v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 338
  S.C. 406, 422, 526 S.E.2d 716, 724 (2000) (holding that, if the losing party
  has raised an issue in the lower court, but the court fails to rule upon it,
  the party must file a Rule 59(e) motion to alter or amend the judgment in order
  to preserve the issue for appellate review).
Accordingly,
  we hold the Court of Appeals erred in finding the issue was not preserved for
  review, and we remand the matter to the Court of Appeals for a ruling on the
  merits.Â  
REVERSED AND REMANDED.
WALLER,
  ACTING CHIEF JUSTICE, BEATTY, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur; TOAL, C.J., and
  PLEICONES, J., not participating.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				In the Matter of Michael T.
      Jordan, Respondent.
			
		
	


Opinion No.Â  26614
Submitted February 6, 2009 - Filed March 9, 2009Â  

DISBARRED


	
		
			
				Lesley M.
  Coggiola, Disciplinary Counsel, and Barbara M. Seymour, Deputy Disciplinary
  Counsel, both of Columbia, for the Office of Disciplinary Counsel. 
				J.
  Steedley Bogan, of Columbia, for respondent.Â  
			
		
	


PER
  CURIAM:Â Â  In this attorney disciplinary
  matter, respondent and the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) have entered
  into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule
  413, SCACR.Â  In the agreement, respondent admits misconduct and consents to any
  sanction provided for in Rule 7(b), RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  We accept the
  agreement and disbar respondent from the practice of law in this state.Â  The
  facts, as set forth in the agreement, are as follows.Â  

FACTS
Matter I
Respondent
  entered into a contract with his friend and business associate, Complainant.Â 
  In the contract, respondent agreed to purchase a residential lot from
  Complainant and Complainant agreed to finance the purchase.Â  There was no
  written contract memorializing the terms of the partiesâ€™ agreement.Â  
Respondent prepared all of
  the documents to complete the conveyance of the property, including the deed,
  the mortgage, and the note.Â  In preparing these documents, respondent was
  acting in a representative capacity for Complainant.Â  Â 
Complainant knew
  respondent was an attorney with experience in residential real estate
  transactions.Â  As a result, she did not consult with or obtain her own counsel
  for the sale of her property to respondent.Â  Â Â  
Respondent failed to
  disclose to Complainant that it was a conflict of interest for him to engage in
  a transaction with a client.Â  He did not obtain Complainantâ€™s written waiver of
  or consent to the conflict and he did not advise Complainant to seek the advice
  of independent counsel prior to entering into the transaction.Â  
Respondent conducted a
  closing in which he delivered two checks to Complainant as the agreed-upon down
  payment.Â  At the closing, respondent instructed Complainant to sign two sets of
  documents, one naming himself as grantee and one naming his LLC as grantee.Â  
Respondent did not file
  the deed or the mortgage after the closing.Â  He did not deliver the note to
  Complainant.Â  
When Complainant attempted
  to negotiate the down payment checks, they were returned for insufficient
  funds.Â  At respondentâ€™s request, Complainant attempted to negotiate the checks
  a second time.Â  Again, the checks were returned for insufficient funds.Â  
Two months after the
  closing, respondent applied for a loan to purchase another residential
  property.Â  He attempted to use the lot he purchased from Complainant as
  collateral.Â  The loan officer informed respondent that the deed conveying the
  lot to him was not recorded.Â  At that time, respondent recorded the deed, but
  not the mortgage.Â  
Respondent paid
  Complainant only five of the twelve scheduled payments in the year following
  the closing.Â  He did not pay the balance in full which was due at the end of
  the year.Â  
Six months after the
  balance in full was due, respondent brought his payments current, but did not
  pay off the balance.Â  Ultimately, Complainant hired a lawyer.Â  Respondent then
  sold the lot and paid her in full from the proceeds.Â  
Respondent agrees the
  terms of the transaction with Complainant were not fair and reasonable to
  Complainant because respondentâ€™s personal financial situation rendered him
  unable to pay as agreed.Â  
Matter II
On
  December 21, 2007, respondent signed a plea agreement in which he pled to an
  information charging him with one count of wire fraud.[1] Â The plea agreement was accepted by
  the United States District Court on January 22, 2008.Â  The wire fraud to which
  respondent pled guilty involved unauthorized transfers of client funds from
  respondentâ€™s trust accounts for respondentâ€™s personal benefit from 2003 to
  2007.Â  The total amount of funds respondent fraudulently obtained from his
  trust accounts was $2,325,404.18. 
The
  unauthorized transfers from respondentâ€™s trust accounts resulted in a series of
  checks being presented on insufficient funds which were reported to the
  Commission on Lawyer Conduct by respondentâ€™s bank as required by Rule 1.15(h),
  RLDE.Â  
LAW
Respondent admits that, by his
  misconduct, he has violated the following provisions of the Rules of
  Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR:Â  Rule 1.1 (lawyer shall provide
  competent representation to a client); Rule 1.3 (lawyer 
shall act with reasonable diligence and promptness
    in representing a client); Rule 1.7 (lawyer shall not represent client if
    representation involves a conflict of interest unless specified conditions are
    met); Rule 1.8 (lawyer shall not knowingly acquire possessory interest adverse
    to client unless specified conditions are met); Â Rule 1.15
  (lawyer shall hold property of clients in the lawyerâ€™s possession in connection
  with a representation separate from the lawyerâ€™s own property); Rule 8.4(b) (it
  is professional misconduct for lawyer to commit a criminal act that reflects
  adversely on the lawyerâ€™s honesty, trustworthiness or fitness as a lawyer in
  other respects); Rule 8.4(c) (it is professional misconduct for lawyer to
  engage in conduct involving moral turpitude); Rule 8.4(d) (it is professional
  misconduct for a lawyer to engage in conduct involving dishonesty, fraud,
  deceit, or misrepresentation); and Rule 8.4(e) (it is professional misconduct
  for a lawyer to engage in conduct that is prejudicial to the administration of
  justice).Â  
Respondent further admits his
  misconduct is grounds for discipline under Rule 7, RLDE, of Rule 413, SCACR,
  specifically Rule 7(a)(1) (it shall be ground for discipline for lawyer to violate
  Rules of Professional Conduct), Rule 7(a)(4) (it shall be ground for discipline
  for lawyer to be convicted of crime or moral turpitude or serious crime), Rule
  7(a)(5) (it shall be ground for discipline for lawyer to engage in conduct
  tending to pollute administration of justice, bring courts or legal profession
  into disrepute, or conduct demonstrating an unfitness to practice law), and Rule
  7(a)(6) (it shall be ground for discipline for lawyer to violate oath of
  office).Â  
CONCLUSION
We accept the Agreement for Discipline
  by Consent and disbar respondent from the practice of law.Â  Further, before he
  may file a Petition for Reinstatement, respondent must make restitution to all
  clients, banks, the Lawyersâ€™ Fund for Client Protection, and any other entities
  which have been harmed as a result of his misconduct in connection with this
  matter.Â  Within fifteen (15) days of the date of this opinion, respondent shall
  file an affidavit with the Clerk of Court showing that he has complied with
  Rule 30 of Rule 413, SCACR, and shall also surrender his Certificate of
  Admission to the Practice of Law to the Clerk of Court.Â  Â  Â 
DISBARRED.
TOAL, C.J.,
  WALLER, PLEICONES, BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.


[1] On August 7, 2007. the Court placed respondent
  on interim suspension.Â  In the Matter of Jordan, 374 S.C. 350, 650
  S.E.2d 58 (2007).

title: Hiott v. State
description: We granted certiorari in this case to determine whether Rule 11 of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure is applicable in post-conviction relief proceedings.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Milton Hiott, Petitioner,
        v.
        State of South Carolina, Respondent.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF
APPEALS

Appeal From Bamberg County
  Â Reginald I. Lloyd, Post-Conviction Relief
Judge

Opinion No.Â  26615
  Heard February 18, 2009 - Filed March 16,
2009Â  

REVERSED


  
    
      
        Appellate
          Defender Robert M. Pachak, of the South Carolina Office of Indigent Defense, of
          Columbia, for Petitioner.
        Attorney
          General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
          Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Assistant Attorney General David
          Spencer, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE
  BEATTY:Â  Milton Hiottâ€™s application
  for post-conviction relief (PCR) was denied.Â  The PCR judge found Hiottâ€™s
  testimony and claims were frivolous and sanctioned him $3,000 pursuant to Rule
  11 of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure.Â  The Court of Appeals
  affirmed, holding as a matter of first impression that Rule 11 is applicable in
  PCR proceedings.Â  Hiott v. State, 375 S.C. 354, 652 S.E.2d 436 (Ct. App. 2007).Â  We granted Hiottâ€™s petition for a writ of certiorari and now reverse.
I.Â  FACTS
Hiott was convicted
  of incest with his daughter after a two-day criminal trial on January 16 and
  17, 2003.Â  He filed a PCR application on June 9, 2003.Â  Hiott was represented
  by counsel at the PCR hearing.Â Â Â  
During
  the hearing, Hiott asserted that his trial counsel was ineffective for, among
  other things, failing to discover that his daughter had previously been
  molested by a family friend.Â  He also contended the prosecution committed a Brady[1] violation by not disclosing this information to the defense.Â Â Â  
Hiottâ€™s
  trial counsel apparently first became aware of the incident when one of Hiottâ€™s
  family members advised him about it during Hiottâ€™s criminal trial.Â  Hiott
  maintained the incident did not occur to him because he had put it out of his
  mind, but if counsel had adequately questioned him it likely would have â€œjogged
  [his] memoryâ€ and he probably would not have been convicted.Â  
The
  PCR judge found Hiottâ€™s claims in this regard were â€œabsurdâ€ and â€œpatently
  frivolousâ€ because Hiott was the complaining party in the molestation case, yet
  he supposedly forgot to mention it to his trial attorney.Â  The PCR judge further
  found the prosecution did not commit a Brady violation as the
  information was readily available to Hiott.Â  The PCR judge ruled the remaining
  issues raised by Hiott were also without merit.Â  
The
  PCR judge imposed a $3,000 sanction on Hiott under Rule 11, SCRCP, finding
  Hiottâ€™s testimony and claims were frivolous.Â  The PCR judge stated that he
  considered many variables in making this decision, including the time and
  expense incurred by the South Carolina Attorney Generalâ€™s Office, the South
  Carolina Department of Corrections, Hiottâ€™s appointed attorney, and the court.
The Court of
  Appeals affirmed the imposition of a sanction under Rule 11, SCRCP.Â  Hiott
    v. State, 375 S.C. 354, 652 S.E.2d 436 (Ct. App. 2007).Â  We granted Hiottâ€™s
  petition for a writ of certiorari. 
II.Â  STANDARD OF REVIEW
The
  decision of the PCR judge may be reversed when it is controlled by an error of
  law.Â  Pierce v. State, 338 S.C. 139, 526 S.E.2d 222 (2000).Â  This Court
  is entitled to decide a novel question of law without any particular deference
  to the lower court.Â  Page v. State, 364 S.C. 632, 615 S.E.2d 740 (2005).
III.Â  LAW/ANALYSIS
Rule
  11(a), SCRCP provides in relevant part as follows:

  The signature of an attorney or party constitutes a
    certificate by him that he has read the pleading, motion or other paper; that to
    the best of his knowledge, information and belief there is good ground to
    support it; and that it is not interposed for delay. 
  . . . .
  . . .Â  If a pleading, motion, or other paper is signed
    in violation of this Rule, the court, upon motion or upon its own initiative,
    may impose upon the person who signed it, a represented party, or both, an
    appropriate sanction, which may include an order to pay to the other party or
    parties the amount of the reasonable expenses incurred because of the filing of
    the pleading, motion or other paper, including a reasonable attorneyâ€™s fee.

The sole
  issue before the Court of Appeals, as here, is whether the PCR judge erred in
  finding Rule 11 applies to PCR proceedings.[2]Â 
  The Court of Appeals, noting this was a case of first impression, affirmed the
  PCR judgeâ€™s ruling.Â  The court first noted that the Uniform Post-Conviction
  Procedure Act specifically provides that the South Carolina Rules of Civil
  Procedure are applicable in PCR actions.Â  Hiott, 375 S.C. at 357, 652
  S.E.2d at 437.
Section
  17-27-80 of the Act provides:Â  â€œAll rules and statutes applicable in civil
  proceedings are available to the parties.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-27-80 (2003).Â 
  The Court of Appeals stated all rules that apply in civil cases apply to PCR
  actions; therefore, â€œRule 11 would apply to PCR proceedings because PCR actions
  are civil.â€Â  Hiott, 375 S.C. at 357, 652 S.E.2d at 437.Â  
The
  Court of Appeals next observed that the South Carolina Legislature has
  specifically limited the application of discovery in PCR proceedings in section
  17-27-150[3] of the Act, and stated that â€œ[i]f the legislature sought to limit the
  applicability of Rule 11 to PCR proceedings as it sought to limit the discovery
  process, the legislature would have inserted constricting language to that
  effect in the Act.â€Â  Id.Â  
Finally,
  citing Rule 1 and Rule 71.1(a), SCRCP, the Court of Appeals observed that â€œthe
  South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure support the conclusion that Rule 11 is
  applicable to PCR actions.â€Â  Id. at 357-58, 652 S.E.2d at 437.Â Â Â  
Rule
  1, SCRCP states:Â  â€œThese rules govern the procedure in all South Carolina
  courts in all suits of a civil nature whether cognizable as cases at law
  or in equity, with the exceptions stated in Rule 81.â€Â  Rule 81 contains
  no exception stating Rule 11 is inapplicable in PCR actions. 
Rule
  71.1(a), SCRCP, regarding PCR actions, provides as follows:

  (a) Procedure.Â 
    The procedure for post-conviction relief is provided by the Uniform
    Post-Conviction Procedure Act (Act), S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 17-27-10 to -120 (1985).[4]Â 
    The South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure shall apply to the extent that they
    are not inconsistent with the Act.

The
  Court of Appeals concluded:Â  â€œGiven the plain language of Rules 1 and 71.1 and
  that Rule 11 is consistent with the Act, ample justification exists to conclude
  Rule 11 applies to PCR situations.â€Â  Hiott, 375 S.C. at 358, 652 S.E.2d
  at 438.
On
  review, Hiott asserts that Rule 11 sanctions should not apply in PCR proceedings
  because â€œ[t]o hold otherwise would be to put a chilling effect on an
  applicantâ€™s right to file for post-conviction relief.â€Â  Hiott states PCR
  applications are often prepared by the petitioners themselves or other inmates,
  and they are often not educated in the law and are not readily able to discern
  meritorious issues.[5]Â Â Â  
The
  State, in contrast, contends a circuit court judge has the authority to
  sanction a PCR applicant just like any other plaintiff in a civil action and
  that PCR applicants â€œdo not have special rights to present frivolous claims and
  testimony.â€Â  The State argues â€œan applicantâ€™s education, representation by
  counsel, potential reliance on an individual [who] is unlicensed to practice
  law, and the manner in which a claim is raised are all considerations that a
  circuit court could properly examine to determine if sanctions are
  appropriate.â€Â  Moreover, any â€œ[s]anctions imposed . . . can be reviewed on appeal.â€Â  
The
  Court of Appeals correctly determined there is currently no provision in either
  the Uniform Post-Conviction Procedure Act or the South Carolina Rules of Civil
  Procedure that expressly prohibits the application of Rule 11 in PCR
  actions.Â  
In an analogous
  case, however, this Court previously held that a statute revoking inmate
  credits for prisoners submitting frivolous claims or giving false testimony
  should not be applied to PCR applicants.Â  In Wade v. State, 348 S.C.
  255, 559 S.E.2d 843 (2002), the petitioner filed a PCR application, which was
  denied.Â  The PCR judge also revoked petitionerâ€™s inmate credits under section
  24-27-200 of the Inmate Litigation Act (ILA) for testifying falsely at the PCR
  hearing.[6]Â  Id. at 257, 559 S.E.2d at 844.Â  
We
  stated this provision â€œmay not stop a prisoner from utilizing the PCR
  structure, but it would assuredly chill a prisonerâ€™s exercise of a
  constitutional right,â€ and â€œ[s]uch a result is contrary to the long tradition
  of giving prisoners ready access to PCR [proceedings].â€Â  Id. at 262, 559
  S.E.2d at 846.
Further,
  we reasoned that, although the ILA applies to civil actions, and PCR actions
  are civil, courts treat PCR actions differently than traditional civil cases:

  Courts treat PCR differently than traditional civil
    cases.Â  For example, PCR actions are the only type of case which this Court
    mandates appellate counsel must brief all arguable issues, despite counselâ€™s
    belief the appeal is frivolous.Â  A lawyer knowingly filing a frivolous claim
      in any other civil case violates Rule 11, SCRCP.Â  Additionally, a PCR
    applicant who is granted a hearing has a statutory right to be represented by a
    court-appointed attorney.Â  This right does not generally exist for plaintiffs
    in civil cases.

Id. at 263, 559 S.E.2d at 847 (internal citations and
  footnote omitted) (emphasis added).Â  
In Hiott,
  the Court of Appeals, citing Wade, stated that it was â€œcognizant that
  â€˜[c]ourts treat PCR differently than traditional civil cases,â€™â€ but
  nevertheless concluded PCR courts have the authority to issue Rule 11 sanctions
  against PCR applicants â€œgiven the plain language of the [Uniform
  Post-Conviction Procedure] Act and the South Carolina Rules of Civil
  Procedure[.]â€Â  Hiott, 375 S.C. at 358, 652 S.E.2d at 438.
Although
  the PCR judge in the current case was understandably concerned with the
  potential abuse of PCR proceedings by inmates filing meritless claims, as noted
  in Wade, â€œthe legislative and judicial systems already place limitations
  to deter inmate litigation abuse in the PCR process.â€Â  Wade, 348 S.C. at
  263, 559 S.E.2d at 847.Â  
â€œFirst,
  a petitioner must raise all available grounds for relief in the first PCR
  application since successive actions are usually barred.â€Â  Id. at
  263-64, 559 S.E.2d at 847; see also Aice v. State, 305 S.C. 448,
  409 S.E.2d 392 (1991) (discussing successive applications); S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  17-27-90 (2003) (stating all grounds for relief must be raised in the first PCR
  application unless the court finds there is a sufficient reason why they were
  not asserted in the original application).Â Â Â  
â€œSecond,
  an applicant must file the PCR application within one year of the final
  resolution of the criminal conviction.â€Â  Wade, 348 S.C. at 264, 559
  S.E.2d at 847; see also S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-27-45(A) (2003) (stating a
  PCR application â€œmust be filed within one year after the entry of a judgment of
  conviction or within one year after the sending of the remittitur to the lower
  court from an appeal or the filing of the final decision upon an appeal,
  whichever is laterâ€).
â€œThird,
  a petitioner faces a one-year deadline to file an application asserting a newly
  created standard or right, and to raise newly discovered material facts.â€Â  Wade,
  348 S.C. at 264, 559 S.E.2d at 847; see also S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-27-45(B),
  (C) (2003) (providing one year from the determination of a newly created
  standard or right in subsection (B) and one year from the time new evidence was
  discovered, or could have been discovered by due diligence, in subsection (C)).
Together,
  these provisions effectively grant an individual â€œone chance to argue for
  reliefâ€ within a year of the final appeal; consequently, â€œ[t]hese limitations
  adequately prevent inmates from abusing the PCR process.â€Â  Wade, 348
  S.C. at 264, 559 S.E.2d at 847.Â Â  
Given the public policy
  considerations involved, including our recognition in Wade that PCR
  actions are treated differently than traditional civil cases and that sanctions
  of any kind could chill a petitionerâ€™s pursuit of PCR, as well as the fact that
  there are already limitations in place that serve to curb the potential abuse
  of the PCR process, we hold that Rule 11 of the South Carolina Rules of Civil
  Procedure does not apply in PCR proceedings.Â  We can discern no practical
  benefit to be obtained by imposing sanctions on PCR petitioners who are often indigent.Â 
  Further, the increase in appellate review that would be necessitated by the challenges
  to any sanctions imposed would create an additional burden on the resources of
  the courts, which would effectively thwart the stated purpose of imposing
  sanctions in the first place.
IV.Â  CONCLUSION
Based on the
  foregoing, we hold, as a matter of public policy, that Rule 11 of the South
  Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure does not apply to PCR proceedings.Â  Accordingly,
  the decision of the Court of Appeals is 
REVERSED.Â  
TOAL,
  C.J., WALLER, PLEICONES, JJ., and Acting Justice Timothy M. Cain, concur.


[1]Â  Brady v. Maryland, 373 U.S. 83 (1963).
[2]Â  The Court of Appeals noted that â€œHiott does not
  argue the PCR judge abused his discretion by imposing sanctions.Â  The sole
  issue on appeal is whether the PCR judge had authority to issue Rule 11
  sanctions.Â  Thus, we do not address whether the PCR judge abused his discretion
  in sanctioning Hiott.â€Â  Hiott, 375 S.C. at 358 n.5, 652 S.E.2d at 438
  n.5.
[3]Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-27-150(A) (2003) (â€œA
  party in a noncapital post-conviction relief proceeding shall be entitled to
  invoke the processes of discovery available under the South Carolina Rules of
  Civil Procedure if, and to the extent that, the judge in the exercise of his
  discretion and for good cause shown grants leave to do so, but not
  otherwise.â€).
[4]Â 
The Act has been updated to S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 17-27-10 to -120 (2003).
[5] Hiott also maintains the Court of Appeals
  â€œapparentlyâ€ found it was frivolous that he did not present testimony for some
  of the claims he raised in his PCR application and penalized him.Â  He asserts
  that requiring a petitioner to present meritless claims, however, would create
  an undue burden on the courts.Â  As the State correctly points out, the Court of
  Appeals made no such finding and did not examine the validity of Hiottâ€™s PCR
  claims.Â  Thus, there is no merit to this allegation.
[6]Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 24-27-200 (2007) (providing for the forfeiture of
  inmate credits by a prisoner who submits a frivolous claim, testifies falsely,
unreasonably delays a proceeding, or abuses the discovery process).
