THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Marsha Tennant, Petitioner,
        v.
        Beaufort County School District, Employer, and
          S.C. School Board Insurance Trust, Carrier, of whom Beaufort County School District is Respondent.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF
APPEALS

Appeal from Beaufort County
Â Curtis L. Coltrane, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26616
  Heard January 7, 2009 - Filed March 16,
2009Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        James
          H. Moss, Esquire and H. Fred Kuhn, both of Moss, Kuhn & Fleming, of Beaufort,
          for Petitioner.
        Kirsten
          L. Barr, Jamie C. Guerrero, and Kathryn C. Thompson, all of Trask and Howell, of
          Mt. Pleasant, for Respondent.
      
    
  


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL: In this workersâ€™ compensation case, the single
  commissioner denied benefits, and the full commission, the circuit court, and
  the court of appeals affirmed.Â  Tennant v. Beaufort County Sch. Dist. Op. No. 2007-UP-056 (S.C. Ct. App. filed February 8, 2007).Â  This Court granted
  a writ of certiorari to review the court of appealsâ€™ decision.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL
  BACKGROUND
Petitioner Marsha
  Tennant worked as a special education teacher for thirty years prior to working
  for Respondent in that same role.Â  In the fall of 2001, after being employed
  for approximately one year with Respondent, two new aides were assigned to
  assist Petitioner with her students in the classroom.Â  As the year progressed,
  Petitioner was concerned that the aides were not performing their job in violation
  of federal Individualized Education Programs regulations and worried that the
  aidesâ€™ performances would jeopardize the education program.Â  Both Petitioner
  and the aides complained to the supervisor.
On
  October 18, 2001, after an argument with the aides, Tennant felt faint and went
  to the nurseâ€™s office, where the nurse recorded Petitionerâ€™s blood pressure as
  elevated.Â  Petitioner later returned to the nurseâ€™s office complaining of chest
  pains and dizziness.Â  The nurse recorded a higher blood pressure and called an
  ambulance.Â  The emergency room doctor diagnosed Petitioner with a stress
  reaction.Â  
At the hearing,
  Petitionerâ€™s family doctor (â€œFamily Doctorâ€) testified that Petitioner suffered a panic attack that was caused by work
  conditions and diagnosed Petitioner with â€œsituational depression and panic
  disorder.â€Â  Additionally, Petitioner submitted the deposition testimony of a
  licensed social worker (â€œSociologistâ€) who began treating Petitioner at her
  psychotherapy practice after the anxiety attack. Â Sociologist diagnosed
  Petitioner with post traumatic stress disorder and continued panic attacks and
  concluded that Petitioner should not return to work as a special education
  teacher. Â Respondent submitted a letter from a psychiatrist (â€œPsychiatristâ€) who
  evaluated Petitioner.Â  She concluded that Petitioner suffered a single anxiety
  attack, but that Petitioner did not require additional medical treatment and
  could return to work.Â  
The
  single commissioner found that Petitioner failed to prove that the conditions
  of her employment were either extraordinary or unusual.Â  Additionally, the
  single commissioner gave greater weight to the testimony of Psychiatrist than
  to the testimonies of Family Doctor and Sociologist and ruled that Sociologist
  was not qualified to render an opinion on causation under South Carolina case
  law.Â  The full commission ruled that Sociologistâ€™s testimony should be made a
  part of the record, but affirmed the denial of benefits.Â  The circuit court and
  the court of appeals found that substantial evidence in the record supported a
  finding that Petitioner did not suffer a compensable injury, and therefore,
  affirmed the full commissionâ€™s decision.
We granted
  a writ of certiorari to review the court of appealsâ€™ decision, and Petitioner
  presents the following issue for review:

  Did the
    court of appeals err in affirming the order denying benefits because the full
    commissionâ€™s decision is not support by substantial evidence?

STANDARD OF
REVIEW
This Court must affirm the findings of fact made by the full commission
  if they are supported by substantial evidence. Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276
  S.C. 130, 136, 276 S.E.2d 304, 307 (1981). Â Substantial evidence is not a mere
  scintilla of evidence, but evidence which, considering the record as a whole,
  would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion the agency reached. Tiller
    v. Natâ€™l Health Care Ctr., 334 S.C. 333, 338, 513 S.E.2d
  843, 845 (1999).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Petitioner argues that the court of appeals erred in affirming the
  full commissionâ€™s finding that she did not suffer a compensable injury.Â  We
  disagree.
In
  order to recover for mental injuries caused solely by emotional stress, or
  â€œmental-mentalâ€ injuries, the claimant must
  show that she was exposed to unusual and extraordinary conditions in her employment
  and that these unusual and extraordinary conditions were the proximate cause of
  the mental disorder.Â  Powell
    v. Vulcan Materials Co., 299
  S.C. 325, 384 S.E.2d 725 (1989).Â  This standard, also known
  as the â€œheart attack standard,â€ balances the employeeâ€™s interests with the
  employerâ€™s interests and provides a framework which ensures that the claimant
  shows that she suffered a work-related injury.Â  Requiring a claimant to prove
  exposure to â€œunusual or extraordinaryâ€ circumstances in a mental-mental injury
  claim is consistent with the heightened burden required to prove a claim for
  intentional infliction of emotional distress claims, a cause of action that
  also allows recovery for mental injuries in the absence of physical injury.Â  See
    Hasson v. Scalise Builders of South Carolina, 374
  S.C. 352, 356, 650 S.E.2d 68, 71 (2007),
  quoting Ford v. Hutson, 276 S.C. 157, 166, 276 S.E.2d
  776, 780 (1981) (recognizing that â€œwhere
  physical harm is lacking, the courts should look initially for more in the way
  of extreme outrage as an assurance that the mental disturbance claimed is not
  fictitiousâ€).
In the instant
  case, Petitioner alleges that the aidesâ€™ insubordination created the unusual
  and extraordinary conditions, which caused her panic attack.Â  Petitioner testified that the aides would walk out of the
  classroom and refused to escort the children to the bathroom and that several
  of her students regressed in their progress as a result of the aidesâ€™ actions.Â 
  She also testified that she reported her concerns to her supervisor, but the
  supervisor sided with the aides and would not help her.Â  
We
  find substantial evidence in the record supports the full commissionâ€™s findings.Â 
  Although the conflict may have been stressful, it was not an unusual or
  extraordinary circumstance of Petitionerâ€™s employment.Â  Neither the aides nor Petitionerâ€™s
  supervisor threatened her, and the conflict never involved physical contact.Â  Petitioner
  admits that a special education teacher is an inherently stressful job, and Social
  Worker conceded that a panic attack may be triggered absent unusual or
  extraordinary circumstances.Â  Additionally, Petitionerâ€™s supervisor testified
  that conflicts
  like the one between Petitioner and the aides were not unusual.Â  In
  our view, cases
  in which the Court has found unusual and extraordinary circumstances that
  resulted in a mental injury involve much more extreme and severe facts.Â  See Shealy v. Aiken County, 341
  S.C. 448, 455, 535 S.E.2d 438, 442 (2000)
  (finding the combination of death threats, gun incidents with
  violent drug dealers, high tension confrontations, fear of being uncovered, and
  loss of security as a police officer constituted unusual or extraordinary
  conditions of employment when they occur over several months); Stokes v. First Nat. Bank, 306
  S.C. 46, 50, 410 S.E.2d 248, 250 (1991)
  (concluding that the extreme prolonged increase in employeeâ€™s
  work hours, combined with additional job responsibilities, constituted unusual
  and extraordinary conditions of employment); Powell, 299 S.C. at 328,
  384 S.E.2d at 727 (holding that an intense verbal exchange between the employee
  and the supervisor constituted unusual and extraordinary condition of
  employeeâ€™s work). Â 
Accordingly, we hold that substantial evidence in the record
  exists to support the commissionâ€™s decision that Petitioner failed to meet her burden that she suffered a
  compensable injury.
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, we affirm the court of appealsâ€™
  decision upholding the denial of benefits.Â  
WALLER,
  PLEICONES, BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

IN THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        In the Matter of James W.
          Fayssoux, Respondent.
      
    
  


Opinion No. 26617
Submitted February 6, 2009 - Filed March 23, 2009Â Â  

PUBLIC REPRIMAND


  
    
      
        Lesley M.
          Coggiola, Disciplinary Counsel, of Columbia, for Office of Disciplinary
          Counsel. 
        James W.
          Fayssoux, of Greenville, pro se.Â  
      
    
  


PER
  CURIAM:Â Â  In this attorney disciplinary
  matter, respondent and the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) have entered
  into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule
  413, SCACR.Â  In the Agreement, respondent admits misconduct and consents to the
  imposition of an admonition, a public reprimand, or the imposition of a definite
  suspension not to exceed sixty (60) days.Â  We accept the Agreement and impose a
  public reprimand.Â  The facts, as set forth in the Agreement, are as follows.Â  
FACTS
Respondent
  self-reported to ODC that he, along with several other lawyers, numerous
  non-lawyers, and several business entities had been named as defendants in
  civil litigation initiated by a lender.Â  Respondentâ€™s errors and omissions
  carrier settled the litigation by paying damages in an agreed amount of $35,000
to the lender.Â  
It is
  now known that, as a result of a federal investigation, James Byrd, Eric Byrd,
  and their related business associates and/or entities entered into schemes to
  acquire and then sell real estate at inflated values to the detriment of the
  purchasers and to a lender who made loans to those purchasers.Â  Due to those
  schemes, the lender made loans to persons it would not have otherwise approved.Â 
  Further, the lender made loans contrary to its policies and procedures and in
  amounts in excess of its lending policies and procedures which it had in place
  to promote timely repayment and to prevent default upon its loans secured by
  real estate mortgages.Â  Subsequently, both the Byrds and others were indicted
and sentenced to terms in federal prison for wire, mail, and/or bank fraud.Â  
Respondent
  represents that he was unaware of any criminal activity in connection with any
  of the real estate transactions he handled that were arranged by the Byrds.Â 
  ODC does not dispute this representation.Â  Further, respondent represents that
  he does not believe that his activities constituted criminal acts and ODC does
not dispute this representation.[1]Â  
However,
  twenty-eight (28) real estate closings which were handled by respondent as
  arranged by one or both of the Byrds revealed irregularities that ODC contends
  constitute lawyer misconduct on the part of respondent.Â  With the advantage of
  information revealed by hindsight and the investigation by the federal
authorities and ODC, respondent agrees with ODCâ€™s contention.Â  
In one
  transaction, respondent wrote a check on his trust account payable to Vision
  Enterprises, an entity known by respondent to be owned and/or controlled by one
  or more of the Byrds.Â  The check was for the exact amount due to the seller
  Eric Byrd on a related HUD-1 Settlement Statement prepared by respondent.Â  As a
  result, the information furnished to the borrower and lender on the HUD-1
contained incorrect information.Â  
 In
  another transaction, Vision Enterprises placed an $18,000 mechanics lien
  against real property acquired by James Byrd who then sold the same property
  the next day, paying the mechanics lien out of the proceeds of that sale.Â 
  Respondent prepared the closing papers and made the disbursements.Â  It is now
  recognized that Byrd, through his colleagueâ€™s placement of the mechanics lien,
  actually placed the mechanics lien against himself and then paid it out of the
  proceeds of the sale to a borrower and a loan made by the lender, even though
  little or no repairs were made to the property.Â  ODC contends respondent should
  have recognized this was a sham mechanics lien because it was placed on
  property by an entity or person known to respondent to be a Byrd confidant the
very day before Byrd and/or a Byrd-controlled entity sold the property.Â  
In
  several other Byrd-arranged closings, the HUD-1s prepared by or at the
  direction of respondent showed money being withheld for repairs.Â  It is now
  known that little, if any, such repairs warranting the amount withheld were
  actually made.Â  Respondent withheld the funds and paid them over to one or more
  of the Byrds and/or one or more entities controlled by or having a very close
  working relationship with the Byrds.Â  In retrospect, respondent now recognizes
  that, as a result, both borrowers and lenders were acquiring interest in real
  property at inflated values and/or there was greater consideration begin
  received by the seller than reflected on the corresponding HUD-1s prepared by
respondent.Â  
In three
  other transactions, respondentâ€™s firmâ€™s pension and profit sharing plan
  provided loans in Byrd-arranged transactions (and then sold those properties
  for a profit).Â  By participating in the transactions, respondent had business
  dealings with a client without complying with the requirements of the Rules of
Professional Conduct. 
Further,
  the properties were sold to Byrd under financing to the pension and profit
  sharing plan (secured by notes and mortgages to that plan from Byrd or Byrd-controlled
  entities).Â  Respondent prepared the closing documents in these transactions and
  then handled the closings when Byrd sold these three properties to borrowers.Â 
  Monies from these transactions were applied toward the notes and mortgages, but
  no mention of the monies being paid to the pension and profit sharing plan of
  respondentâ€™s firm were made on the borrowersâ€™ HUD-1s.Â  By omitting the
  information from the HUD-1s, the information given to the lender and borrowers
  was not entirely correct.Â  Further, respondent issued title insurance policies
  that did not make exception to the mortgages, notwithstanding the fact that the
  mortgages were publicly recorded.Â  These three transactions were the subject of
  the civil litigation against respondent and the federal indictments against the
Byrds and others.Â  Â Â 
In
  another transaction, Eric Byrd was the seller and another Byrd business
  associate was the buyer in the arrangement.Â  Â Â Respondent was aware of the
  relationship between the seller and buyer and closed the transaction.Â  Line 201
  on the HUD-1 Settlement Statement (earnest money paid by borrowers) states that
  $12,000 was paid as earnest money by the borrower when, in fact, no such amount
  was received by respondent into his firmâ€™s trust account and no notation â€œPOCâ€
  (paid outside of closing) was made on that line.Â  As a result, the receipts and
  disbursements made out of respondentâ€™s trust account were not consistent with
the information on the HUD-1.Â  
In
  several other matters closed by respondent, James Byrd purchased transactions
  as refinancings which allowed Byrd to circumvent the lenderâ€™s guidelines, procedures,
  and policies applicable to purchase transactions to avoid the lender making
  loans on property at inflated amounts.Â  In furtherance of this scheme, a
  Byrd-controlled land trust served as a straw buyer giving a note and mortgage.Â 
  Respondent was aware that the land trust was a Byrd-related and controlled
  entity.Â  In hindsight, respondent acknowledges the peculiarities of these
  transactions should have served as â€œred flagsâ€ that improprieties were being
committed in connection with these real estate transactions.Â  
Another
  Byrd scheme was to make fictitious notes and mortgages from Byrd cohorts as
  â€œborrowersâ€ to Next Generation (an entity known at the time by respondent to be
  Byrd-controlled). Â While respondent did not draft these notes and mortgages, in
  some cases they were drawn and recorded the day before respondent conducted the
  closings on the encumbered property sold to genuine borrowers.Â  Respondent
  should have seen additional â€œred flagsâ€ when Byrd left the closing with a check
  made to the lender, especially when a known Byrd family member was the
borrower.Â  
Respondent
  represents that all checks exchanged during these transactions were honored
  upon presentment.Â  ODC does not dispute this representation.Â  However, it is
  now known that personal checks which were brought to closings handled by
  respondent in some of the transactions by the Byrds or their associates would
  only be made good out of the proceeds of the ultimate, inflated sales of the
subject property.Â  
Toward
  the end of their relationship, respondent began having concerns about the
  propriety of the Byrdsâ€™ transactions.Â  Around the same time, one of the Byrds
  asked respondent to assist in â€œflipâ€ transactions; respondent recognized participating
  in a â€œflipâ€ transaction would constitute misconduct.Â  Respondent ceased closing
transactions for the Byrds.
Respondent
  has been engaged in the practice of law since 1972.Â  He has no prior
  disciplinary history.Â  He has fully cooperated with ODCâ€™s inquiries into this
matter.Â  
LAW
Respondent admits that
  his misconduct constitutes grounds for discipline under Rule 413, RLDE,
  specifically Rule 7(a)(1) (lawyer shall not violate Rules of Professional
  Conduct or any other rules of this jurisdiction regarding professional conduct
  of lawyers).Â  In addition, respondent admits he has violated the following
  provisions of the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR: Â Rule 1.1 (lawyer shall provide
  competent representation to a client); Rule 1.7(a) (lawyer shall not represent
  client if representation involves concurrent conflict of interest); Rule 1.8(a)
  (lawyer shall not enter into business transaction with client or knowingly
  acquire a pecuniary or security interest adverse to a client unless certain
  conditions are met); Rule 4.1(a) (in course of representing client, lawyer
  shall not make false statement of material fact to a third person); Rule 8.4(a) (it is professional misconduct for lawyer
    to violate the Rules of Professional Conduct); Rule 8.4(d) (it is professional
    misconduct for lawyer to engage in conduct involving dishonesty, fraud, or
    misrepresentation); and Rule 8.4(e) (it is professional misconduct for lawyer
    to engage in conduct that is prejudicial to the administration of justice).Â  
CONCLUSION
The misconduct reported in this opinion would
  normally warrant the imposition of a suspension from the practice of law.Â 
  However, because respondent self-reported his misconduct to ODC, fully
  cooperated with the disciplinary investigation, and has served the Bar of this
  State for more than thirty years with no prior disciplinary history, we find
  that a public reprimand is warranted.Â  Accordingly, we accept the Agreement for
  Discipline by Consent and publicly reprimand respondent for his misconduct
PUBLIC REPRIMAND.
TOAL, C.J., WALLER, PLEICONES, BEATTY
and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

[1] Respondent was not charged with any criminal
  activity in connection with the transactions reported in this opinion and
neither respondent nor ODC expect any charges to be filed in the future.Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Donald D.
          Berry, Petitioner,
        v.
        State of South Carolina, Respondent.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal From Cherokee County
  Doyet A. Early, III, Post-Conviction
Relief Judge

Opinion No. 26618
  Submitted November 19, 2008 - Filed March
23, 2009

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
        Deputy
          Chief Appellate Defender Wanda H. Carter, of South Carolina Commission on
          Indigent Defense, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
        Attorney
          General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
          Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General S.
          Prentiss Counts, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE KITTREDGE:Â Â Â Â Â  We granted a writ of certiorari
  to review the denial of Donald
  D. Berryâ€™s application for post-conviction relief (PCR).Â  Berry pled guilty to
  a drug charge, second offense, and was sentenced to prison.Â  The prior offense
  for enhancement purposes was a drug paraphernalia conviction.Â  Because a drug
  paraphernalia conviction does not qualify as a prior offense for enhancement
  purposes under South Carolinaâ€™s statutory scheme and plea counsel neither informed
  Berry of this fact nor made an objection in the plea court, we reverse the
  denial of PCR, vacate the guilty plea, and remand to the general sessions
  court.
I.
Berry pled guilty to manufacturing methamphetamine, second
  offense, and was sentenced to seven yearsâ€™ imprisonment.Â  The plea was enhanced
  to a second offense by Berryâ€™s prior conviction for possession of drug
  paraphernalia.Â  As part of the plea agreement, an accompanying possession with
  intent to distribute methamphetamine charge was dismissed.Â  The PCR court found
  Berry did not establish his entitlement to relief and denied his application.Â 
  Berry sought a writ of certiorari, which we granted.
Section
  44-53-470 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2007) states, â€œ[a]n offense is
  considered a second or subsequent offense if . . . the offender has been
  convicted within the previous ten years of a violation of a provision of this
  article or of another state or federal statute relating to narcotic drugs,
  marijuana, depressants, stimulants, or hallucinogenic drugs . . . .â€Â 
  Additionally, section 44-53-375(B)(2) of the South Carolina Code (Supp.
  2007) provides the following requirements for an enhanced offense:

  [F]or a second offense or if, in the case of a first conviction of
    a violation of this section, the offender has been convicted of any of the laws
    of the United States or of any state, territory, or district relating to
    narcotic drugs, marijuana, depressant, stimulant, or hallucinogenic drugs, the
    offender must be imprisoned for not less than five years nor more than thirty
    years, or fined not more than fifty thousand dollars, or both.

II.
Whether
  a drug paraphernalia conviction qualifies as a prior offense for enhancement
  purposes has not been decided by this Court.Â  The question is one of statutory
  construction. Â See State
    v. Dingle, 376 S.C. 643, 649, 659
  S.E.2d 101, 105 (2008) (â€œIn interpreting statutes, the Court looks to the plain
  meaning of the statute and the intent of the Legislature.â€). Â Moreover, in construing a criminal statute, we are guided by the
  rule of lenityâ€”the principle that any ambiguity must be resolved in favor of
  the accused. Â State v. Blackmon, 304 S.C. 270, 273, 403
  S.E.2d 660, 662 (1991) (â€œ[W]hen a statute is penal in nature, it must be
  construed strictly against the State and in favor of the defendant.â€).Â  We hold that the Legislature intended a prior
  offense to qualify for enhancement purposes only if the prior offense â€œrelates
  toâ€ one of the statutorily enumerated drugs.
To
  construe a paraphernalia conviction as â€œrelating toâ€ drugs would be contrary to
  unambiguously expressed legislative intent and additionally violate the rule of
  lenity long established in our jurisprudence.Â  Moreover, were we to construe
  the phrase â€œrelate toâ€ so loosely as to include a paraphernalia conviction,
  there would essentially be no limitation for qualifying enhancement offenses.Â 
  We therefore hold that a conviction for possession of drug paraphernalia may not be used for enhancement purposes as it does
  not â€œrelate toâ€ drugs as statutorily mandated.
III.
Ineffective Assistance of Counsel
We now
  turn to Berryâ€™s PCR claim of ineffective assistance of counsel.Â  To establish a
  claim of ineffective assistance of counsel under the Sixth Amendment, a PCR
  applicant must prove deficient representation and resulting prejudice. Â Strickland v. Washington, 466 U.S. 668, 687 (1984).
Where
  a defendant pleads guilty upon the advice of counsel, post-conviction relief is
  available only when the applicant proves the advice he received from counsel
  â€œfell below an objective standard of reasonablenessâ€ and that â€œbut forâ€ counselâ€™s
  deficient representation, he would not have pled guilty.Â  Hill v. Lockhart,
  474 U.S. 52, 56-59 (1985). Â Plea counsel for Berry acknowledges he neither
  challenged the Stateâ€™s reliance on the paraphernalia conviction for enhancement
  purposes, nor informed Berry of the potential challenge.
A. Deficient Representation
We
  find plea counselâ€™s failure to inform Berry of the potential challenge of the
  use of the paraphernalia conviction for enhancement purposes amounts to deficient
  representation.Â  Strickland v. Washington, 466 U.S. at 687.Â  In so ruling, we recognize that a defendant, for a host of legitimate reasons, may
  plead guilty to an offense for which a valid legal challenge may exist.Â  See
    Rollison v. State, 346 S.C. 506, 510, 552 S.E.2d 290, 292 (2001) (â€œA
  defendant may, as part of a plea bargain, agree to plead guilty to a crime for
  which he has been indicted (or to which he has waived grand jury presentment),
  but of which he is not guilty.â€); Anderson v. State, 342 S.C. 54, 58,
  535 S.E.2d 649, 651 (2000) (â€œWe find
  the decision to accept a plea to voluntary manslaughter notwithstanding the
  lack of any provocation was simply a tactical maneuver to avoid the very real
  possibility that the jury might come back with a verdict of murder.Â  Accordingly, we find the plea was knowingly and voluntarily
  entered.â€).Â  The difference in such circumstances between a valid guilty
  plea and an invalid guilty plea lies in the knowing and voluntary nature of the
  plea.Â  Here, counsel never informed Berry of the potential challenge to the use
  of the drug paraphernalia conviction for enhancement.Â  In fact, Berryâ€™s plea counsel never gave any thought to the issue.
We
  believe the Sixth Amendment guarantee of effective assistance of counsel requires
  that counsel accurately inform a defendant, to the extent possible, of the
  qualifying nature of a prior offense for enhancement purposes.Â  It may well be
  that in situations unlike the one before us, the answer is unclear.Â  Yet, an
  accused is entitled to counselâ€™s considered and reasonable judgment.[1]Â 
  In fact, uncertainty concerning a potential legal challenge may well provide a
  defendant a catalyst in plea negotiations with the State.Â  In this regard, a
  defendant may choose to forgo a legal challenge and opt for what he considers a
  favorable plea arrangement, especially where other charges will be dismissed or
  sentences are run concurrently.
This
  â€œgive and takeâ€ lies at the heart of virtually every guilty plea, as plea
  agreements allow our overly burdened criminal courts to function.Â  The point,
  for purposes of the issue before us, is that such decisions must be made
  knowingly and voluntarily with the advice of constitutionally competent
  counsel.Â  Simply saying â€œI never gave it a thoughtâ€ falls short of the Sixth
  Amendment guarantee of effective assistance of counsel.Â  As a result, we find
  counselâ€™s failure to even consider whether a paraphernalia conviction qualifies
  for enhancement, and so inform Berry, fell below the standard of objective
  reasonableness.Â  We therefore find plea counsel provided constitutionally deficient
  representation.
B.
  Prejudice
We
  next turn to the second step in the analysisâ€”whether Berry was prejudiced by the
  deficient representation.Â  Strickland
    v. Washington, 466 U.S. at 687.Â  As this was a guilty plea, Berry â€œmust show that there
  is a reasonable probability that, but for counselâ€™s errors, he would not have
  pleaded guilty and would have insisted on going to trial.â€Â  Hill, 474 U.S. at 59.Â  During the PCR hearing, Berry repeatedly said that he would have gone to trial
  had he known that his paraphernalia conviction did not qualify as a prior
  offense for enhancement purposes. Â Cf. Robinson v. State, Op. No. 26564
  (S.C.Sup.Ct. filed Nov. 24, 2008) (Shearouse Adv.Sh. No. 43 at 25) (granting
  post-conviction relief and remanding for resentencing where prior uncounseled conviction
  was improperly used for enhancement and applicant insisted that he wanted to
  plead guilty free of the â€œunconstitutional prior conviction[]â€).Â  We find Berry has established the prejudice prong of Strickland v. Washington, and we grant
  him the relief he requests.
IV.
We grant Berry post-conviction relief and return him to his pre-guilty plea position.Â  Berryâ€™s conviction and sentence for manufacturing
  methamphetamine are vacated.Â  Because the accompanying indictment for possession
  with intent to distribute methamphetamine was dismissed as part of the plea
  bargain, it is restored as an active charge.Â  We remand these charges to the general
  sessions court for disposition.
REVERSED AND
  REMANDED.
TOAL, C.J., WALLER,
and BEATTY, JJ., concur. PLEICONES, J., not participating.


[1] While
  the case at hand concerns use of prior convictions for enhancement purposes,
  this reference to an accusedâ€™s entitlement to counselâ€™s considered and
  reasonable judgment clearly has broad application in Sixth Amendment
jurisprudence.

title: Rydde v. Morris
description: This is a legal malpractice case involving the drafting of a will.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Robert A. Rydde and Brandon Konija, Appellants,
        v.
        M. Robin Morris, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Â J. Michael Baxley, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  26619
  Heard February 4, 2009 - Filed March 23,
2009Â  

AFFIRMED 


  
    
      
        Eric S.
          Bland, of Bland Richter, LLP, of Columbia, Ronald L. Richter, Jr., Bland
          Richter, LLP, of Charleston, Thomas A. Pendarvis, of Pendarvis Law Offices, PC,
          of Beaufort, for Appellants.
        Susan
          Taylor Wall, and J.W. Nelson Chandler, both of Parker, Poe, Adams &
          Bernstein, LLP, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE KITTREDGE:Â Â Â Â Â  This
  legal malpractice action presents the following question: whether an attorneyâ€™s
  alleged negligent failure to timely draft a will and arrange for its execution
  permits prospective beneficiaries of the estate to maintain a cause of action
  for legal malpractice.Â  There is no such claim in South Carolina, and we hold
  an attorney owes no duty to a prospective beneficiary of a nonexistent will.Â 
In so ruling, we affirm the trial courtâ€™s dismissal of the action.
I.
Johanna
  W. Knight was an elderly resident of Myrtle Beach, South Carolina, who died on
  October 3, 2005, as a result of lung cancer.Â  Approximately one month prior to
  her death, attorney M. Robin Morris was engaged by Knight to prepare her estate
  plan.Â  Morris provided Knight with an estate planning questionnaire.Â  Knight returned the estate
  planning questionnaire to Morris on Thursday, September 22, 2005.Â  Appellants Robert A. Rydde and Brandon Konija, and others, were included
  as prospective will beneficiaries in the questionnaire completed by Knight.Â  
On
  Tuesday, September 27, 2005, Morris delivered to Knight a portion of the
  requested estate plan documents: a durable healthcare power of attorney and a
  durable financial power of attorney.Â  These documents were not executed.Â 
  Knight was incapacitated on September 28, for she was on a respirator in the
  intensive care unit and was in a drug-induced sleep.Â  As noted, Knight died on
  October 3.
Because a will was not prepared for execution prior to Knightâ€™s
  death, her estate passed through intestacy.Â  Appellants filed this legal malpractice action under various
  theories, all of which are premised on the imposition of a duty on Morris in
  favor of the non-client prospective beneficiaries. Â Morris answered the
  complaint by moving to dismiss pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP.
II.
The learned trial judge
  determined that Appellantsâ€™ complaint failed to â€œstate facts sufficient to
  constitute a cause of action.â€Â  Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP.Â  On appeal from the
  dismissal of a case pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6), an appellate court applies the
  same standard of review as the trial court.Â  Williams v. Condon,
  347 S.C. 227, 233, 553 S.E.2d 496, 500 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  That standard requires
  the Court to construe the complaint in a light most favorable to the nonmovant
  and determine if the â€œfacts alleged and the inferences reasonably deducible
  from the pleadings would entitle the plaintiff to relief on any theory of the
  case.â€Â  Id. at 233, 553 S.E.2d at 499.
III.
Appellants
  assert that attorney Morris owed them a duty to draft a will for Knight (naming
  Appellants as beneficiaries) between Thursday September 22, 2005, and the
  following Tuesday, September 27, which was the day before Knight became
  completely unresponsive. Â Without pause, we reject the notion of imposing a
  duty on an attorney in favor of a prospective beneficiary for the attorneyâ€™s purported
  negligent failure to timely draft a will.
A.
We begin with South Carolina law.Â  A plaintiff in a legal malpractice action must establish four
  elements: (1) the existence of an attorney-client relationship; (2) a breach of
  duty by the attorney; (3) damage to the client; and (4) proximate cause of the
  clientâ€™s damages by the breach.Â  Smith v. Haynsworth, Marion, McKay & Geurard,
  322 S.C. 433, 435 n.2, 472 S.E.2d 612, 613 n.2 (1996); Ellis v. Davidson,
  358 S.C. 509, 523, 595 S.E.2d 817, 824 (Ct. App. 2004); Hall v. Fedor,
  349 S.C. 169, 174, 561 S.E.2d 654, 656 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  â€œBefore a claim for
  malpractice may be asserted, there must exist an attorney-client
  relationship.â€Â  Am. Fed. Bank, FSB v. No. One Main Joint Venture, 321
  S.C. 169, 174, 467 S.E.2d 439, 442 (1996); see also Pye v. Estate of Fox,
  369 S.C. 555, 564, 633 S.E.2d 505, 509 (2006) (â€œ[A]n attorney is immune from
  liability to third persons arising from the performance of his professional
  activities as an attorney on behalf of and with the knowledge of his client.â€
  (quoting Gaar v. N. Myrtle Beach Realty Co., Inc., 287 S.C. 525, 528,
  339 S.E.2d 887, 889 (Ct. App. 1986))).Â  
B.
Our
  decision today not to impose a duty on an attorney in favor of a prospective
  beneficiary for alleged negligent failure to draft a will follows the law in
  other jurisdictions.Â  We find persuasive the reasoning of decisions from New Hampshire, Connecticut, and Florida.Â  We reference these three jurisdictions, for these
  states recognize generally that an attorney owes a duty to a non-client intended
  beneficiary of an executed will where it is shown that the testatorâ€™s intent has
  been defeated or diminished by negligence on the part of the attorney,
  resulting in loss to the beneficiary.Â  Having relaxed the traditional privity requirement
  in legal malpractice claims, these states nevertheless draw the line and refuse
  for compelling policy reasons to permit a malpractice claim by a non-client for
  negligent failure to draft a will. [1]
Â The
  Connecticut Supreme Court was presented with this issue in Krawczyk v.
    Stingle, 543 A.2d 733 (Conn. 1988).Â  While acknowledging its precedent permitting
  a cause of action against an attorney who failed to draft a will in conformity
  with a testatorâ€™s wishes, the Krawczyk court addressed â€œwhether such
  liability should be further expanded to encompass negligent delay in completing
  and furnishing estate planning documents for execution by the client.â€Â  Id. at 735.Â  The Connecticut Supreme Court concluded â€œthat the imposition of
  liability to third parties for negligent delay in the execution of estate
  planning documents would not comport with a lawyerâ€™s duty of undivided loyalty
  to the client.â€Â  Id. at 736.Â  Krawczyk advanced the following
  policy rationale for its decision, with which we concur:

  A central dimension of the attorney-client relationship
    is the attorneyâ€™s duty of â€œ[e]ntire devotion to the interest of the client.â€ Â This
    obligation would be undermined were an attorney to be held liable to third
    parties if, due to the attorneyâ€™s delay, the testator did not have an
    opportunity to execute estate planning documents prior to death.Â  Imposition of
    liability would create an incentive for an attorney to exert pressure on a
    client to complete and execute estate planning documents summarily.Â  Fear of liability
    to potential third party beneficiaries would contravene the attorneyâ€™s primary
    responsibility to ensure that the proposed estate plan effectuates the clientâ€™s
    wishes and that the client understands the available options and the legal and
    practical implications of whatever course of action is ultimately
    chosen.Â  These potential conflicts of interest are especially significant in
    the context of the final disposition of a clientâ€™s estate, where the testatorâ€™s
    testamentary capacity and the absence of undue influence are often central
    issues.Â  

Id. (internal citations omitted).
In Sisson
  v. Jankowski, 809 A.2d 1265 (N.H. 2002), the New Hampshire Supreme Court answered
  a certified question from the United States District Court for the District of New
  Hampshire: â€œ[w]hether . . . an attorneyâ€™s negligent failure to arrange for his
  or her clientâ€™s timely execution of a will . . . which failure proximately
  caused the client to die intestate, gives rise to a viable common law claim
  against that attorney by an intended beneficiary of the unexecuted will.â€Â  Id. at 1265-66.Â  Sisson, relying on Krawczyk and other authorities,
  answered the question in the negative.Â  By focusing on â€œthe importance of an
  attorneyâ€™s undivided loyalty to a client,â€ the Sisson analysis mirrors
  the self-evident policy considerations discussed in Krawczyk.Â Â  

  [W]e
    conclude that the risk of interfering with the attorneyâ€™s duty of undivided
    loyalty to the client exceeds the risk of harm to the prospective beneficiary.Â 
    For these reasons, we join the majority of courts that have considered this
    issue and hold that an attorney does not owe a duty of care to a prospective
    will beneficiary to have the will executed promptly.

Id. at 1270.
We
  next turn to a Florida Court of Appeals case, Babcock v. Malone, 760
  So.2d 1056 (Fla. Dist. Ct. App. 2000). Â Babcock and others filed a lawsuit
  alleging that their uncleâ€™s lawyer was â€œnegligent in failing to timely prepare
  a new will for [him].Â  As a result, their uncle died before executing the new
  will under which [Babcock and the others] would have inherited, and instead
  they were left nothing.â€Â  Id. at 1056.Â  The trial court dismissed the
  lawsuit for failure to state a cause of action.Â  Babcock focused on the
  absence of an executed will and rejected the legal malpractice claim, noting
  the â€œrisk of misinterpreting the testatorâ€™s intentâ€ and the â€œheighten[ed] . . .
  tendency to manufacture false evidence that cannot be rebutted due to the
  unavailability of the testator.â€Â  Id. at 1057 (quoting Espinosa v.
    Sparber, Shevin, Shapo, Rosen & Heilbronner, 612 So.2d 1378, 1380 (Fla. 1993)). Â 
C.
And
  finally, this Courtâ€™s recent recognition of a physicianâ€™s limited duty to third
  parties lends Appellants no support.Â  In Hardee v. Bio-Medical Applications
    of S.C., Inc., 370 S.C. 511, 636 S.E.2d 629 (2006), a physician failed to
  warn a patient of the ill effects that could result from dialysis treatment.Â 
  While driving home following the dialysis treatment, the patient lost control
  of his vehicle and collided with a vehicle in which Allene and Kathleen Hardee
  were traveling.Â  The Hardees filed a tort action against the physician for
  failure to provide appropriate warnings to the patient.Â  
We
  reversed the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment to the physician and noted
  that â€œa medical provider has a duty to warn [the patient] of the dangers
  associated with medical treatment.â€ Â Id. at 516, 636 S.E.2d at 631.Â 
  Based on the duty to warn the patient, we held that â€œa medical provider who
  provides treatment which it knows may have detrimental effects on a patientâ€™s
  capacities and abilities owes a duty to prevent harm to patients and to
  reasonably foreseeable third parties by warning the patient of the attendant
  risks and effects before administering the treatment.â€Â  Id. at 516, 636
  S.E.2d at 631-32.Â  Appellants misapprehend the reach of Hardee.
The
  central feature in Hardeeâ€™s â€œvery narrow holdingâ€ is the recognition
  that â€œthis duty owed to third parties is identical to the duty owed to the
  patient.â€ Id. at 516, 636 S.E.2d at 632. Â Thus, a medical providerâ€™s
  breach of a potential duty to reasonably foreseeable third parties is
  inextricably connected to a breach of duty to the patient.Â  We stressed that
  â€œour holding does not hamper the doctor-patient relationship.â€Â  Id. at 516, 636 S.E.2d at 632.
Hardee lends Appellants no aid.Â  The imposition of a duty on
  an attorney to a prospective beneficiary of a nonexistent will would wreak
  havoc on the attorneyâ€™s ethical duty of undivided loyalty to the client and
  force an impermissible wedge in the attorney-client relationship. Â The
  rationale and policy underpinnings of Hardee support our rejection of
  the duty Appellants seek to impose. 
IV.
In
  sum, under the circumstances presented, we see no reason to depart from
  existing law which imposes a privity requirement as a condition to maintaining
  a legal malpractice claim in South Carolina.Â  We hold an attorney owes no duty
  to a prospective beneficiary of a nonexistent will.Â  The judgment of the trial
  court is
AFFIRMED.
TOAL,
C.J., WALLER, PLEICONES and BEATTY, JJ., concur.


[1] While Connecticut, New Hampshire, and Florida all recognize that a non-client may maintain a legal malpractice claim under
  certain circumstances, these states follow different approaches.Â  These states,
  however, are uniform in their rejection of a claim by a non-client for alleged
  negligence for the failure to draft a will.Â  For an in depth analysis of the
  different approaches in the Nation, see Max. N. Pickelsimer, Comment, Attorney
    Malpractice in Will Drafting: Will South Carolina Expand Privity to Impose a
    Duty to Intended Beneficiaries of a Will?, 58 S.C. L. Rev. 581, 585-98 (2007).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Samuel Brownlee
      and Richard Jolly, Respondents,
				v.
				South Carolina
      Department of Health and Environmental Control, Petitioner.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF
  APPEALS

Appeal From Charleston County
Â Mikell R. Scarborough, Circuit Court
  Judge
Opinion No.Â  26620
Heard January 22, 2009 - Filed March 30,
  2009Â  
REVERSED


	
		
			
				General
  Counsel Carlisle Roberts, Jr. and Staff Attorney Sara P. Bazemore, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
				Christopher
  M. Holmes, of Mt. Pleasant, for Respondents.
			
		
	


JUSTICE BEATTY:Â  We
  granted the petition of the South Carolina Department of Health and
  Environmental Control (DHEC) for certiorari to review the decision in Brownlee
    v. South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control, 372 S.C.
  119, 641 S.E.2d 45 (Ct. App. 2007).Â  In Brownlee, the South Carolina
  Court of Appeals reversed a circuit court order affirming the denial of dock
  permits to Samuel Brownlee and Richard Jolly (Landowners) by DHECâ€™s Office of
  Ocean and Coastal Resource Management (OCRM).Â  We reverse, finding DHEC properly
  denied the permit requests. 
I.Â  FACTS
Landowners
  have property on Johns Island that is adjacent to an unnamed tributary of the Bohicket River in Charleston County, South Carolina.Â  Landowners brought this action against
  DHEC after it denied their requests for construction permits to extend their
  docks across the tributary to the Bohicket River.Â  Landowners asserted the
  location of a dock owned by a neighbor, Lawrence Atkinson, was situated near
  the mouth of the tributary in a manner that made the water no longer
  navigable.Â Â Â  
DHEC
  denied the permits on the basis it would be contrary to existing regulations to
  allow the docks to cross the tributary.Â  Specifically, after DHEC staff
  conducted a boat trip in the area, DHEC determined the tributary was navigable
  and that construction of the docks would violate the regulatory prohibition on
  crossing navigable creeks.Â  DHEC advised the Landowners of its decision in
  letters sent in April 2002:

	OCRM staff [DHEC] has determined that authorizing the
  dock extension would be counter to Regulations.Â  OCRM Regulations specifically
  state, â€œdocks shall not impede navigation and they can only extend to the first
  navigable creek as evidenced by a significant change in grade.â€Â  OCRM staff
  performed a boat trip and found that the creek exhibits significant width (50′)
  and change in grade at your dock that exudes the very nature of a waterbody
  that is navigable.Â  Furthermore, the creek has an established history of public
  use as evidenced by the 4 docks that currently access this creek.Â  

DHEC relied upon several provisions,
  including former 23A S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 30-12(A)(2)(n) (Supp. 2001),[1] in support of the denial of Landownersâ€™ applications.Â  This regulation has
  since been amended, but the former version relied upon by DHEC at the time the
  permit applications were considered is controlling for purposes of this appeal.[2] 
Upon review, an
  administrative law judge[3] (ALJ) ordered DHEC to issue the permits.Â  The ALJ noted that â€œ[a] creek is not
  navigable unless the waterway has the capacity for â€˜valuable floatage,â€™â€ and
  the test is not whether it is accessible at all times, but whether it is
  accessible at the ordinary stage of the water.â€Â  He stated that â€œthe area of
  the tributary in front of [Landownersâ€™] property is currently a defined
  channel, as evidenced by a significant change in grade with the surrounding
  marsh.â€Â  However, he â€œconclude[d] that in order for a waterway to be legally
  navigable under Regulation 30-12A(2)(n), the navigation of the waterway must
  not be so impeded as to create a frequent hazard.â€Â  
The
  ALJ stated the waterway was not navigable and explained â€œthe determination that
  the tributary is not navigable is due to a man-made impediment.Â  If the
  Atkinson dock is removed from its location in the mouth of the tributary, theÂ 
  impediment would no longer exist and the tributary would be a navigable
  stream.â€Â  The ALJ reversed DHECâ€™s decision and remanded the case for DHEC to
  either have the Atkinson dock removed from its current location and built as
  permitted[4] or to approve Landownersâ€™ applications.Â  
Upon motion, the ALJ amended his order â€œto clarify [his] conclusionsâ€ as follows:Â  

	Though
  the waters of the tributary in front of the [Landownersâ€™] property are
    navigable, the waterway itself is not navigable because the mouth of the
      tributary cannot safely be entered at the ordinary stages of the tide.Â 
  This case presents exceptional facts because the safety of the navigation
  varies depending upon the winds, tide, currents, etc.Â  [Emphasis added.]Â  

In this amended order, the
  ALJ ordered DHEC to grant outright Landownersâ€™ permit applications to extend
  their docks to the Bohicket River.Â  
The
  Coastal Zone Management Appellate Panel (the Appellate Panel) reversed the ALJ
  and reinstated the denial of the permits, finding the ALJ had erred in several
  conclusions of law.Â  Specifically, the Appellate Panel found the ALJ â€œerred in
  his interpretation of 23A S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 30-12(A)(2)(n), where he
  concludes in Conclusion of Law Number 6, that â€˜in order for a waterway to be
  legally navigable . . . , the navigation of the waterway must not be so impeded
  as to create a frequent hazard.â€™â€Â  In addition, the panel found the ALJ
  committed â€œreversible error in Conclusion of Law Number 4, specifically:Â  â€˜the
  facts establish that the mouth of the tributary cannot be consistently
  navigated safely at the ordinary stages of the tides because of the Atkinson
  dock.Â  Therefore, I find that it currently is not a navigable waterway.â€™â€Â Â Â  
The
  circuit court affirmed the Appellate Panel.Â  The circuit court stated the
  â€œcentral issueâ€ in this case â€œconcerns an interpretation of state law that
  limits the circumstances under which docks may be constructed across navigable
  waterways, specifically the interpretation of . . . Reg. 30-12 . . . .â€Â  The
  circuit court concluded that the Appellate Panel acted â€œwithin the scope of
  [its] authority by setting forth [its] own interpretation of the regulationsâ€
  and â€œagree[d] with [its] interpretation that Reg. 30-12 prohibits the crossing
  of navigable waterways unless there is an obstruction, which prohibits
  navigation at most stages of the tide cycle.â€Â  
Upon
  further review, the South Carolina Court of Appeals reversed in a split
  decision.Â  The majority found the ALJ had not committed an error of law and his
  factual findings were supported by substantial evidence and should be upheld
  under the applicable standard of review.Â  Brownlee, 372 S.C. at 126, 641
  S.E.2d at 48.Â  In particular, the majority held the Appellate Panelâ€™s
  determination that the ALJ had misinterpreted what constitutes a navigable
  waterway under Regulation 30-12(A)(2)(n) was in error.Â  Id.Â  
The
  dissent, in contrast, agreed with the Appellate Panelâ€™s determination that the
  ALJ erred in his interpretation of what legally constitutes a navigable
  waterway.Â  The dissent noted that the ALJ had expressly found the tributary was
  navigable, but the ALJ had, nevertheless, concluded that because navigation at
  the mouth of the tributary was impeded by the Atkinson dock, the tributary was
  rendered nonnavigable.Â  Id. at 133, 641 S.E.2d at 52 (Goolsby, J.,
  dissenting).Â  The dissent contended that â€œ[t]he mere fact that an artificial
  structure, such as Atkinsonâ€™s dock, impedes navigation, does not make the
  waterway nonnavigableâ€ and that there was â€œno compelling reason to reverse the
  agencyâ€™s interpretation of its own regulation.â€Â  Id. at 134, 641 S.E.2d
  at 52.Â  This Court granted DHECâ€™s request for a writ of certiorari.
II.Â  ISSUES
On
  certiorari, DHEC contends the Court of Appeals erred in evaluating the legal
  standard for navigability in this case as a question of fact rather than a
  question of law.Â  DHEC also contends the Appellate Panelâ€™s interpretation of
  its regulation should be awarded deference and upheld.Â  

III. Â LAW/ANALYSIS
A.Â  Standard of Review
This case involved
  multiple levels of review.Â  Under the Administrative Procedures Act, the ALJ
  presided as the fact finder in this matter.Â  Brown v. South Carolina Depâ€™t
    of Health & Envtl. Control, 348 S.C. 507, 560 S.E.2d 410 (2002).Â  The
  proceeding before the ALJ was in the nature of a de novo hearing, including the
  presentation of evidence and testimony.Â  Id.Â  Under the review procedure
  in effect at the time, the Appellate Panel was authorized to reverse the ALJ
  based on an error of law or if his findings were not supported by substantial
  evidence.[5]Â  See Dorman v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control,
  350 S.C. 159, 565 S.E.2d 119 (Ct. App. 2002).
â€œCourts defer to
  the relevant administrative agencyâ€™s decisions with respect to its own
  regulations unless there is a compelling reason to differ.â€Â  South Carolina Coastal Conservation League v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl.
    Control, 363 S.C. 67, 75, 610 S.E.2d 482, 486 (2005); see also Brown
      v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 354 S.C. 436, 440, 591 S.E.2d 836, 838 (2003) (â€œWe
  recognize the Court generally gives deference to an administrative agencyâ€™s
  interpretation of an applicable statute or its own regulation.â€).
B.Â  Navigability
DHEC argues the
  Court of Appeals erred in evaluating navigability as a question of fact because
  DHEC does not challenge the facts in this case, but rather, the legal standard
  applied by the ALJ.Â  DHEC asserts:Â  â€œ[T]he ALJ developed a test which provides
  that a waterbody is not navigable when challenges to easy and safe navigation
  exist.Â  In contrast, the [Appellate] Panel determined that pursuant to the
  legal test of navigability, a waterbody is navigable despite certain challenges
  to navigability.Â  That fundamentally is a dispute as to the appropriate legal
  standard, and not a dispute of facts.â€Â  DHEC contends â€œ[t]he [Appellate] Panel
  interpreted regulation 30-12(A)(2)(n) to mean that some impairment does not
  render a waterbody nonnavigable. . . .Â  In practical terms, every dock creates
  some impairment to navigation, yet that does not render the waterbody nonnavigable.â€Â Â Â  
DHEC
  further contends that â€œunder the ALJâ€™s test of navigability which considers
  wind, currents and safety, the frequent small craft advisories issued . . . on
  windy days would potentially result in [waterways] being deemed [nonnavigable]
  at times and ultimately destroy the navigable status of [waterways] containing
  â€˜unsafeâ€™ conditions.â€Â  DHEC argues the Court of Appeals erred in viewing the
  appeal as a dispute of fact rather than a challenge to the correct legal
  standard.Â  
In
  this case, the Court of Appeals stated the question of navigability was a
  question of fact and that the ALJ found those facts adverse to DHEC and these
  findings should be upheld under the applicable standard of review.Â  Although
  navigability may turn on the facts of the case, the determination regarding navigability
  here was influenced by the ALJâ€™s interpretation of the law.Â  The majority
  extensively quoted the ALJâ€™s findings, stating these were factual findings that
  were supported by the evidence.Â  However, the findings and conclusions were
  based on the definition of navigability that was applied and the interpretation
  of a regulation.Â  The ALJ found the tributary in front of Landownersâ€™ property
  was inherently navigable, but concluded the entire tributary had been rendered
  nonnavigable because a neighborâ€™s dock at â€œthe mouth of the channelâ€ created an
  impediment at that point.Â  Although we agree the ALJ is the fact-finder in this
  proceeding, we find that his determination of navigability was based on his
  application of those facts to the law.
Former Regulation
  30-12(A)(2)(n), which was in effect at the time of DHECâ€™s consideration of the
  permit applications, provided that docks could not be built over
  â€œnavigable creeksâ€ in order to access deeper water:Â  

	Docks must extend to the first
  navigable creek with a defined channel as evidenced by a significant change in
  grade with the surrounding marsh.Â  Such creeks cannot be bridged in order to
    obtain access to deeper water.Â  However, pierheads must rest over open
  water and floating docks which rest upon the bottom at normal low tide will not
  normally be permitted.

23A S.C. Code Ann. Regs.
  30-12(A)(2)(n) (Supp. 2001) (emphasis added).
â€œNavigable
  water is a public highway which the public is entitled to use for the purposes
  of travel either for business or pleasure.â€Â  State ex rel. Lyon v. Columbia
    Water Power Co., 82 S.C. 181, 189, 63 S.E. 884, 888 (1909).
Navigable
  water is protected under state law to ensure public access.Â  S.C. Const. art.
  XIV, Â§ 4 (declaring navigable waters to be public highways for which citizens
  are entitled to free access); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 49-1-10 (Supp. 2008) (â€œAll
  streams which have been rendered or can be rendered capable of being navigated
  by rafts of lumber or timber by the removal of accidental obstructions and all
  navigable watercourses and cuts are hereby declared navigable streams and such
  streams shall be common highways and forever free . . . .â€).Â  
In
  determining navigability, â€œ[t]he true test to be applied is whether a stream
  inherently and by its nature has the capacity for valuable floatage,
  irrespective of the fact of actual use or the extent of such use.â€Â  State ex
    rel. Medlock v. South Carolina Coastal Council, 289 S.C. 445, 449, 346
  S.E.2d 716, 719 (1986).Â  â€œValuable floatage is not necessarily commercial
  floatage.â€Â  Id.Â  Commercial use of the waterway is not required for it
  to be navigable; and pleasure traffic is entitled to protection in using the
  waterway.Â  Hughes v. Nelson, 303 S.C. 102, 399 S.E.2d 24 (Ct. App.
  1990). 
â€œValuable
  floatageâ€ is a term that has been used as the standard in this state for many
  years.Â  See Heyward v. Farmersâ€™ Mining Co., 42 S.C. 138, 19 S.E.
  963 (1894) (applying this term).Â  â€œValuable floatageâ€ is not determined by what
  specific size or class of vessel or object can achieve buoyancy in the
  waterway; rather, the term is defined broadly to include any legitimate and
  beneficial use, whether commercial or recreational.Â  Whiteâ€™s Mill Colony,
    Inc. v. Williams, 363 S.C. 117, 125, 609 S.E.2d 811, 815 (Ct. App. 2005).

	As
  we have previously stated:
	
		Section
  49-1-10 of the South Carolina Code does not change the definition of navigable
  waters, but merely emphasizes the law already declared and set out in Heyward
    v. Farmers Mining Company, 42 S.C. 138, 19 S.E. 963 (1894). Â The Court in 
		Heyward rendered a thorough pronouncement of the law of navigability. Â As noted in 
		Heyward, the common law doctrine that the navigability of a stream is to be determined
  by the ebb and flow of the tide was repudiated in South Carolina in the case of 
		State v. Pacific Guano Co., 22 S.C. 50 (1884).
		The Court
  clarified in Heyward v. Farmers Mining Company, 19 S.E. at 971, that neither
    the character of the craft nor the relative ease or difficulty of navigation
    are tests of navigability. Â The surroundings (e.g. marshland) need not be
  such that it may be useful for the purpose of commerce nor that the stream is
  actually being so used. Â The Court points out a distinction between navigable
  waters of the United States and navigable waters of the State. Â In order to be
  navigable under the United States, the water must connect with other water
  highways so as to subject them to the laws of interstate commerce. Â This is not
  a requirement for navigability of waters under the control of the State.
	


    State ex rel. Medlock, 289 S.C. at 449, 346 S.E.2d at 719 (emphasis added).
Access
  at all times is not required for the waters to be navigable.Â  In Hughes v.
    Nelson, the Court of Appeals held a canal was navigable despite the fact
  that, â€œ[a]t certain times of the year, the canal has very little water in it,
  making access difficult.â€Â  Hughes, 303 S.C. at 104, 399 S.E.2d at 25.Â 
  The canal was approximately fifteen feet wide and twelve feet deep and had been
  used by the public for fishing and recreation, but not commercial traffic.Â 
  Nelson blocked the opening to the canal and argued it was not navigable because
  â€œthe canal cannot sustain boat traffic or be fished for certain periods during
  the year because of insufficient depth.â€Â  Id. at 106, 399 S.E.2d at 26.Â  
In
  rejecting the argument the canal was not navigable, the Court of Appeals
  stated:Â  â€œThe test of navigability is not whether a waterway is accessible at
  all times.Â  Rather, the test is whether it is accessible â€˜at the ordinary stage
  of the water.â€™â€Â  Id. (quoting State v. Columbia Water Power Co.,
  82 S.C. 181, 186, 63 S.E. 884, 888 (1909)).
Moreover,
  â€œ[i]n order that the stream or body of water be classed as navigable, it need
  not be navigable in its entirety.â€Â  65 C.J.S. Navigable Waters Â§ 7
  (2000).Â  â€œIn other words, a stream or body of water which is susceptible of
  being used in its ordinary condition as a highway of commerce may be navigable
  regardless of whether it admits the passage of boats at all portions thereof,
  and the general character of a stream as being navigable is not changed by the
  fact that at a particular place it is not in fact navigable by boats.â€Â  Id. Â 
In
  this case, the ALJ specifically stated that â€œthe waters of the tributary in
  front of [Landownersâ€™] property are nagivable,â€ but nevertheless
  concluded that â€œthe waterway itself is not navigable because the mouth of
    the tributary cannot safely be entered at the ordinary stages of the tide.Â 
  This case presents exceptional facts because the safety of the navigation varies
  depending upon the winds, tide, currents, etc.â€Â  [Emphasis added.]Â  The ALJ
  referred to the test for navigability, but added the additional qualification
  that navigation of the waterway must not be so impeded as to create a frequent
  hazard.Â  
The
  fact that the mouth of the tributary has a man-made impediment does not render
  the entire tributary nonnavigable.Â  â€œThe navigability of water does not depend
  on its actual use for navigation, but on its capacity for such use . . . .Â 
  [T]he definition of navigable water embraces, not only that which is actually
  used, but that which is susceptible of use for navigation in its ordinary
  state.â€Â  State ex rel. Lyon, 82 S.C. at 187, 63 S.E. at 888.Â  In State
    ex rel. Lyon, we held that the fact that a waterway ceased to be passable
  because a lock at the Broad River terminus had been so neglected that it could
  not be used did not render the waterway nonnavigable as the waterway was
  capable of navigation up to the lock.Â  Id. 
As
  the dissent noted in the current appeal, the test for navigability does not
  hinge on the existence of man-made impediments or other obstructions, and these
  impediments do not cause the waterway to lose its characterization as
  navigable.[6]Â  See 65 C.J.S. Navigable Waters Â§ 8 (2000) (â€œAs a general rule a
  stream or other body of water is not rendered nonnavigable because of
  occasional difficulties attending navigation.Â  The existence of occasional
  natural obstructions do not destroy the navigability of a river.Â  So, a stream
  may be navigable despite the obstruction of falls, rapids, sand bars, carries,
  or shifting currents.Â  Artificial obstructions which are capable of being
  abated by the due exercise of pubic authority do not prevent a stream from
  being regarded as navigable . . . .â€ (footnotes omitted)); see also State
    v. Head, 330 S.C. 79, 89, 498 S.E.2d 389, 394 (Ct. App. 1997) (â€œ[T]he
  existence of occasional natural obstructions to navigation, such as rapids or
  falls, or the construction of authorized or unauthorized artificial
  obstructions to navigation, such as dams, generally does not change the
  character of an otherwise navigable stream.â€).
The
  ALJâ€™s factual findings are not in dispute in this case, but his conclusions as
  to navigability were based on not only the facts, but also his interpretation
  of the legal test for navigability.Â  See 65 C.J.S. Navigable Waters Â§ 3 (2000) (â€œEach determination as to navigability must rest on the facts and
  circumstances of the particular case.Â  To these facts and circumstances,
  however, certain judicial standards are to be applied for determining whether
  the complex of conditions with respect to the capacity of the water . . .
  renders it a navigable stream.â€).Â  
The
  ALJ essentially found the tributary was navigable but for the Atkinson dock;
  however, our precedent establishes that the entire tributary did not lose its
  navigability merely because there was an impediment that made access at the
  mouth of the tributary where it joined the Bohicket River more difficult.Â  See State v. Head, 330 S.C. at 91, 498 S.E.2d at 395 (holding the judge
  applied an erroneous test of navigability by agreeing that the creek in
  question was navigable except for a â€œstopping pointâ€ such as a dam that
  prevented navigability); see also 78 Am. Jur. 2d Waters Â§ 125
  (2002) (â€œOnce a waterway has been deemed navigable, it remains so; it retains
  its navigable status, even though it is . . . presently incapable of use
  because of changed conditions or the presence of obstructions.â€).Â  Thus, we
  hold the ALJ committed an error of law in assessing navigability in this case
  and that the Court of Appeals decision should be reversed.
C.Â  Atkinson Dock
Finally,
  we note that the Court of Appeals correctly observed in its majority opinion
  that the cause of this entire litigation is the location of the Atkinson dock,
  which has made traversing the mouth of the tributary where it meets the Bohicket River more difficult.Â  Brownlee, 372 S.C. at 128, 641 S.E.2d at 49.Â  As that
  court remarked, â€œThe dock remains to this day in the same place, still impeding
  navigation.â€Â  Id.Â  
We
  believe this is a prime example of an â€œ[a]rtificial obstruction[] which [is]
  capable of being abated by the due exercise of public authority,â€ 65 C.J.S. Navigable
    Waters Â§ 8, and we are bewildered as to why DHEC has allowed the Atkinson
  dock to remain in this location since 1991.Â  After Atkinson built his nonconforming
  dock, he requested an as-built permit, but the request was promptly denied and
  Atkinson was advised that enforcement proceedings would be commenced to require
  the dock to be brought into compliance.Â  Although an administrative order was
  issued on November 22, 1991 directing Atkinson to relocate the dock within
  thirty days, the record on appeal revealed no further action taken in this
  regard.
DHEC
  opined during oral argument that its failure to require compliance could have
  arisen from a general lack of resources, particularly its inability to perform on-site
  inspections for every permit application.Â  However, an on-site inspection was already
  conducted by DHEC in 1991 that revealed the dock was not in compliance.Â  Thus, DHEC
  needed only to follow up on its own directives.Â  After oral argument in this
  matter, DHEC investigated further and subsequently submitted a letter from the
  Coastal Council to Atkinson dated October 27, 1992 advising him that it had
  amended Atkinsonâ€™s permit and had approved the â€œas-builtâ€ dock.Â  No explanation
  is provided as to why Atkinsonâ€™s dock was approved in this manner.Â  We note the
  unnecessary litigation that has been spawned with this case and several others by
  the location of the Atkinson dock constitutes a waste of valuable judicial
  resources.Â  Public funds would have been better spent in enforcing compliance
  rather than engaging in protracted litigation to resolve what is essentially a dispute
  among neighbors.
Section
  49-1-10 of the South Carolina Code declares that obstruction of a stream is a
  â€œnuisance and such obstruction may be abated as other public nuisances are by
  law.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 49-1-10 (Supp. 2008).Â  We strongly believe that equal
  enforcement of the rules and regulations and compliance with the law by all
  parties is absolutely essential to avoiding precisely the problems generated
  here.
IV.Â  CONCLUSION
Based
  on the forgoing, we find the ALJ committed legal error in reversing the
  Appellate Panel and that DHECâ€™s denial of the permit requests should be
  reinstated.Â  However, we urge DHEC to take the proper steps to prevent
  additional unnecessary litigation in this regard.Â  The decision of the Court of
  Appeals is, hereby,

REVERSED. 
TOAL, C.J., and
  KITTREDGE, J., concur. PLEICONES, J., concurring in part, dissenting in part in
  a separate opinion in which WALLER, J., concurs.

JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  I join the majority except as to Part 3 C captioned
  â€œAtkinson Dockâ€ and the second sentence of the Conclusion urging DHEC
  â€œto take proper steps to prevent additional unnecessary litigation.â€ As I read
  this record, we are not asked, nor do we have any basis, to comment upon
  Coastal Councilâ€™s decision to amend the permit and approve the â€œas-builtâ€ dock,
  to scold DHEC, to imply that the dock constitutes a â€œpublic nuisance,â€ or to
  suggest that there has been an unequal enforcement of rules and regulations.Â 
  In my opinion, an appellate court must confine its discussion as narrowly as
  possible solely to the issues properly presented for its consideration.Â  As
  Chief Judge Sanders famously wrote, â€œ[A]ppellate courts in this state . . . .
  do not answer questions they are not asked.â€Â  Langley v. Boyter,
  284 S.C. 162, 325 S.E.2d 250 (Ct. App. 1984) subsequent history omitted. 
WALLER, J., concurs.


[1]Â  Former regulation 30-12(A)(2)(n) provided as
  follows:Â  

	Docks
  must extend to the first navigable creek with a defined channel as evidenced by
  a significant change in grade with the surrounding marsh.Â  Such creeks cannot
  be bridged in order to obtain access to deeper water.Â  However, pierheads must
  rest over open water and floating docks which rest upon the bottom at normal
  low tide will not normally be permitted. 

[2]Â  The current version of this provision, now
  renumbered and denominated as Regulation 30-12(A)(1)(n), states as follows:

	Docks
  must extend to the first navigable creek, within extensions of upland property
  lines or corridor lines, that has a defined channel as evidenced by a
  significant change in grade with the surrounding marsh; or having an
  established history of navigational access or use.Â  Such creeks may only be
    bridged/crossed when there are rare geographic circumstances, such as very
  close proximity of a significantly larger creek within extensions of property
  or corridor lines, [which] may warrant dock extension to a creek other than the
  first navigable creek.Â  A creek with an established history of navigational use
  may also be considered as navigable.Â  In exceptional cases, the Department
  may allow an open water channel to be bridged if current access is
    prohibited by other man made or natural restrictions or if site-specific
  conditions warrant such a crossing.Â Â Â  

23A S.C. Code Ann.
  Regs. 30-12(A)(1)(n) (Supp. 2008) (emphasis added).Â  DHEC notes that under
  either version of the regulation - the one in effect when the permits were
  first considered or the current regulation - DHEC would deny the permit
  applications.Â  Under the current regulation, access must be prohibited by a man-made or natural restriction to warrant an exception, and the parties
  acknowledge that access is not prohibited at this time.Â  Landowners
  argue there was an intervening version of the regulation that allowed a
  navigable creek to be bridged if the creek merely had impeded access, so the
  permits should be granted.Â  However, we find this argument is unavailing as it
  is clear that this prior version, which existed for a limited time, is not
  applicable in this case and it does not mandate granting of the permits, in any
  event. 
[3]Â  The name has since changed to the Administrative Law Court. 
[4]Â  In 1991, as Atkinson was building his dock, the
  South Carolina Coastal Council, the predecessor to DHECâ€™s OCRM, discovered
  through a neighborâ€™s report and an on-site inspection that he was not in
  compliance with the dock permit he had been issued.Â  Atkinson requested
  authorization for construction of the dock â€œas-built.â€Â  By letter dated
  September 4, 1991, DHEC denied the request, finding the location of the dock is
  substantially different from that originally permitted and that it â€œpresents a
  hazard to navigation both in its proximity to the mouth of the tributary and in
  its channelward extension.â€Â  Atkinson was advised in the letter that
  enforcement proceedings would be instituted to bring the dock into compliance.Â 
  On November 22, 1991, the Coastal Council issued an Administrative Order
  finding the Atkinson dock was not in compliance with the permit and instructing
  Atkinson to relocate the dock within thirty days.Â  However, there is no
  indication in the record that any enforcement action was ever taken.Â  At oral
  argument, we asked DHEC for further information about the status of the
  Atkinson dock.Â  DHEC subsequently provided a letter dated October 27, 1992 from
  the Coastal Council to Atkinson advising Atkinson that his â€œpermit has been
  amended to authorize the â€˜as-builtâ€™ dockâ€ and that the amendment closed the
  â€œenforcement fileâ€ in this case.Â  Atkinson was advised, however, that â€œ[t]his
  letter does not relieve you of your responsibility of acquiring any other
  applicable federal or local permits that may be required.â€Â  
[5]Â  The review procedure under the Administrative
  Procedures Act was changed by 2006 South Carolina Laws Act No. 387, which
  eliminated the review of the ALJâ€™s determination by the Appellate Panel.Â  Chem-Nuclear
    Sys. v. South Carolina Bd. of Health & Envtl. Control, 374 S.C. 201,
  648 S.E.2d 601 (2007).Â  However, this appeal continues under the prior
  procedure.
[6]Â  In his original order the ALJ found the tributary
  was navigable at mid-tide and higher and it was possible to easily navigate
  around the Atkinson dock, though the dock presented a hazard:Â  â€œWhile the
  tributary itself can be navigated at mid-tide and higher, the â€˜theadâ€™ of the
  stream goes underneath the Atkinson dock and is an impediment to boaters
  attempting to enter or exit the tributary.Â  Though it is possible to easily
  navigate around the dock, as reflected by the experience of the OCRM staff,
  that ease of navigation is dependent upon unpredictable winds and currents.Â 
  Therefore, I find that the Atkinson dock as it is currently situated presents a
  frequent hazard to safe navigation in and out of the tributary at the ordinary
  tides due to the location of the channel of the tributary under the Atkinson
  dock, the existence of the sand bar/mud flat on the side of the mouth opposite
  the Atkinson dock, and the prevailing winds and currents.â€Â Â

title: Kiriakides v. School District of Greenville County
description: Alex Kiriakides, Jr. and the School District of Greenville County cross appeal from an order that found (1) Kiriakides was not entitled to damages for inverse condemnation and (2) Kiriakides was entitled to statutory attorneys' fees for the School District's abandonment of condemnation proceedings.
