THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Alex
      Kiriakides, III, Mary Ann Kiriakides, and Michael Kiriakides, as Personal
      Representatives of the Estate of Alex Kiriakides, Jr., Appellants/Respondents,
				v.
				The School
      District of Greenville County, South Carolina, a Political Subdivision, Respondent/Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Charles B. Simmons, Jr., Master-in-Equity
Opinion No.Â  26621
Heard December 3, 2008 - Filed March 30,
  2009Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				David
  Lloyd Thomas, of Moore, Taylor & Thomas, of Greenville, and S. Jahue Moore,
  of Moore, Taylor & Thomas, of West Columbia, for Appellants-Respondents.
				Thomas
  W. Traxler and Travis V. Olmert, both of Carter, Smith, Merriam, Rogers &
  Traxler, of Greenville, for Respondent-Appellant.
			
		
	


JUSTICE BEATTY:Â  Alex
  Kiriakides, Jr. (Kiriakides) sued the School District of Greenville County (the
  School District) to prevent it from condemning his property.Â  He also sought
  damages for inverse condemnation for the School Districtâ€™s alleged delay in
  this matter, as well as attorneysâ€™ fees.Â  The master-in-equity found in favor
  of the School District on the condemnation claims, but awarded attorneysâ€™ fees
  to Kiriakides.Â  Kiriakides and the School District filed cross appeals.[1]Â  We affirm.
I.Â  FACTS
Kiriakides owned
  property in Greenville County that was formerly the site of the Bijou Theater,
  an eight-theater multiplex.Â  During the first half of 2001, the property was
  under a monthly lease to United Artists.Â  United Artists was in bankruptcy
  proceedings during this time.Â Â Â  
In
  February 2001, a real estate agent working for the School District, Henry
  Garrison, advised Kiriakides that the School District was interested in
  purchasing the property.Â  The Kiriakides property adjoined Wade Hampton High School, and the School District wanted to renovate and expand the school.Â 
  Kiriakides initially informed Garrison that he did not want to sell the
  property, but that he would lease it.Â Â Â Â Â  
In June 2001,
  United Artists stopped paying rent and moved out of the theater.Â  Kiriakides
  and the School District continued their negotiations for a voluntary sale until
  approximately April 2002, but when the negotiations proved unsuccessful, the School District began the process to acquire the property by eminent domain.Â  
The School District retained an appraiser as part of the preliminary preparation for a
  condemnation proceeding, but Kiriakides refused to allow entry on his
  property.Â  On April 30, 2002, the School District filed a complaint seeking an
  order of entry.Â  On May 1, 2002, the circuit court issued an â€œOrder for Entry
  Pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 28-2-70 (1991)â€ allowing the School District to
  enter upon the property to make a survey, to determine the location of proposed
  improvements, and to prepare an appraisal.Â Â Â  
Due to the workload
  of the appraiser, the appraisal was first given to the School District in late
  July 2002.Â  On or about August 12, 2002, the School District served Kiriakides
  with a â€œCondemnation Notice and Tender of Paymentâ€ pursuant to the South
  Carolina Eminent Domain Procedure Act.[2]Â  
The
  School District never filed the condemnation action with the court, however,
  because on August 23, 2002, Kiriakides instituted the current action
  challenging the right of the School District to condemn his property.Â  In his
  pleadings, Kiriakides additionally sought damages for inverse condemnation and
  attorneysâ€™ fees, alleging â€œ[t]he stigmatization of [his] property as well as
  the unreasonable delay in commencing condemnation [proceedings] has amounted to
  an inverse condemnation of [his] property.â€Â  
In May
  2003, because of the urgency of the school construction project and the
  existence of this litigation challenging the right to proceed with
  condemnation, the School District notified Kiriakides that it had abandoned its
  efforts to condemn the property.Â  The School District ultimately purchased a
  different piece of property located nearby.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Thereafter,
  in December 2005, the master held a bench trial regarding Kiriakidesâ€™s
  complaint.Â  By order filed May 4, 2006, the master ruled in favor of the School
  District, finding as follows:Â  (1) Kiriakidesâ€™s challenge to the School
  Districtâ€™s right to condemn his property was moot because the School District
  had abandoned its condemnation efforts; (2) any challenge to the delay in the
  condemnation proceedings was likewise moot and there was no evidence of delay,
  in any event; and (3) Kiriakides had not established his inverse condemnation
  claim and was not entitled to damages.Â Â Â  
After
  a post-trial motion and hearing, the master awarded Kiriakides $6,500 in
  attorneysâ€™ fees pursuant to a provision in the South Carolina Eminent Domain Procedure
  Act based on his finding that the School District had â€œabandoned its
  condemnation efforts.â€Â  This cross appeal followed.Â  
II.Â  LAW/ANALYSIS
On
  appeal, Kiriakides challenges the masterâ€™s ruling in favor of the School
  District on his claim for inverse condemnation, and the School District challenges
  the masterâ€™s award of attorneysâ€™ fees to Kiriakides.
A.Â  KIRIAKIDESâ€™S APPEAL
Kiriakides contends
  the master erred in denying his claim for inverse condemnation.Â  We disagree.
â€œThe
  concept of inverse condemnation was originally conceived as a remedy for the
  physical taking of private property without following eminent domain
  procedures.â€Â  11A Eugene McQuillin, The Law of Municipal Corporations Â§
  32.132.20 (3d ed. 2000) (citing, inter alia, Woods v. State,
  314 S.C. 501, 431 S.E.2d 260 (Ct. App. 1993)).Â  â€œInverse condemnation is,
  therefore, a cause of action against a governmental defendant to recover the
  value of property which has been taken in fact by a governmental entity
  although not through eminent domain procedures.â€Â  Id.
â€œOne basic difference between condemnation and inverse condemnation is that in condemnation proceedings, the governmental
  entity is the moving party, whereas, in inverse condemnation, the property owner is the
  moving party.â€Â  South Carolina
    State Highway Depâ€™t v. Moody, 267 S.C. 130, 136, 226 S.E.2d 423,
  425 (1976).Â  
A
  landowner has the burden of proving damages for the taking of the landownerâ€™s
  property, whether through condemnation proceedings or by inverse condemnation.Â  Brenco v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 377 S.C. 124, 128, 659 S.E.2d
  167, 169 (2008) (citing Owens v. South Carolina State Highway Depâ€™t, 239
  S.C. 44, 54, 121 S.E.2d 240, 245 (1961)).
Not all
  damages that are suffered by a private property owner at the hands of the
  governmental agency are compensable.Â  Woods v. State, 314 S.C. 501, 504,
  431 S.E.2d 260, 262 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  The property itself must suffer some
  diminution in substance, or it must be rendered intrinsically less valuable.Â  Id. 
â€œ[I]n
  an inverse condemnation case, the trial judge will determine whether a claim
  has been established; the issue of compensation may then be submitted to a jury
  at either partyâ€™s request.â€Â  Cobb v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 365
  S.C. 360, 365, 618 S.E.2d 299, 301 (2005).
Inverse
  condemnation claims can result from two instances:Â  â€œAn inverse condemnation
  may result from the governmentâ€™s physical appropriation of private property, or
  it may result from government-imposed limitations on the use of private
  property.â€Â  Byrd v. City of Hartsville, 365 S.C. 650, 656, 620 S.E.2d 76,
  79 (2005).
In
  the second instance, where there is a regulatory inverse condemnation, there
  are two elements that must be shown:Â  (1) affirmative conduct, and (2) a
  taking.Â  Id. at 657, 620 S.E.2d at 80.Â  The analysis of whether a taking
  has occurred is governed by the case of Penn Central Transportation Co. v.
    City of New York, 438 U.S. 104 (1978) when the claim stems from an
  allegation of a temporary denial of less than all economically viable use of
  the property.Â  Id. at 658, 620 S.E.2d at 80.Â  â€œIn the context of a
  regulatory delay, the Penn Central inquiry is whether the delay ever
  became unreasonable.â€Â  Id. at 81, 620 S.E.2d at 660.Â  â€œUntil regulatory
  delay becomes unreasonable, there is no taking.â€Â  Id. Â 
As enumerated
  in Byrd, two circumstances are particularly important:Â  (1) the economic
  impact on the claimant, especially the extent to which the governmental entity
  has interfered with the claimantâ€™s investment-backed expectations, and (2) the
  character of the governmental action.Â  Id. at 659, 620 S.E.2d at 80
  (citing Penn Central, 438 U.S. 104, 124 (1978)).Â  
In
  the case now before us, the parties conceded, and the master specifically
  found, that there was never any physical occupation or appropriation of
  Kiriakidesâ€™s property, the first type of taking under Byrd.Â  Rather,
  Kiriakides asserted the stigmatization of his property by the threat of
  condemnation amounted to a regulatory inverse condemnation under the
  second prong of Byrd.Â  
In
  rejecting this assertion of a regulatory inverse condemnation, the master found
  there was no act and no taking by the School District that would come within
  the parameters of an inverse condemnation claim.Â  The master noted:Â  â€œThe
  parties agree that the School District never imposed any regulations or
  restrictions on the property of Mr. Kiriakides.Â  The School Districtâ€™s
  pre-condemnation activities and the service of the Condemnation Notice and
  Tender of Payment to Mr. Kiriakides certainly did not give rise to a taking,
  regulatory or otherwise.â€Â  
The
  master stated that â€œ[a] regulatory taking by its very nature
  necessitates the existence of some regulation, statute, ordinance, zoning law,
  or similar rule of law that impacts a landownerâ€™s use of his property.Â  In
  other words, regulatory takings exist only in conjunction with affirmative
  governmental restrictions on the use of land.â€Â  The master further stated:Â  â€œSuch
  was the essence of the Byrd case, where Mr. Byrdâ€™s property was
  restricted by zoning regulations, and in Lucas v. South Carolina Coastal
    Council, 505 U.S. 1003 (1992)[,] where land use restrictions constituted a
  regulatory taking.Â  That does not exist in this case.â€Â  
The
  master additionally observed his conclusion was supported by public policy, namely,
  the construction of public projects would be severely impeded if the government
  incurred liability for inverse condemnation as a result of merely announcing
  plans to condemn, citing National By-Products, Inc. v. City of Little Rock,
  916 S.W.2d 745, 749 (Ark. 1996) (â€œConstruction of public-works projects would
  be severely impeded if the government could incur inverse condemnation
  liability merely by announcing plans to condemn property in the future.â€); Santini
    v. Connecticut Hazardous Waste Management Service, 739 A.2d 680, 691 (Conn.
  1999) (â€œ[I]f the government were to be considered as having accomplished a
  compensable taking as a result of mere planning that, because of its publicity,
  harmed the value of property, public planning would be discouraged . . . .â€); City
    of Buffalo v. J. W. Clement Co., 269 N.E.2d 895, 903-04 (N.Y. 1971)
  (stating the threat of condemnation generally does not constitute a taking and
  any changes in value are incidents of ownership).Â  The master stated that
  Kiriakidesâ€™s arguments, â€œif accepted, would have a devastating impact on government
  and its citizens.â€Â Â Â  
We agree
  with the masterâ€™s determination that Kiriakides did not establish a claim for
  inverse condemnation.Â  We find no merit to his arguments that the mere threat
  of a condemnation suit stigmatized his property and that the School Districtâ€™s alleged
  delay in bringing this action entitled him to damages for an inverse
  condemnation.Â  
The
  Supreme Court of the United States has held that the â€œimpairment of the market
  value of real property incident to otherwise legitimate government action
  ordinarily does not result in a taking.â€Â  Kirby Forest Indus. v. United States, 467 U.S. 1, 15 (1984).Â  In Kirby Forest, the Supreme Court concluded
  the landowner â€œfailed to demonstrate that its
  interests were impaired in any constitutionally significant way before the
  Government tendered payment and acquired title in the usual course.â€Â  Id. at 16. 
The
  mere institution of condemnation proceedings does not constitute a taking, as
  it is a legitimate exercise of the governmentâ€™s authority.Â  See generally 29A C.J.S. Eminent Domain Â§ 90 (2007) (stating the mere planning in
  anticipation of a public improvement is not an actionable taking of property);
  J. R. Kemper, Annotation, Plotting or Planning in Anticipation of
    Improvement as Taking or Damaging of Property Affected, 37 A.L.R.3d 127
  (1971 & Supp. 2008) (discussing acts performed in preparation for and as
  part of condemnation proceedings and the imposition of liability therefor).
The
  evidence shows that the School District and Kiriakides engaged in extensive
  negotiations concerning a voluntary sale of the property until at least April
  2002.Â  During this time, no public action was taken by the School District that
  would â€œstigmatizeâ€ the property as Kiriakides alleges, as the communications
  were solely with Kiriakides and there was no public filing of a condemnation
  action.Â  The first public communication occurred when Kiriakides refused to
  allow an appraiser to enter his property and the School District filed a motion
  in April 2002 seeking an order allowing entry.Â  
Thereafter,
  when negotiations failed, the School District followed the statutory procedures
  for an eminent domain action and served a notice of condemnation in August
  2002.Â  Kiriakides challenged the School Districtâ€™s right to condemn within
  thirty days of being served with notice by the School District by filing the
  current, separate action, as was his right under state law, which stayed the
  condemnation proceedings.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 28-2-470 (2007) (providing
  an â€œaction [challenging a condemnorâ€™s right to condemn] must be commenced
  within thirty days after service of the Condemnation Notice upon the landownerâ€
  and that â€œ[a]ll proceedings under the Condemnation Notice are automatically
  stayed until the disposition of the action, if any, unless the landowner and
  the condemnor consent otherwiseâ€).
We
  discern no unreasonable delay or bad faith conduct on the part of the School District in this matter.Â  The School District never tried to obtain possession of
  Kiriakides land, and until Kiriakides refused to allow an appraiser on his
  property, it had made no public filing in this case. Â If anything, Kiriakidesâ€™s
  failure to cooperate with the School Districtâ€™s efforts to obtain an appraisal
  and his challenge to the School Districtâ€™s right to condemn extended these proceedings.Â 
  Further, Kiriakides presented no evidence of damages.Â  He offered no proof that
  the value of his property was diminished or that he lost any potential sales of
  his property due to the proceedings.Â  In fact, Kiriakides admitted that he had
  not tried to sell his property during this time. 
The School Districtâ€™s actions were part of the statutorily-mandated process for condemnation,
  and did not constitute an unreasonable delay in these circumstances that would
  establish a compensable claim.Â  See Tahoe-Sierra Pres. Council, Inc.
    v. Tahoe Regâ€™l Planning Agency, 535 U.S. 302, 335 (2002) (â€œA rule that
  required compensation for every delay in the use of property would render
  routine government processes prohibitively expensive or encourage hasty
  decision-making.â€); Woods, 314 S.C. at 504, 431 S.E.2d at 262 (holding not
  all damages suffered by private property owners at the hands of the government
  are compensable).Â  The nine-month period between the time the School District
  served notice of the condemnation in August 2002 until it notified Kiriakides
  in writing in May 2003 that it was abandoning the condemnation proceeding due
  to Kiriakidesâ€™s opposition and the need to proceed with the project did not
  establish a taking.Â  Cf. Byrd, 365 S.C. at 661-63, 620 S.E.2d at 82
  (finding an eleven-month delay in evaluating the rezoning of certain property
  did not result in a regulatory taking and inverse condemnation).Â  
The
  master observed that cases from other jurisdictions overwhelmingly hold that
  normal activities incident to condemnation do not rise to the level of a
  taking.Â  See Joseph M. Jackovich Revocable Trust v. Alaska Depâ€™t of
    Transp., 54 P.3d 294, 302 (Alaska 2002) (stating â€œthere is no indication
  the state did anything more than make announcements, prepare and publish plans,
  and provide publicity concerning the projectâ€ and no evidence the state
  interfered with the property rights of the landowners); City of Chicago v.
    Loitz, 295 N.E.2d 478, 480 (Ill. App. Ct. 1973) (observing â€œthe weight of
  authority in other states and in the Federal courts, is that mere planning by a
  governmental body in anticipation of the taking of land for public use and
  preliminary steps taken to accomplish this, without the filing of proceedings
  and without physically taking or actual invasion of the real estate, is not
  actionable by the owner of the landâ€).Â  
To
  the extent Kiriakidesâ€™s alleges the master improperly considered public policy
  in determining no inverse condemnation occurred in this matter, we find no
  error.Â  The master merely cited this as additional support for his conclusion
  that Kiriakidesâ€™s position was untenable because if it was accepted, the
  government would be faced with inverse condemnation claims every time it
  attempted to survey property and obtain an appraisal, which would preclude the
  government from engaging in normal activities incident to a condemnation.Â 
  Accordingly, based on the foregoing, we affirm the masterâ€™s determination that
  Kiriakides did not establish a claim for inverse condemnation. 
B.Â  THE SCHOOL DISTRICTâ€™S APPEAL
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  In its cross
  appeal, the School District contends the master erred in awarding statutory attorneysâ€™
  fees to Kiriakides.Â  We disagree.
In
  the order ruling on Kiriakidesâ€™s complaint, the master found that, â€œbecause the
  School District abandoned its condemnation efforts, that part of the present
  litigation challenging its right to condemn has been rendered moot.â€Â 
  Kiriakides filed a post-trial motion seeking a determination whether he was
  entitled to attorneysâ€™ fees, stating he had requested attorneysâ€™ fees in his
  complaint, but the issue was not addressed in the masterâ€™s order.[3]Â  
After
  a hearing, the master issued an order on December 5, 2006, finding Kiriakides
  was entitled to attorneysâ€™ fees pursuant to section 28-2-510(C) of the South
  Carolina Code, which allows a landowner costs and fees in the event a condemnor
  abandons a â€œcondemnation actionâ€ as follows:

	If the
  condemnor abandons or withdraws the condemnation action in the manner
  authorized by this chapter, the condemnee is entitled to reasonable attorney
  fees, litigation expenses, and costs as determined by the court.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 28-2-510(C)
  (2007) (emphasis added). Â Â Â 
The master
  concluded a reasonable fee would be $6,500, which â€œfairly represents the
  portion of the fees in this case that were necessarily related to the issues of
  abandonment or withdrawal of the condemnation action by the Defendant.â€[4]Â 
  On appeal, the School District contends this was error.
The
  decision to award or deny attorneysâ€™ fees under a state statute will not be
  disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Layman v. State, 376
  S.C. 434, 444, 658 S.E.2d 320, 325 (2008).Â  â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs
  when the conclusions of the trial court are either controlled by an error of
  law or are based on unsupported factual conclusions.â€Â  Id.Â  â€œSimilarly,
  the specific amount of attorneysâ€™ fees awarded pursuant to a statute
  authorizing reasonable attorneysâ€™ fees is left to the discretion of the trial
  judge and will not be disturbed absent an abuse of discretion.â€Â  Id.
(1)
  Â Applicability of Section 28-2-510(C).
The School District
  argues the master erred in awarding attorneysâ€™ fees to Kiriakides under section
  28-2-510(C) of the South Carolina Eminent Domain Procedure Act because the
  statute is inapplicable. Â The School District asserts that, although it served Kiriakides with a Condemnation Notice and Tender of Payment, it never filed the notice with the circuit court; therefore, the action was never commenced.Â  Consequently,
  it is not liable for attorneysâ€™ fees for the abandonment of a â€œcondemnation
  action.â€
The master rejected
  this argument, finding â€œunder the unique facts of this case,â€ a party is
  entitled to attorneysâ€™ fees if the condemnor abandons the action after service of the Condemnation Notice.Â  The master reasoned that â€œ[t]o hold otherwise
  would . . . encourage a governmental entity to serve its Condemnation Notice,
  chill the value of the property, negotiate until it determines that the value
  sought by the landowner is still too high or that another parcel is more
  suitable, and then unilaterally withdraw its Notice with complete impunity
  since a condemnation lawsuit was never filed.Â  All to the detriment of the
  landowner.Â  This certainly cannot be the result intended by our Legislature.â€Â  
Under
  Rule 3 of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure, a civil action is generally
  deemed commenced by filing and serving a summons and complaint.Â  Rule 3(a),
  SCRCP.Â  Under this rule, both filing and service are required to institute an
  action.Â  See 24 S.C. Juris. Rules of Civil Procedure Â§ 3.2 (1994)
  (â€œSubpart 3(a) requires both the filing and service of a summons and complaint
  prior to the commencement of a civil action.Â  The South Carolina courts have
  demanded literal compliance with Rule 3(a).â€).
The
  provisions of the South Carolina Eminent Domain Procedure Act, however, constitute
  the exclusive procedure for condemnation in this state.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  28-2-210 (2007).Â  Moreover, these provisions control over the South Carolina
  Rules of Civil Procedure.Â  Id. Â§ 28-2-120 (â€œIn the event of conflict
  between this act and the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure, this act
  shall prevail.â€).
In
  this case, section 28-2-30(5) specifically states a â€œâ€˜[c]ondemnation actionâ€™
  includes all acts incident to the process of condemning property after the
    service of a Condemnation Notice.â€Â  Id. Â§ 28-2-30(5) (emphasis
  added).
The
  Act also makes reference to service in other provisions.Â  For example, section
  28-2-470 provides that a separate action to challenge the condemnorâ€™s right to
  condemn automatically stays a proceeding for condemnation, and the Act requires
  this separate action to be filed within thirty days after service of the
  Condemnation Notice.Â  Id. Â§ 28-2-470. Â 
In addition, the
  Act defines litigation expenses as those incurred from the time of service of
  the Condemnation Notice, again referencing service:

	(14)
  â€œLitigation expensesâ€ means the reasonable fees, charges, disbursements, and
  expenses necessarily incurred from and after service of the Condemnation
    Notice, including, but not limited to, reasonable attorneyâ€™s fees . . . .

Id. Â§ 28-2-30(14) (emphasis added).
The provisions of
  the Act are unique and thus the commencement of the condemnation action cannot be
  measured in terms of regular civil proceedings:

	The Act
  does not require the issuance of a summons and complaint and the filing of
  responsive pleadings.Â  Rather, the procedure begins with service of a
    condemnation notice.Â  The condemnation notice may be served in any manner
  allowed for serving a summons and complaint in a civil action.Â  

18 S.C. Juris. Eminent
  Domain Â§ 38 (1993) (emphasis added) (footnotes omitted).
Although there
  are references to filing in the Act,[5] we hold service marks the time for commencement of the action as defined in the
  Act.Â  Thus, we find section 28-2-510(C) is applicable in this instance.Â  
(2)
  Â Contingency Fee Agreement.Â  
The School District further argues the master erred in awarding attorneysâ€™ fees to Kiriakides
  because he legally owed no fees to his attorneys.Â  One of Kiriakidesâ€™s
  attorneys testified that he and his co-counsel had no written fee agreement with
  Kiriakides, but they did have a contingency fee arrangement with him - their
  understanding was they were to be paid if Kiriakides recovered on his claims.Â 
  The attorney acknowledged that they had not billed Kiriakides for any fees and
  that Kiriakides had paid no fees.Â  [R. 44-46]Â  The School District argues that,
  because Kiriakides did not prevail on his inverse condemnation claim and he did
  not obtain a recovery, no attorneysâ€™ fees were legally due, relying upon the
  case of South Carolina Public Service Authority v. Weeks, 201 S.C. 199, 22
  S.E.2d 249 (1942).
In Weeks,
  we considered a statutory provision allowing attorneysâ€™ fees for the
  abandonment of eminent domain proceedings that provided as follows:

	At any
  time prior to the final conclusion of the condemnation proceeding provided for
  in this Act and prior to entry into possession by such State Authority, it may
  abandon, withdraw or dismiss such condemnation proceedings upon payment by it
  to the owner of all costs and expenses incurred by the owner, and the amount of
  such costs and expenses shall constitute a lien, for the payment thereof, upon
  any award theretofore deposited in said proceeding by said Authority.

Id. at 200-01, 22 S.E.2d at 249.
The parties in Weeks had a contingency fee agreement to compensate the attorneys one-half of the
  amount recovered over and above what the condemnor offered, but there was no
  recovery obtained as the condemnation proceeding was abandoned.Â  Id. at 202, 22 S.E.2d at 250.Â  Consequently, no fees were owed under the terms of
  the agreement.Â  The trial judge allowed attorneysâ€™ fees, however, on the theory
  of quantum meruit.Â  Id. Â Upon review, we noted that, we found this was
  error, stating: 

	[T]he
  agreement was for a contingent fee, contingent upon recovery and, incidentally,
  recovery of more than the amount offered for the land by the condemnor.Â  This
  contingency never occurred, the event of recovery did not transpire, because
  the condemnation was abandoned, and the right to that course by the condemnor
  is not challenged.
	* *
  * * 
	Undoubtedly, generally where an attorney is discharged
  without cause by his client after they have entered into a contingent fee
  agreement, he is entitled to compensation. . . .Â  
	The latter, however, is not the case now presented.Â  No
  action on the part of the landowners prevented the happening of the
  contingency; it failed because of the abandonment of the condemnation by the
  appellant.Â  The inevitable result is that the attorneys by force of the terms
  of their contract, voluntarily entered into, are entitled to no compensation.

Id. at 202-03, 22 S.E.2d at 250.
The master noted
  the holding of the Weeks case, but concluded:Â  â€œNotwithstanding, I find
  that Plaintiff and his attorneys had a reasonable expectation of payment and
  that [section 28-2-510(C)] entitles Plaintiff, as the owner of property which
  was subject to an abandoned condemnation action, to reasonable attorneys[â€™]
  fees.Â  Further, even though an express contract for legal services was not
  entered into, the law in this State is clear that under the facts of a case
  such as this, the law will imply one.â€Â  
Kiriakides
  maintains Weeks is distinguishable because the statute there referred to
  â€œall costs and expenses incurred by the owner,â€ which requires the fees to be
  actually incurred, whereas section 28-2-510(C) generally provides for the recovery
  of â€œreasonableâ€ attorneysâ€™ fees, which means the fees need not be actually
  incurred.Â  The South Carolina Eminent Domain Procedure Act, however, defines â€œlitigation
  expensesâ€ as those â€œreasonable . . . expenses necessarily incurred from
  and after service of the Condemnation Notice, including, but not limited to,
  reasonable attorneyâ€™s fees . . . .â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 28-2-30(14) (emphasis
  added).Â  
In
  the current appeal, Kiriakidesâ€™s attorneys had an unwritten agreement to be
  paid on a contingency basis - essentially they would recover a percentage of
  any award Kiriakides obtained.Â  They included a request for attorneysâ€™ fees in
  their pleadings, but the School District subsequently abandoned its
  condemnation action.Â  As one treatise has stated:

	Some courts have denied recovery for attorneysâ€™ fees
  which were wholly contingent upon the payment of an award or judgment in the
  condemnation proceeding, when the proceeding was abandoned by the condemnor.Â  [Citing, 
	inter alia, South Carolina Public Service Authority v. Weeks, 201 S.C. 199, 22
  S.E.2d 249 (1942).]Â  However, other courts have held or recognized that the
  recovery of attorneysâ€™ fees in such a situation is not barred by the existence
  of a contingency fee agreement between the property owner and the ownerâ€™s
  attorney, rejecting the
  contention that the contingent nature of the agreement meant that fees were not
  â€œincurredâ€ by the landowner and thus not recoverable.

2 Robert L.
  Rossi, Attorneysâ€™ Fees Â§ 11:38 (3d ed. 2001) (footnotes omitted).
We agree
  with the masterâ€™s determination that Kiriakides was entitled to attorneysâ€™ fees
  under these circumstances. Â We hereby overrule Weeks to the extent that
  it conflicts with section 28-2-510(C), as the obvious intent of this statute is
  to allow a landowner to recover his expenses in the event of abandonment of a
  condemnation proceeding.Â  Further, we see no reason to differentiate situations
  where a party terminates the attorney and those where the condemnor terminates
  the proceeding.Â  Having found the School District abandoned its efforts to
  condemn Kiriakidesâ€™s property, we hold attorneysâ€™ fees were properly awarded.Â  We
  note that on appeal the School District has challenged Kiriakidesâ€™s entitlement
  to attorneysâ€™ fees, but it has not challenged the reasonableness of the
  masterâ€™s award.Â  Accordingly, we affirm the award of attorneysâ€™ fees to
  Kiriakides in the amount of $6,500. 
III. CONCLUSION
Based on the
  foregoing, we affirm the masterâ€™s determination that Kiriakides has not
  established his claim for inverse condemnation and that Kiriakides is entitled
  to attorneysâ€™ fees pursuant to section 29-2-510(C) of the South Carolina Code for
  the School Districtâ€™s abandonment of its condemnation proceeding.
AFFIRMED.
TOAL,
  C.J., WALLER and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.Â  KITTREDGE, J., not participating.


[1]Â  Alex Kiriakides, Jr. passed away before oral
  argument was held in this matter.Â  This appeal continues via his personal
  representatives.Â  
[2]Â  The Act is codified at S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 28-2-10 to
  -510 (2007).
[3]Â  We find the issue is preserved for our review under
  these circumstances.
[4]Â  Kiriakides submitted an affidavit and statement
  seeking attorneysâ€™ fees of $13,775, representing 55.1 hours at $250 per hour.Â  
[5]Â  For example:Â  â€œIn all condemnation actions, the date
  of valuation is the date of the filing of the Condemnation Notice.â€Â  S.C. Code
  Ann. Â§ 28-2-440 (2007) (referencing filing).Â

CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  In
  this case, Petitioner was convicted of armed robbery and sentenced to twenty
  years imprisonment.Â  The court of appeals affirmed the conviction and sentence.Â  State v. Mitchell, Op. No. 2006-UP-403 (S.C. Ct. App. filed December 11,
  2006).Â  We granted Petitioner a writ of certiorari to review the court of
  appealsâ€™ decision.Â  We affirm.Â  
Factual/Procedural
  Background
On December 30, 2003, Petitioner Curtis Jerome
  Mitchell entered a Bi-Lo grocery store in Rock Hill.Â  A store employee observed
  Petitioner pick up two twelve-pack cases of chewing tobacco and proceed past
  the point of sale towards the exit without paying.Â  The employee approached
  Petitioner as he reached the exit door and asked him to return the chewing
  tobacco.Â  Petitioner presented a pocket knife and told the employee, â€œGo ahead,
  mother f****r, try something.Â  Iâ€™ll kill you.â€Â  Petitioner then walked out the
  exit door with the chewing tobacco.Â  
Petitioner was
  subsequently apprehended and indicted by the York County grand jury for armed
  robbery.Â  On April 21, 2004, Petitioner was tried before a jury.Â  After the
  state rested its case, Petitionerâ€™s trial counsel moved for directed verdict on
  the grounds that Petitioner completed the crime of larceny before using force
  or intimidation, and therefore did not commit an armed robbery.Â  The trial
  court ruled that a person may be convicted of armed robbery if he arms himself
  at any time during commission of the larceny, and instructed the jury accordingly.Â 
  The trial court based its ruling on this Courtâ€™s opinion in State v. Keith,
  283 S.C. 597, 325 S.E.2d 325 (1985).Â  The jury returned a guilty verdict.Â  
On appeal to the
  court of appeals, Petitioner argued that: (1) the trial court erred by refusing
  to grant Petitionerâ€™s motion for directed verdict on the charge of armed
  robbery, where the evidence showed that Petitioner had completed the larceny
  prior to the threat of force; and (2) the trial court erred in instructing the
  jury that a robber need not be armed at all times during the commission of the
  larceny in order to be guilty of armed robbery.Â  The court of appeals affirmed
  the trial court, holding that armed robbery may be proved by showing that the
  defendant became armed before asportation of the property, and that the trial
  court properly instructed the jury that a robber need not be armed at all time
  during the commission of a theft in order to be found guilty of armed robbery.
Standard
  of Review
In criminal cases,
  this Court will review errors of law only.Â  State v. Baccus, 367 S.C.
  41, 48, 625 S.E.2d 216, 220 (2006).Â  This Court is bound by the trial courtâ€™s
  factual findings unless they are clearly erroneous.Â  State v. Quattlebaum,
  338 S.C. 441, 452, 527 S.E.2d 105, 111 (2000).Â  On review, this Court is limited to determining whether the
  trial court abused its discretion. Â State v. Rochester, 301 S.C. 196,
  200, 391 S.E.2d 244, 247 (1990).Â  This Court does not re-evaluate the facts
  based on its own view of the preponderance of the evidence but simply
  determines whether the trial courtâ€™s ruling is supported by any evidence.Â  State
    v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 6, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001).Â  
Law/Analysis 
Petitioner argues that the court of appeals
  erroneously affirmed the trial courtâ€™s finding that he was properly charged
  with armed robbery.Â  Petitioner submits that he should have instead been
  charged with separate offenses for petit larceny and assault with intent to
  kill or assault of a high and aggravated nature.Â  We disagree.Â  
Armed robbery
  occurs when a person commits robbery while either armed with a deadly weapon or
  alleging to be armed by the representation of a deadly weapon.Â  S.C. Code Ann.
  Â§ 16-11-330 (2003).Â  Included in armed robbery is the lesser included offense
  of robbery, which is defined as â€œthe felonious or unlawful taking of money,
  goods, or other personal property of any value from the person of another or in
  his presence by violence or by putting such person in fear.â€Â  State v.
    Al-Amin, 353 S.C. 405, 424, 578 S.E.2d 32, 42 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Larceny,
  which is a lesser included offense in the crime of robbery, is defined as the
  felonious taking and carrying away of the goods of another against the ownerâ€™s
  will or without his consent.[1]Â  Id.Â  â€œThus, it is the use or alleged use of a deadly weapon that
  distinguishes armed robbery from robbery, and the employment of force or threat
  of force that differentiates a robbery from a larceny.â€Â  State v. Moore,
  374 S.C. 468, 477, 649 S.E.2d 84, 89 (Ct. App. 2007).Â  
The central issue
  in the present case involves the determination of at what point asportation
  becomes final so that a larceny may not become a robbery.Â  We considered that
  issue, pursuant to a different set of factual circumstances, in State v.
    Keith, 283 S.C. 597, 325 S.E.2d 325 (1985).Â  In that case, the defendant
  Keith was one of three unarmed men, who accosted the victim as he walked along
  a public street.Â  The men rifled through the victimâ€™s pockets and removed cash
  from his wallet.Â  The men also found the victimâ€™s pocketknife, which they used
  to stab the victim repeatedly.Â  Keith was convicted of armed robbery and on
  appeal argued that the conviction was improper because he did not become armed
  until after he had taken the victimâ€™s money.Â  We disagreed and held that â€œwhen
  a defendant commits robbery without a deadly weapon, but becomes armed with a
  deadly weapon before asportation of the victimâ€™s property, a conviction for
  armed robbery will stand.â€Â  Keith, 283 S.C. at 598-99, 325 S.E.2d
  at 326.Â  We also noted that â€œthe crime of robbery is not completed the moment
  the stolen property is in the possession of the robbers, but may be deemed to
  continue during their attempt to escape.â€Â  Id.Â  
Petitioner argues
  that Keith is inapposite to the present case.Â  We disagree.Â  Keithâ€™s
  enduring legacy, which is directly relevant to the present case, is the
  â€œcontinuous offense theory.â€Â  This theory is articulated thoroughly in the
  court of appealsâ€™ opinion in State v. Moore, which involves a set of
  facts nearly identical to the present case.Â  374 S.C. at 478, 649 S.E.2d at
  89.Â  
In Moore, defendant Moore entered a Wal-Mart, picked up a package of over-the-counter
  medication from a display shelf, and walked toward the exit.Â  A security guard
  followed Moore out of the door and stopped him just outside the door on the
  sidewalk.Â  Moore then brandished a handgun, and the security guard, fearing his
  safety, ended the encounter and returned inside the store.Â  Moore was later
  apprehended and charged with armed robbery.
At trial, Moore moved for directed verdict on the same grounds raised by Petitioner.Â  Moore argued that he could not be convicted of armed robbery because the asportation of the
  property occurred before the confrontation and no force or threat of force was
  used to take the merchandise.Â  The trial court denied Mooreâ€™s motion on the
  grounds that asportation, a necessary element of armed robbery, continues
  during the escape.Â  
The
  court of appeals affirmed the trial courtâ€™s ruling, and began its analysis with
  the Keith opinion, which it interpreted to support â€œthe continuous
  offense theory.â€Â  This theory â€œprovides that [a robbery] has occurred â€˜not only
  if the perpetrator uses force or intimidation to take possession of the
  property, but also if force or intimidation is used to retain possession
  immediately after the taking, or to carry away the property, or to facilitate
  escape.â€[2]Â  Id. (quoting State v. Meyers, 620 So.2d 1160, 1163 (La. 1993)).Â  As articulated by the court of appeals, the theory supports the proposition
  that â€œa â€˜takingâ€™ is not complete - that is to say, has not come to an end -
  until the perpetrator has neutralized any immediate interference with his or
  her possession.â€Â  Id. at 480, 649 S.E.2d at 90.Â Â  
We
  believe the court of appealsâ€™ opinion in Moore articulates the correct
  view of the law in the present case.Â  This view is in keeping with the majority
  of states and legal authorities.Â  See id. at 480-482, 649 S.E.2d
  at 90 (listing the twenty-seven states to have adopted the continuous offense
  theory by statute and the eight states to have adopted the theory by common
  law).Â  See also Model Penal Code Â§ 222.1(1) (2001) (adopting the
  position that a robbery occurs when force or intimidation is part of the entire
  act, and includes the use of force or intimidation to retain possession of the
  thing taken or to escape or prevent pursuit); 77 C.J.S. Robbery Â§ 4 (2008)
  (â€œAsportation is not confined to a fixed point in time.Â  The taking away is a
  transaction which continues as the perpetrators depart from the place where the
  property was seized, and may, under appropriate circumstances, be deemed to
  continue even after such departure from the place of seizure.â€); 67 Am.Jur.2d
  Robbery Â§ 4 (â€œAlthough the required force or threat of force for the offense of
  armed robbery must either precede or be contemporaneous with the taking of a
  victimâ€™s property, the use of a dangerous weapon at any point in the robbery
  will constitute armed robbery as long as it reasonably can be said to be part
  of a single occurrence.â€).Â Â  
Applied
  to the facts of the present case, the continuous offense theory requires that we
  affirm the court of appeals.Â  It is clear that Petitioner did not complete the
  asportation of the chewing tobacco until after he employed the threat of force
  to secure his escape and retain possession of the goods.Â  Thus, the trial court
  was correct to deny Petitionerâ€™s motion for directed verdict on the charge for
  armed robbery.
Conclusion

For the foregoing
  reasons, we hereby affirm the decision of the court of appeals.Â  
WALLER,
  PLEICONES, BEATTY, JJ., and Acting Justice James E. Moore, concur.


[1]Â 
  The â€œtaking and carrying awayâ€ of goods is often referred to as the element of
  â€œasportation.â€
[2] The rationale for adopting the continuous offense
  theory is to effectuate the purpose of the distinction between larceny and
  robbery:

	[T]he
  purpose of the force or intimidation element of the crime of robbery is to
  distinguish, by imposition of a more severe penalty, those takings which pose a
  greater risk to the victim.Â  The danger to the victim, however, is identical
  whether the force or intimidation is employed against the victim immediately
  before or after the actual taking.

Â Id.Â Â Â

title: State v. Woods
description: This is a capital case.   The issues on appeal are whether the trial court erred utilizing a jury pool from Clarendon County, rather than Marion County and whether the court erred in excusing a black female potential juror for cause.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Anthony Woods, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Clarendon County
Â John C. Few, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No.Â  26623
Heard February 3, 2009 - Filed March 30,
  2009Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Chief
  Appellate Defender Joseph L. Savitz, III, of South Carolina Commission on
  Indigent Defense, of Columbia, and Frederick A. Hoefer, II, of Ballenger Barth
  & Hoefer, of Florence, for Appellant.
				Attorney
  GeneralÂ  Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh,
  Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, Senior Assistant Attorney
  General William Edgar Salter, III, all of Columbia, and Solicitor Cecil Kelly
  Jackson, of Sumter, for Respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE
  WALLER:Â  Appellant, Anthony Woods, was convicted of murder, first degree
  burglary and criminal sexual conduct (CSC).Â  He was sentenced to death for
  murder, thirty years for CSC, and life imprisonment without parole (LWOP) for
  burglary, the sentences to run consecutively.Â  We affirm the convictions and
  sentences.Â  
FACTS
Joanne
  Dubose, a fifty-three year old Manning school teacher, was last seen alive on
  Monday, June 2, 2003.Â  When Dubose did not answer telephone calls for several
  days, a friend went to check on her Wednesday evening, June 4, 2003, and found
  Dubose lying on her bed, face up, with blood running off the side of her face.Â 
  The friend called 911, and police arrived to find Dubose dead, with a sheet
  tied around her neck, and her right arm tied down; her legs were spread under
  the sheet, her tongue was protruding from her mouth, and her face was beginning
  to decompose.Â  
In the
  early morning hours of June 5, 2003, Woods was arrested in connection with a
  burglary the previous evening of the residence of Linda Taylor, another Clarendon County woman.[1]  A shoeprint impression taken from the shoes Woods was wearing at the time of
  his arrest was ultimately determined to be consistent with a shoeprint lifted
  from the floor of Duboseâ€™s bedroom.Â  DNA testing on the mattress pad and sheet from
  Duboseâ€™s bed revealed semen which matched Woodsâ€™ DNA profile.Â  A pathologist
  determined Dubose died from asphyxiation due to strangulation, and that she had
  been dead for approximately two days, indicating she died on June 3, 2003.Â  The
  pathologist found no evidence of sexual trauma, but testified decomposition
  could have affected the ability to detect such trauma.Â  
Woods
  was indicted and charged with murder, first degree burglary, and first degree CSC.Â 
  The state sought the death penalty based upon the aggravating circumstances of
  burglary and criminal sexual conduct.Â  Woodsâ€™ first trial, utilizing a jury
  pool from Marion County, ended in a hung jury and a mistrial in September
  2006.Â  Upon retrial in December 2006, a jury was selected from Clarendon County, and Woods was convicted on all counts; the jury recommended a sentence of
  death.
ISSUES

	1.Â  Did the trial court err in utilizing a jury pool from Clarendon County, rather than Marion County?
	2.Â  Did the trial court err in excusing a black female potential
  juror for cause? 

1.Â  JURY POOL
Prior
  to Woodsâ€™ first trial in 2006, he requested a change of venue due to extensive
  pre-trial publicity and the fact that the Victim was a well-known teacher who
  had taught in Clarendon County public schools.Â  With the stateâ€™s consent, the
  trial judge granted the motion and ruled a jury would be selected from Marion County and transported to Clarendon County for trial.Â  Trial took place in September
  2006 and ended in a hung jury and a mistrial.Â  
When
  the case was called for re-trial in October 2006, the state withdrew its
  consent to the change of venue.Â  The state took the position that the mistrial
  resulted in going back to â€œground zero.â€Â  Defense counsel contended the stateâ€™s
  consent to the change of venue in the first trial was binding, such that venue
  remained proper in Marion.Â  The trial judge ruled he would endeavor to empanel
  a jury in Clarendon County before moving jury selection elsewhere.[2]Â  After a lengthy voir dire process, a jury was selected in Clarendon County, and Woods was tried in December
  2006; he was convicted on all counts and sentenced to death. Â Woods now argues it
  was reversible error for the trial court to transfer jury selection from Marion County back to Clarendon County.Â  We disagree.
When a
  trial judge grants or denies a motion for a change of venue after adequate voir
    dire of prospective jurors, the decision will not be overturned absent
  extraordinary circumstances.Â  State v. Evins, 373 S.C. 404, 645 S.E.2d
  904, cert. denied 128 S.Ct. 622 (2007).Â  The moving party has the burden
  of demonstrating actual juror prejudice.Â  State v. Caldwell, 300 S.C.
  494, 388 S.E.2d 816 (1990).Â  
A
  mistrial is the equivalent of no trial and leaves the cause pending in the
  circuit court.Â  State v. Smith, 336 S.C. 39, 518 S.E.2d 294 (Ct. App.
  1999).Â  It leaves the parties â€œas though no trial had taken place.â€ Grooms
    v. Zander, 246 S.C. 512, 514, 144 S.E.2d 909, 910 (1965) (rulings of trial
  judge in proceeding ending in mistrial represent no binding adjudication upon
  the parties as the mistrial leaves the parties in status quo ante). Â A court
  ruling as to admissibility and competency of testimony during a trial which is
  later declared a mistrial results â€œin no binding adjudication of the rights of
  the parties.â€ Keels v. Powell, 213 S.C. 570, 572, 50 S.E.2d 704, 705
  (1948).Â  
In State
  v. Manning, 329 S.C.1, 495 S.E.2d 191 (1997), upon a retrial in a capital
  case, the trial court granted the stateâ€™s motion to change venue from Dillon County to Kershaw County.Â  On appeal, this Court held the trial court â€œabused his
  discretion in granting the Stateâ€™s motion to change venue based on pretrial
  publicity because no evidentiary facts supported a finding of actual juror
  prejudice toward the State.â€Â  Id. at 9, 409 S.E.2d at 195. Â Â However, we
  noted that â€œwe think the better practice is to attempt to seat a jury prior
    to ruling on a motion to change venue based on pretrial publicity.â€Â  Id.Â  (Emphasis supplied).Â Â  
Here,
  the case having resulted in a mistrial, it was a nullity and therefore began
  anew when called again for trial.Â  State v. Mills, 281 S.C. 60, 314 S.C.
  324, cert. denied 469 U.S. 930 (1984) (when mistrial occurs because of
  inability of jury to agree on verdict, it is the same as if no trial took place).Â 
  Accordingly, the trial court properly exercised its discretion in attempting to
  seat a jury from Clarendon County prior to ruling on the motion to change
  venue.Â  
Inasmuch as the trial court was able to select an unbiased jury
  pursuant to our mandate in Manning, we find no error.Â  Accord State
    v. Evins, 373 S.C. 404, 645 S.E.2d 904, (2007) (grant or denial of change
  of venue after adequate voir dire of prospective jurors will not be
  overturned absent extraordinary circumstances).Â  
2.Â  EXCUSAL OF
  JUROR FOR CAUSE
Woods
  next asserts the trial court erred in excusing Juror Carolyn Hilton for
  cause.Â Â  We disagree.
A
  prospective juror may be excluded for cause when his or her views on capital
  punishment would prevent or substantially impair the performance of his duties
  as a juror in accordance with his instructions and his oath.Â  State v. Evins,
  373 S.C. 404, 645 S.E.2d 904 (2007); State v. Sapp, 366 S.C. 283, 621
  S.E.2d 883 (2005), cert. denied 547 U.S. 1133 (2006). When reviewing the
  trial courtâ€™s qualification or disqualification of prospective jurors, the
  responses of the challenged juror must be examined in light of the entire voir
    dire.Â  Id.Â  The determination whether a juror is qualified to serve
  in a capital case is within the sole discretion of the trial judge and is not
  reversible on appeal unless wholly unsupported by the evidence. Â Id.Â  A jurorâ€™s disqualification will not be disturbed on appeal if there is a
  reasonable basis from which the trial court could have concluded the juror
  would not have been able to faithfully discharge his responsibilities as a
  juror under the law.Â  State v. Green, 301 S.C. 347, 392 S.E.2d 157, cert.
    denied 498 U.S. 881 (1990).Â  Deference must be paid to the trial court who
  saw and heard the juror. Â Id. Â There will be situations where a trial
  court is left with the definite impression a prospective juror would be unable
  to faithfully and impartially apply the law, and this is why deference must be
  paid to the trial court. Wainwright v. Witt, 469 U.S. 412, 105 S.Ct. 844, 83 L.Ed.2d 841 (1985).
During voir
  dire, Juror Hilton was questioned extensively concerning her views on
  capital punishment.Â  When initially questioned about which type of juror she
  would be,[3] she indicated she would always vote for life imprisonment.Â  When the three
  types of jurors were explained to her again, she indicated she would be the
  third type of juror, indicating she would wait and see before deciding on
  punishment.Â  When the trial court questioned her as to whether, if they got to
  a sentencing phase, she could consider a life sentence, she responded, â€œyes.â€Â 
  However, when the court went further and questioned if, depending on the facts
  and circumstances, she could vote to return a verdict imposing the death
  penalty, she replied, â€œno.â€Â  The lawyers then questioned Juror Hilton and she
  reiterated to the solicitor that she could not vote for the death penalty.Â  She
  continued to maintain she would vote for life and could not vote for death.Â 
  After some vacillation, she indicated she would not feel comfortable signing a
  death verdict.Â  
Defense
  counsel then examined Juror Hilton, advising her that all twelve jurors would
  have to sign beyond a reasonable doubt to vote for a sentence of death.Â  Hilton
  replied she â€œguessedâ€ she could vote for such a sentence.Â  When questioned
  whether she could, after the vote occurred, confirm her vote on the verdict
  form, she again replied, â€œI guess.â€Â  After further voir dire and much
  vacillation, Juror Hilton ultimately maintained she was a type three juror, and
  felt she could vote for a death sentence and sign the death verdict.Â  
The
  trial court then meticulously reflected on whether Juror Hilton was qualified;
  the judge was clearly concerned that Juror Hiltonâ€™s initial responses seemed
  adamant in stating she could not vote to impose a death sentence.Â  The trial
  court felt her initial responses that she would not vote for a death sentence
  did not reflect any real confusion.Â  The trial judge ultimately ruled that he
  would re-read the transcript of Juror Hiltonâ€™s testimony before making a ruling
  the next day.Â  
When
  she was discharged for the evening, Juror Hilton was advised to go home and to
  call a recorded message after 6:00 p.m. the following night to find out when
  she was to return to the courthouse.Â Â  She was also told that when she
  returned, she was to bring with her enough clothing and personal items to stay
  for the seven to ten day duration of trial. Â The next day, the Clerk advised the
  trial judge that Juror Hilton had not come to court, and they had to go out and
  find her.Â  She also failed to bring any clothing or personal items.Â  
After further voir dire, the trial court ruled Juror Hilton
  was not qualified to serve, both because of her vacillation over the death
  penalty, and because of her inability to follow the courtâ€™s instructions.Â Â Â  
Woods now asserts Juror Hilton was improperly disqualified
  inasmuch as her views reflect an ability to recommend the death penalty in an
  appropriate case.Â  We disagree.
Initially,
  Woods does not challenge the trial courtâ€™s alternate basis for removing Juror
  Hilton, i.e., that she would not follow simple instructions.Â  Accordingly, the
  ruling is the law of the case and there is no basis for reversal.Â  Sloan v.
    S.C. Depâ€™t of Transp., 365 S.C. 299, 618 S.E.2d 876 (2005); South
      Carolina Tax Commâ€™n v. Gaston Copper Recycling Corp., 316 S.C. 163, 447
  S.E.2d 843 (1994) (failure to appeal an alternative ground of judgment below
  will result in affirmance). 
In any
  event, the trial court acted within its discretion in disqualifying the juror.Â  Accord State v. Sapp, 366 S.C. 283, 621 S.E.2d 883 (2005), citing Commonwealth v. Duffey, 855 A.2d 764 (Pa. 2004) (where voir dire indicated juror was somewhat unclear as to her convictions regarding imposition
  of the death penalty, and these concerns could have substantially impaired her
  ability to function as an impartial juror, the trial court was in the best
  position to make that determination and did not abuse its discretion in
  dismissing the prospective juror for cause); State v. Green, supra (the determination of whether a juror is qualified to serve on a death penalty
  case is within the sole discretion of the trial judge and is not reversible on
  appeal unless wholly unsupported by the evidence).Â  The trial courtâ€™s ruling on
  this issue is affirmed.[4]
PROPORTIONALITY
  REVIEW
We have
  conducted a proportionality review pursuant to S.C.Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-25(C)
  (2003). We find the death sentence was not the result of passion, prejudice, or
  any other arbitrary factor. Furthermore, a review of prior cases shows the
  death sentence in this case is proportionate to that in similar cases and is
  neither excessive nor disproportionate to the crime. See State v. Stanko,
  376 S.C. 571, 658 S.E.2d 94, cert. denied 129 S.Ct. 182 (2008); State
    v. Evins, 373 S.C. 404, 645 S.E.2d 904 (2007); State v. Hughes, 336
  S.C. 585, 521 S.E.2d 500 (1999), cert. denied 529 U.S. 1025, 120 S.Ct.
  1434, 146 L.Ed.2d 323 (2000); State v. Johnson, 306 S.C. 119, 410 S.E.2d
  547 (1991), cert. denied, 503 U.S. 993, 112 S.Ct. 1691, 118 L.Ed.2d 404,
  (1992); State v. South, 285 S.C. 529, 331 S.E.2d 775, cert. denied 474 U.S. 888, 106 S.Ct. 209, 88 L.Ed.2d 178 (1985).
Woodsâ€™
  convictions and sentences are affirmed.
AFFIRMED.
TOAL, C.J., PLEICONES, BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.


[1]Â  The Court of Appeals subsequently affirmed
  Woodsâ€™ convictions for first degree burglary and two counts of assault and
  battery of a high and aggravated nature in conjunction with the Linda Taylor
  offense.Â  State v. Woods, 376 S.C. 125, 654 S.E.2d 867 (Ct. App. 2007), cert. denied Oct. 23, 2008.Â  Woods was also tried and convicted of
  burglary, armed robbery and assault and battery with intent to kill in
  connection with a May 27, 2003 attack upon an eighty-four year old Clarendon County woman named Laura Jackson.Â  These convictions were recently affirmed by
  the Court of Appeals.Â  State v. Woods, Op. No. 2008-UP-536 (S.C. Ct. App. filed Sept. 16, 2008).Â  
[2]Â Â  The judge specifically noted the primary reason
  he had granted the motion to change venue in the first trial was due to the
  stateâ€™s consent, and the fact that the state wanted to be able to complete the
  trial in September 2006, before one of the solicitors was leaving to become a judge.Â 
  The court ruled that if it had not been for this consideration, the motion to
  move the trial to Marion County would have been denied.Â  
[3]Â  The trial court gave the jury a sheet listing
  the three types of jurors: 1) would always vote for death, 2) would always vote
  for life, or 3) would wait and hear facts and circumstances before deciding on
  punishment.Â  
[4] Â The remaining issues are affirmed pursuant to
  Rule 220(b)(1), SCACR, and the following authorities:Â  Woodsâ€™ Issue 3- Nix
    v. Williams, 467 U.S. 431, 446-47, 104 S.Ct. 2501, 81 L.Ed.2d 377 (1984); State
      v. McCord, 349 S.C. 477, 562 S.E.2d 689 (Ct. App. 2002) (exclusion of
  physical evidence not required in cases of inevitable discovery); State v.
    Gaines, 380 S.C. 23, 667 S.E.2d 728 (2008) (admission of evidence is
  harmless where it is cumulative); Woodsâ€™ Issue 4- State v. Stone, 285
  S.C. 386, 387, 330 S.E.2d 286, 287 (1985) (failure to object to charge as
  given, or request additional charge waives right to complain on appeal); State
    v. Cutro, 365 S.C. 366, 618 S.E.2d 890 (2005) (no error to refuse a charge
  on mere suspicion where trial courtâ€™s charge adequately instructs jury
  regarding reasonable doubt); Woodsâ€™ Issue 5- State v. Skipper, 285 S.C.
  42, 328 S.E.2d 58 (1985) revâ€™d on other grounds 476 U.S. 1 (1986) (Stewart limiting instruction required only where defendant not convicted in guilt phase
  of crime relied on by State as statutory aggravating circumstance); State v.
    Avery, 333 S.C, 284, 509 S.E.2d 476 (1998) (failure to object to jury
  charge precludes consideration on appeal).

title: State v. Odom
description: In this case, the Court reversed the circuit court's suppression of certain evidence obtained through the use of criminal discovery orders authorized by provisions of the federal PATRIOT Act.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				The State, Appellant,
				v.
				Anthony Clark
      Odom, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal from Spartanburg County
Â J. Mark Hayes, II, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26624
Heard March 5, 2009 - Filed March 30, 2009Â  
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Attorney
  General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
  Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General Deborah
  R.J. Shupe, and Assistant Attorney General William M. Blitch, Jr., all of
  Columbia, for Appellant.
				Andrew
  J. Johnston, of Spartanburg, Jack B. Swerling of Columbia, and Katherine
  Carruth Link, of West Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	


ACTING
  JUSTICE MOORE:Â  This case involves
  questions as to the validity of criminal discovery orders obtained by the State
  under the federal PATRIOT Act for use in an online child predator sting.Â  
Respondent
  Anthony Clark Odom (Respondent) allegedly communicated with a detective with
  the Spartanburg County Sheriffâ€™s Office, who was posing as a thirteen-year-old
  girl, in online chat rooms.Â  Respondent was charged with criminal solicitation
  of a minor.Â  In pre-trial hearings, the circuit court found that the Attorney
  Generalâ€™s office failed to comply with South Carolina law in procuring criminal
  discovery orders, and the orders were therefore not proper under 18 U.S.C. Â§
  2703(d) and 18 U.S.C. Â§ 3127(2)(B) (2006).Â  The court further found that parts
  of the undercover investigation violated internal policies.Â  The court denied
  Respondentâ€™s Motion to Dismiss but granted Respondentâ€™s Motion to Suppress
  certain evidence obtained pursuant to the orders and evidence obtained by
  methods which violated the policies.Â  The State appealed to this Court.[1]Â 
  We reverse.
FACTS
From
  March 12, 2006 until May 5, 2006, a detective with the Spartanburg County
  Sheriffâ€™s Office and member of the Internet Crimes Against Children Task Force
  (ICAC) chatted on Yahoo! Instant Messenger with an individual using the screen
  name â€œDanger6552000,â€ which also displayed the name â€œRoge Wilson.â€[2]Â 
  While chatting, the detective used a profile he created that indicated that the
  person chatting was a thirteen-year-old girl named â€œMelanie.â€[3]Â Â 
  The detective testified that many of the chats with Roge from March 12 until
  March 20 were conducted from his personal computer at his home, at times at
  which he was not officially on duty.
In
  the first chat, Roge noted that Melanie was thirteen years old and made
  sexually explicit comments, attempting to engage Melanie in cybersex.Â  In later
  chats, Roge continued to make sexually explicit comments.Â  Roge stated multiple
  times that he could not engage in actual sexual acts with Melanie until she was
  sixteen years old, but at one point he agreed to come see Melanie and at
  another agreed to meet her at the mall and take her to a hotel room, on both
  occasions for the purpose of having sex with Melanie.
On
  March 23, the Attorney Generalâ€™s Office requested an order from The Honorable
  G. Thomas Cooper, Chief Administrative Judge for the Fifth Judicial Circuit,
  under 18 U.S.C. Â§ 2703(d) to obtain information from Yahoo! related to the
  screen names used by Roge.Â  The State received the IP address[4] from Yahoo! and determined that the address belonged to Bellsouth Internet
  Service.Â  The State then requested another Â§ 2703(d) order to obtain the
  subscriber information and connection logs associated with the IP address,
  which was granted by the Honorable James W. Johnson, Jr.Â  Based on the information
  provided by Bellsouth, the State determined that the screen names used by Roge
  belonged to Respondent.Â  On May 8, the State requested and received another
  order from Judge Cooper to obtain more information about Respondentâ€™s account. 
The
  State indicted Respondent on one count of criminal solicitation of a minor in
  violation of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-15-342 (2006).Â  The circuit court held
  pre-trial hearings to deal with various motions made by Respondent.Â  The judge
  granted Respondentâ€™s Motion to Suppress information obtained from the discovery
  orders after finding that the Attorney Generalâ€™s Office did not comply with South Carolina law relating to the issuance of orders for pen registers and trap and trace
  devices. Â As a result, in the view of the trial judge, the South Carolina
  courts were not authorized to issue the orders under Â§ 2703(d).Â  Furthermore,
  the trial judge suppressed evidence of the internet chats between Respondent
  and the undercover officer which took place between March 12 and March 20 due
  to the fact that chats during this period were not conducted in compliance with
  ICAC Task Force standards.Â  The State appealed.

STANDARD OF REVIEW
Appellate
  courts are bound by fact findings in response to motions preliminary to trial
  when the findings are supported by the evidence and not clearly wrong or
  controlled by error of law. State v. Amerson, 311 S.C. 316, 320, 428
  S.E.2d 871, 873 (1993).Â  
ISSUES

	
		
			A.
			Did the circuit court err in finding that the South 
			Carolina courts were not authorized to issue the discovery orders 
			under Â§ 2703(d)?
 
		
		
			B. 
			Did the circuit court err in suppressing evidence 
			of chats between March 12 and March 20 due to violations of ICAC policies?
			
		
	

DISCUSSION
A. Authority to issue Â§
  2703(d) discovery orders
The
  State connected Respondent to the screen names associated with Roge through the
  use of criminal discovery orders allowed by the federal PATRIOT Act.Â  At the
  circuit court, the State acknowledged that the substantive factual showings
  contained in the applications made to Judge Cooper and Judge Johnson were less
  than the probable cause standard required to obtain an order for a pen register
  or trap and trace device under South Carolina law and that the sole legal
  authority upon which it relied in obtaining each of its discovery orders was 18
  U.S.C. Â§ 2703  (d).Â  The statute provides:

	(d) Requirements for Court Order. - A court order for
  disclosure under subsection (b) or (c) may be issued by any court that is a
  court of competent jurisdiction and shall issue only if the governmental entity
  offers specific and articulable facts showing that there are reasonable grounds
  to believe that the contents of a wire or electronic communication, or the
  records or other information sought, are relevant and material to an ongoing
  criminal investigation.Â  In the case of a State governmental authority, such a
  court order shall not issue if prohibited by the law of such State. 

18 U.S.C. Â§ 2703(d) (2006).Â 
  The term â€œcourt of competent jurisdictionâ€ is defined in 18 U.S.C. Â§
  3127(2)(B):

	(2) the term â€œcourt of competent jurisdictionâ€ means -
	. . . 
	(B) a court of general criminal jurisdiction of a
  State authorized by the law of that State to enter orders authorizing the use
  of a pen register or a trap and trace device;

18 U.S.C. Â§ 3127 (2006).
The
  circuit court found that the orders were not properly issued because, in his
  view, (1) the issuing courts were not â€œcourt[s] of competent jurisdictionâ€
  since they were not authorized to enter orders authorizing use of a pen
  register or trap device; and (2) South Carolina law prohibits Â§ 2703(d)
  orders.Â  We hold that both findings were legal errors.
(1) Court of competent
  jurisdiction
Section
  2703(d) provides that â€œ[a] court order for disclosure under subsection (b) or
  (c) may be issued by any court that is a court of competent jurisdiction . . .
  .â€ 18 U.S.C. Â§ 2703(d).Â  Section 3127(2)(B) defines a â€œcourt of competent
  jurisdictionâ€ as a â€œcourt of general criminal jurisdiction of a State
  authorized by the law of that State to enter orders authorizing the use of a
  pen register or a trap and trace device.â€ 18 U.S.C. Â§ 3127(2)(B).Â  
There
  is no dispute that the circuit court qualifies as a court of general criminal
  jurisdiction under the South Carolina Constitution. S.C. Const. art. V, Â§ 11.Â  Furthermore,
  Â§ 17-29-30(A)(2) allows a law enforcement officer of this State to apply for a
  pen register from any circuit court. S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-29-30.
Nonetheless,
  the circuit court found that the issuing courts were not courts of competent
  jurisdiction because, given that the State admittedly did not show probable
  cause, the courts were not authorized to issue pen registers in the instant
  case.Â  In short, he found that the courts failed the second part of Â§ 3127.Â  This
  was error.
Section
  2703 sets forth standards required in order to obtain information.Â 
  Specifically, Â§ 2703(d) requires a showing of â€œspecific and articulable facts
  showing that there are reasonable grounds to believe that the contents of a
  wire or electronic communication, or the records or other information sought,
  are relevant and material to an ongoing criminal investigation.â€ 18 U.S.C. Â§
  2703(d).Â  It is unlikely that Congress intended to require, as a threshold
  matter, that the forum stateâ€™s standard for the issuance of pen devices be met
  and then require that â€œreasonable suspicionâ€ standards of Â§ 2703(d) be met
  before a court order is issued.Â  Moreover, such an interpretation would defeat
  uniformity.Â  
The
  more logical reading of the statute is that by requiring that applications
  under Â§ 2703(d) be heard by a â€œcourt of competent jurisdictionâ€ Congress meant
  to ensure that the courts deciding whether or not to issue Â§ 2703(d) orders
  were competent to consider whether or not to grant orders of a similar type.Â 
  For this reason, we find that the circuit court erred in finding that the South
  Carolina circuit courts were not â€œcourt[s] of competent jurisdictionâ€ for
  purposes of Â§ 2703.
(2) Prohibited by the law
  of such State
Though
  Â§ 2703(d) allows for courts to issue orders for disclosure, it also limits the
  courtâ€™s power to do so where a State governmental authority seeks the order. 18
  U.S.C. Â§ 2703(d).Â  In that case, â€œsuch a court order shall not issue if
  prohibited by the law of such State.â€ Id.Â  In addition to finding that
  the issuing courts were not â€œcourts of competent jurisdictionâ€ under Â§ 3127,
  the circuit court found, under Â§ 2703(d), that the orders were prohibited by South Carolina law. 
The
  trial court found Â§ 2703(d) orders were prohibited by S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  17-29-20(A) (â€œExcept as provided in this section, no person may install or use
  a pen register or trap and trace device without first obtaining a court order
  under Â§ 17-29-40.â€).Â  The fundamental flaw in the trial courtâ€™s reasoning is in
  equating the issuance of pen registers and trap and trace devices with Â§
  2703(d) orders.Â  Section 2703(d) addresses orders issued under subsection (b)
  or (c) of Â§ 2703. 18 U.S.C. Â§ 2703(d).Â  Neither subsection calls for the
  issuance or use of pen registers and/or trap and trace devices.Â  Moreover, the
  information obtained through the use of either subsection is very different
  from the information obtained through the use of a pen register and trap and
  trace device.Â  
A
  pen register or trap and trace device is different from a Â§ 2703(d) order in
  two main ways.Â  First, while Â§ 2703(d) orders seek information retrospectively,
  a pen register or trap and trace device captures information after its
  installation. See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-29-10.Â  The devices intercept
  information in transmission while Â§ 2703(d) orders elicit information already
  in the possession of the provider. See 18 U.S.C. Â§ 2703(b), (c).Â  
Second,
  information obtained by a Â§ 2703(d) order is more specific than information
  obtained through use of a pen register or a trap and trace device.Â  While Â§ 2703(d)
  orders may be limited to a certain subscriber or time period, pen registers and
  trap and trace devices capture all phone numbers dialed from the targeted phone
  line without regard to the relevance to the ongoing investigation. See 68 Am. Jur. 2d Pen Registers Â§ 342 (2008).
Because
  Â§ 2703(d) orders do not call for issuance of a pen register or trap and trace
  device and allow parties to obtain information different than that obtained by
  a pen register or trap and trace device, we find that Â§Â§ 17-29-10, et seq. does
  not establish that Â§ 2703(d) orders are prohibited by South Carolina law.Â 
  Therefore, the trial court erred in finding that the orders were improperly
  issued on this ground. 

B. Suppression due to
  violation of ICAC policies
The
  circuit court suppressed evidence of the chats between Roge and the undercover
  officer that occurred between March 12 and March 20 due to the officerâ€™s
  non-compliance with the ICAC Program and Investigative Standards (ICAC
  Standards) which were incorporated into a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU)
  between Spartanburg and the Attorney Generalâ€™s Office.Â  
The
  MOU provides, among other things, that no personally owned equipment should be
  used in ICAC investigations and that only sworn, on-duty ICAC personnel should
  conduct investigations in an undercover capacity.Â  At the pre-trial hearing,
  the undercover officer admitted violating the policies by communicating with Roge
  while the officer was officially off-duty and using his personal computer,
  rather than on ICAC computers.Â  The ICAC computers are equipped with software
  capable of recording various information concerning all communications sent and
  received in the course of undercover investigation.
The
  State argues that the violations of the MOU and ICAC Standards go to the weight
  rather than the admissibility of the evidence.Â  We agree.
This
  Court has held on a number of occasions that violations of procedure go to the
  weight, rather than the admissibility of evidence. See, e.g., State
    v. Huntley, 349 S.C. 1, 562 S.E.2d 472 (2002) (failure to conduct
  breathalyzer test using required sample); State v. Carter, 344 S.C. 419,
  544 S.E.2d 835 (2001) (flaw in chain of custody).Â  Moreover, exclusion is
  typically reserved for constitutional violations. See Huntley,
  349 S.C. at 6, 562 S.E.2d at 474 (â€œExclusion of evidence should be limited to
  violations of constitutional rights and not to statutory violations, at least
  where the defendant cannot demonstrate prejudice at trial resulting from the
  failure to follow statutory procedures.â€).
The
  MOU and ICAC Standards are not codified and were created, not by the
  Legislature, but by law enforcement.Â  The MOU and ICAC Standards serve a variety
  of purposes.Â  We find that the violation of the MOU and ICAC policies speak to
  the weight of the evidence rather than its admissibility.Â  Therefore, the
  circuit court erred in suppressing the chats between March 12 and March 20 on
  this basis.
CONCLUSION
The
  circuit court erred in finding a violation of Â§ 2703(d) and in suppressing
  evidence on that basis and on the basis of violations of ICAC Standards.Â  We
  therefore reverse the circuit court.
REVERSED.
TOAL, C.J.,
  WALLER, BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

  appealable under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 14-3-330(2)(a) (1976).â€).
